m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Bellini, Giovanni | Italian | 1430-1516||Artist, workshop of: Workshop of Bellini, Giovanni | Italian | 1431-1516

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

The painting underwent major conservation treatment in 2004 and remains in good structural and visual condition. No intervention is needed at this time. 2012: The painting remains in good condition, both structurally and aesthetically. 2013: The painting remains in good condition, both structurally and aesthetically. 2014: The painting remains in good condition, both structurally and aesthetically. 2015: No apparent change, the painting remains in good structural and aesthetic condition. 2016: No change to the painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the frame and painting are unchanged at this time
The white ground is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment.
On display in CL111. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed on wall in gallery. 2018: In storage on a ladder with a flashlight; framed
Inscribed on the parapet cartellino with black paint: IOANNES BELL/INVS

The oil paint is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment. The original surface was quite damaged and abraded by early cleanings. Extensive inpainting was necessary to integrate the areas of loss with surviving original paint.

The frame appears to be an imitation of a Venetian Renaissance tabernacle style. It was antiqued to give it an old, worn appearance, notably in the blue with gold design flat panels where most of the design and lettering is rubbed away. Examination by a specialist would help to determine its age. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate. -2018: There are numerous old losses to the gilding that should be noted.This includes several untouched losses (especially around the joins in the structure of the frame). These do not appear to be new.
Examination of the frame by a specialist would help to determine its age and suggest any need for further work.
30 x 23 in. approximately 45-1/4 x 34-1/2 x 4-1/2 in. (framed)
The wood panel is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment.
The verso was not available for inspection but there is no reason to suspect that the condition of the cradle has changed.
The varnish layer is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment.
Madonna and Child with St. John the Baptist

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, workshop of: Workshop of Bellini, Giovanni | Italian | 1430-1516

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

The painting underwent major conservation treatment in 2000 and remains in good structural and visual condition. No intervention is needed at this time.
2012: There is no apparent change noted at this time.
2013: There is no apparent change noted at this time. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change in painting at this time. The frame shows seemingly new lifting within the old restoration on the proper right central blue design - At present the area appears stable; however, continued monitoring is advised with the need for localized stabilization possible. 2016: No change apparent to the painting. Minor consolidation was done to the frame using Lascaux medium for conservation to re-adhere minor lifting and one flake of gilding located along the left of the bottom frieze. Consolidation was also done along the right member to prevent any possible lifting from progressing. The frame is now stabilized but should continue to be monitored for any future signs of lifting. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the frame and painting are unchanged at this time
The white ground is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment.
On display in gallery. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall 2017: Framed on wall in gallery 2018: In storage on a ladder with a flashlight; framed

The oil paint is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment. Note that there are some small losses below the varnish layers in the red curtain that were never inpainted and show as tiny white spots. Some of the red inpainting has shifted slightly in tone and doesn't match perfectly but is not apparent under gallery lighting.

The frame is an imitation of a Venetian Renaissance tabernacle style. The frame is in sound structural condition but has suffered much loss of the flat blue paint that covers the gold leaf on the panels. Because of these losses, the detailed sgraffito design is not as legible as it could be. There is also a poorly executed old restoration on the proper right central blue design that should be redone someday. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate. 2015: There appears to be minor incipient lifting of the design within an area of old restoration at the cener of the frame's proper right rail that has resulted in a small pinpoint loss - At present the area appears stable; however, continued monitoring is advised with the need for localized stabilization possible.
Have the frame examined by a specialist to determine its age and quality. Treatment may be suggested at that time to correct the old poor restorations and areas of missing blue paint.
The wood panel is in sound condition. There has been no change in the repaired vertical cracks and splits since the last major conservation treatment.
The verso was not available for inspection but there is no reason to suspect that the condition of the cradle has changed.
The varnish layer is in sound condition. There has been no change since the last major conservation treatment.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Sarah Gowen, David Miller, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Jan Brueghel the Elder | Flemish | 1568-1625

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: Old paint cracks were noted. There are no apparent changes to the condition. 2013: Old paint cracks were noted. There are no apparent changes to the condition. 2018: The condition of the painting and frame appear unchanged. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame appear unchanged.

When viewing thinly painted areas of the composition, it is apparent that the wood panel support has been primed with a white ground. The ground appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is stable at this time. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees, the painting is marked with age craquelure typical for a painting of this time. The age craquelure is stable at this time.
2012: The craquelure pattern is most visible in the white clouds at the upper left. The design layers are stable. The cracks are fine and do not appear to be new.

In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2015: In conservation lab, unframed. 2016: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed on wall in gallery. 2018: In the conservation lab; unframed
IMA - William C. Griffith Jr. and Carolyn C. Griffith Gallery - H215
There is an inventory number (est.) in the bottom right corner of the front of the painting: "708."
The thinly applied oil paint is well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers and appears to be stable at this time.
The frame appears to be stable at this time.
15 x 24 in. approximately 21-1/2 x 31 x 2-3/4 in. (framed)

With the wood grain running horizontally, there is a slight convex warp to the wood panel support. This has been present for a very long time and the rabbet of the frame has long been modified to account for this slight curve in the panel. Within this context the wood panel support is stable. 2018- the wood was identified as Baltic oak; the panel was dated using dendrochronology to the early 17th century
The surface of the painting has been coated with a glossy varnish that was heavily applied. Small cleaning tests on the surface of the painting indicate that a very slight dust layer is present.
An enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dust and/or dirt.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Lucas Cranach, the Elder | German | 1472-1553

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

The painting is in good and structurally sound condition. Old cracks and splits in the panel are stable. The painting is worn and abraded in some areas from past restorations. Old retouchings are mostly well done. The varnish is matte, dull, and somewhat yellowed. The edges of the painting are rubbed from contact with the frame, most notably at the upper proper right edge.
2012: There is no apparent change in the condition. The paint remains stable.
2013: There is no apparent change in the condition. The paint remains stable. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: The painting underwent indepth technical examination and imaging in 2016; no apparent change was noted and both painting and frame are stable. 2018: The painting and frame are in unchanged condition.
The white ground is extensively cracked and slightly cupped but is stable at this time.
Framed and on the wall in the gallery. 2014, 2015,2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed on wall in gallery. 2018: Framed on wall in gallery with flashlight
IMA - William L. and Jane H. Fortune Gallery - H214
Painted inscription in the proper lower right corner, in yellow paint; painted crest in the bottom center; and a Cranach monogram/dated 1532 in brown paint between the inscription and the crest.

The oil paint layers are extensively cracked and slightly cupped but are stable at this time. The painting is worn and abraded in some areas from past restorations. Old retouchings are mostly well done but some have shifted slightly in tone and could be improved. There are a few small, scattered old losses of paint below the varnish that were never retouched. Tiny losses are scattered along the extreme outer edges and the paint is slightly rubbed from contact with the frame, most notably at the upper proper right edge

The imitation gilt and painted German frame is in good and sound condition. Wear marks are artificial distressing to make the frame appear to be older than it really is. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate.
Eventual cleaning and proper revarnishing will improve color and depth of the painting but is not critical at this time.
30 x 21-1/2 in. (panel) approximately 39 x 30-5/8 x 2-1/2 in. (framed)
The wood panel exhibits the same convex warp as it has for many years. The panel appears to be stable. Several cracks and splits along the bottom and top remain stable.

The verso was not available for inspection but there is no reason to be concerned about the cradle at this time. 2016: The painting is not cradled, cracks and splits remain stable and are bridged with fiberous material and adhesive.
The old natural resin varnish is matte, dull, and somewhat yellowed but is still adequate for display.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Commissioned from Ribera in 1636 by Karl Eusebius von Liechtenstein [1611-1684], Schloss Feldsberg (now in Czech Republic) via his agents Lorenzo Cambi and Simone Verzone;{1} By descent within the family of the princes of Liechtenstein, Vaduz, Liechtenstein; Sold to (Newhouse Galleries, New York, New York) in 1954;{2} Acquired by George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1955; Clowes Fund Collection until 2000 (C10066); Acquired by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2000 (2000.345).
{1} In 1983 Eduardo Nappi, in his article ”Pittori del ‘600 a Napoli: Notizie inedited dai documenti dell’Archivio storico del Banco di Napoli,” in Ricerche sul ‘600 napoletano, Milan 1983, pp. 73-87, published information documenting Ribera’s commission which he had located in the archives of the Banco dello Spirito Santo, Naples. See also, Craig Felton, “Ribera’s ‘Philosophers’ for the Prince of Liechtenstein, The Burlington Magazine, vol.128, no. 1004 (November 1986): pp. 785-789 who, following Nappi, transcribes the archival notation as: Banco dello Spirito Santo, giornale del 1636, matr. 270, partita di ducati 100, estinta il 7 maggio. A Lorenzo Cambi e Simone Verzone D. 100. E per lui a Gioseppe de Ribera, dite se li pagano per ordine del conte Carlo Felesbergh et esserno in conto di D. 500 per il valore di dodici quadri d’altezza e di palmi cinque e palmi quattro di larghezza in ognuno dei qualci ci ha da essere dipinto un filosofo di sua propria mano che ha pigliato a fare per servito di don Carlo Felisbergh et quelli han da consegnare a loro fra sei mesi et mancando de consignare debbia restituire tutto il denaro ad ogni loro piacere. The prince is identified here as “Carlo Felesbergh.” Until then, the first source documenting a Liechtenstein provenance for the Ribera painting of Aristotle dated from 1767; see Vincenzio Fanti, Descrizzione Completa di tutto ciò che ritrovasi nella galleria di pittura e scultura di sua altezza Giuseppe Wenceslau del S.R.I. principe regnant della casa di Lichtenstein, Vienna, 1767, p. 105, cat. no. 531. {2} See Clowes Archive, Newhouse Galleries correspondence, letter from Clyde Newhouse to GHAC, dated 22 November 1955, containing some information on this painting. Paintings from the collection of the princes of Liechtenstein were dispersed in 1954, including several of Ribera’s philosophers. Other paintings from this collection went to the National Gallery in Ottawa, Canada, in the same year; see “Canada acquires paintings from one of Europe’s noted collections,” Canadian Art, vol. XI, no. 4 (summer 1954): pp. 142-144.

The painting is in stable structural condition. The canvas is taut and in good plane. The dark colors have suffered from abrasion due to harsh cleaning in the past. The varnish is yellowed and old retouchings have discolored but the overall appearance is acceptable. 2012: No apparent change. 2013: Minor scratch in varnish below and to the right of the proper left elbow. Can be easily corrected locally. Otherwise no apparent change. 2014: Slight scuffing of the varnish in the wax seal. With minor treatment, the varnish can easily be reformed in this localized area. No apparent change to frame. 2015: No change to painting or frame. 2016: The painting and frame underwent indepth technical examination in December, 2016. No apparent change to painting or frame was observed. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: In-depth technical exam was completed. No change was to the painting or frame was observed at this time

A red ground is visible where the paint is thin or abraded. The ground has cracked overall, following the open basket weave pattern of the canvas, typical of the time. The ground is stable with no evidence of weakness.
On display in the gallery; framed and on the wall. 2016: On display in the gallery; framed and on the wall. 2017: On display in the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2018: Unframed in conservation lab
Signed and dated in black paint on the paper below the sitter's proper left hand, Jusepe de Ribera espanol F. 1632. An illegible wax seal is present in the extreme bottom proper left corner.

Oil (assumed) paint, applied thinly with a brush in the dark colors and more thickly with bravura brushwork in the flesh tones and lighter colored passages. The dark colors, especially the background, are very abraded from past harsh cleanings. The texture of the paint is somewhat flattened from the lining process, dulling the vibrancy of the brushwork. Lots of darkened, mismatched old retouching is visible below the varnish.

The carved, gilt, and painted 17th century Spanish style wooden frame is in good condition. Small. insignificant damages and abrasions are scattered around the outer edges. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate.

Reduction/ removal of the discolored varnishes and old retouchings would greatly improve the appearance of the painting but there would be extensive inpainting required to integrate the abraded dark colors. It would be a lengthy and worthwhile treatment but is not critical at this time.
49 x 39 in. (canvas) 56-7/8 x 46-9/16 x 3 in. (framed, not glazed)

The painting is executed on an open basket weave canvas, typical of the artist. The canvas appears to be in good condition and is well bonded to the lining canvas. The canvas is taut and in good plane.

The painting is glue lined. The verso was not available for inspection at this time but previous inspections have shown the lining to be in good condition and well bonded to the original canvas. The replacement stretcher is in good condition. 2018: the verso was examined and the lining canvas was found to be in good condition

The painting is uniformly coated with a thick resin spirit varnish, possibly Dammar, that has discolored to a medium yellow-brown. Darker residues of older resinous coatings are trapped in interstices. A modern synthetic varnish was applied on top of the discolored coating to saturate and unify the older coatings in order to return depth to the picture. The synthetic coating is in good condition.
2013: minor scratch in varnish below and to the right of the proper left elbow. Can be easily corrected locally.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: Both the painting and frame appear to be stable. No changes noted. 2013: No changes noted to either the painting or frame. 2014: No apparent changes to painting or frame, both remain stable and suitable for display. 2015: No change to painting or frame. 2016: No change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged 2018: The condition of the painting and frame remain unchanged

When viewing thinly painted areas of the oil sketch it is apparent that the wood panel support was primed with a white ground. Exhibiting localized areas of age craquelure the ground layer appears to be stable and well adhered to the wood panel support. From a previous restoration attempt, an area within the right portion of the horizontal seam of the wood panel appears to be locally filled and retouched. These areas appear to be stable at this time. It should be noted that the strong diagonal/irregular brushstrokes of the ground layer are evident throughout the composition, creating a slight underlying texture to the overall composition.

In gallery, framed and on wall. 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall. In-depth analysis was recently conducted (Oct. 2014) in the conservation studio with the painting unframed. 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery 2018: Conservation lab; in frame
IMA - William C. Griffith Jr. and Carolyn C. Griffith Gallery - H215

The thinly applied oil paints appear to be stable and well adhered to the ground layer. The minor and localized areas of fill and retouch adequately match the color and opacity of the surrounding original paint.
Frame appears to be stable at this time. 2014: Frame remains stable.
19 x 25-1/2 in. (panel) approximately 28-1/2 x 34 x 3-1/4 in. (framed)
Comprised of two pieces of wood, running horizontally, the wood panel support is stable and relatively in plane. 2018: The wood was identified as Baltic oak.
The surface coating is moderately glossy. Small cleaning tests indicated there is no significant accumulation of dust or dirt on the front of the painting.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dust or dirt.
Triumphant Entry of Constantine into Rome

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: Both painting and frame appear to be stable at this time with no apparent change. 2013: Painting and frame remain the same with no apparent change noted. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: Painting and frame appear to be generally stable with no changes noted. 2016: No changes to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018. There is no change in condition to the painting at this time. A small loss was noted on the frame but it is unclear if this loss is new. The frame is otherwise unchanged.
There appears to be a light colored ground that is slightly visible through areas of abrasion in the paint layer. The adhesion between the ground and the fabric support appears stable at this time.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2015, 2016: In gallery, framed on wall. 2017: Framed, in gallery on wall. 2018: Framed, in gallery on wall, with flashlight.
IMA - William L. and Jane H. Fortune Gallery - H214
There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting. 2016: A signature is present on the rock in the bottom center of the image underneath the donkey's legs.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. There is marked old abrasion throughout the paint layers, especially in thinly painted areas. Additionally, there are cracks throughout the paint, both mechanical and drying cracks. Both types of cracks appear to be stable at this time. The traction cracks are likely the results of the artist's technique and materials and are slightly visually distracting in the darkly painted trees.
There are some areas of old inpainting, which have only slightly discolored over time.

The frame appears stable and adequately supports the painting. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface. There are several nicks and small losses, most of which have been compensated. 2014: A small blue smudge is present on the lower frame member, left side. It appears to be old, and worn, but should be noted. 2018: a loss (1cm x 0.5cm) to the ground and gilding on the frame was noted on the upper edge. It is unclear if this loss is new but should be noted. The condition of the frame is otherwise unchanged.
28 x 38-1/2 in. approximately 36-3/8 x 46-1/2 x 3-3/4 in. (framed)

The fabric support appears stable at this time and is taut and in plane. The original support has been lined to a second fabric support. The adhesion between the original support and the lining appears stable at this time.
The surface coating is relatively even in gloss. The coating is slightly hazy and no longer fully saturates the colors of the painting.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Sarah Gowen, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Speber (2018)

Possibly from a convent near Bregenz, Austria, Private Collection, Austria, Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana, until 1958; The Clowes Fund; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2004.
2004.157 nt 2011-06-30 normal light (strobe) recto right panel #7
2004.157 nt 2011-06-30 normal light (strobe) recto right panel #7
2004.157 nt 2011-06-30 normal light (strobe) recto right panel #7

The panels are all currently structurally stable and in reasonable visual appearance. As an ensemble, they read well enough in gallery light but individually they have varying states of preservation; with old cracking, warping of the wood panel, extensive old damage/ loss of original paint/ gilding, and copious repainting common to all.
2012: No apparent condition changes were noted at this time. 2012, January: A new mounting system was designed, fabricated, and installed by IMA mount maker Paul Siebenthal and Chief Conservator David Miller. Security battens were added at the top and bottom of the assemblages for extra protection. The arrangement of the panels remains the same but they are now very securely attached to the display boards. 2013: No apparent condition changes were noted at this time. 2014: Panel and display remain stable with no changes. 2015: No changes noted to the panels/display mount. 2016: The panels and display mount appear to be stable with no changes. 2017: The panels and display mount appear to be stable with no changes. 2018: The panels and display mount appear to be stable with no changes.

The wood was first covered with plain-woven fabric before an aqueous white priming layer was applied. The surface is quite smooth and regular - the fabric is only visible with x-rays. This structure is typical for the period. The layers are structurally stable at this time.
2004.157 nt 2011-06-30 normal light (strobe) recto right panel #7

2011: Conservation laboratory. 2012: Gallery C203 2013: Gallery C203 2014: Gallery C203 2015: On display in the gallery. 2016: On display in the gallery. 2017: In the gallery, on display. 2018: In storage on display boards with a flashlight

The egg tempera and gold leaf layers are currently structurally stable but have been seriously damaged by previous restorations. The present surface has been heavily repainted and the gold in-filled or retouched with gold paint. The green borders are almost entirely repainted.

The paintings were acquired by Dr. Clowes from Newhouse Gallery in the Gothic style triptych frame shown above but it is doubtful that this is the correct sequence.The panels are currently temporarily attached to two separate display boards while research continues to determine the proper arrangement of the scenes. The system is stable and secure but should not be considered a long-term solution.
2012, January: A new mounting system was designed, fabricated, and installed by IMA mount maker Paul Siebenthal and Chief Conservator David Miller. Security battens were added at the top and bottom of the assemblages for extra protection. The arrangement of the panels remains the same but they are now very securely attached to the display boards.

A long-term solution for display needs to be discussed. This could include devising a framing system to hold the individual panels in what is determined to be the proper sequence, or could be as extreme as an extensive and very expensive major conservation treatment to rejoin the panels into solid boards again (this would require a specialist in panel painting conservation). Removal of the copious repaints would reveal little original paint left in many areas and would be a very lengthy treatment; however, the painting would ultimately look much better and be closer to its original appearance. However, treatment is not needed at this time and is not crucial to long-term preservation.
approximately 14 x 7 in. (each panel) 33-1/2 x 53 in. (framed)

The original wood panels were cut apart into 12 pieces and were thinned to 0.8-0.9 cm as part of the cradling process. The original sequence of the scenes is under study. Each panel has different cracks, splits, warping and small losses, none of which pose any hazards at this time.

Each panel is cradled with three vertical fixed members and three horizontal sliding members. Some of the sliding members are slightly frozen and require effort to move but they pose no hazard. There have been additional small strips of wood glued to the backs of the top and bottom edges for extra support.

Each panel is heavily coated with a natural resin varnish, such as Dammar, which has yellowed to a distinct yellow tone, masking the true colors of the compositions. In 2007, minor treatments included application of a modern synthetic varnish to improve clarity and saturation of the colors and design. The current appearance, although discolored, is acceptable and in good condition.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)
François de Scepeaux, Paris, 1566; Jean de Scepeaux, Paris, by descent; Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, 1950-1958; The Clowes Fund, Inc., 1958-2004

2012: Painting and frame appear to be in stable condition with no apparent change at this time. 2013: No apparent change to painting or frame noted at this time. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame noted at this time. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame noted at this time. 2017: Painting and frame remain stable after full conservation treatment. 2018: painting and frame remain stable and in good condition after the conservation treatment.
There is a light-color ground layer that is visible through cracks in the paint. The adhesion between the ground and panel support appears stable at this time.

In the gallery, framed, and on the wall. 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: After full conservation treatment in Spring/Summer 2017, the framed painting was returned to the gallery. 2018: In storage with flashlight on ladder; framed
The date 1566 is painted in the upper right corner.

The adhesion between the ground and paint layers appears stable at this time. The paint exhibits marked crack patterns throughout the surface, mainly following the vertical grain of the wooden panel. The cracks in the sitter's black garments is very visually distracting as it exposes the underlying light-colored ground. All of the cracks appear stable at this time. 2015: Examination under magnification sugessts that the disfiguring appearance of cracks likely results from degraded varnish rather than exposed ground.

The frame appears stable at this time. There are numerous old areas that exhibit minor abrasion and losses to the ebony finish. The metal elements show some minor distortions, which also appear to be old.

Conservation treatment could be carried out to address the discolored layers of varnish and overpaint as well as the prominent crack pattern, however, any treatment would take a substantial amount of time to complete and require careful and thorough examination and analysis prior to any work.
12-1/2 x 9-1/4 in. (panel) approximately 19 x 16-1/4 x 2 in. (framed)

Overall, the support appears to be stable. The panel exhibits a minor convex warp along the vertical grain of the wood. The panel appears to be comprised on a single plank of wood and there is no evidence of cracks or splits.
The varnish is relatively thick and appears slightly discolored. The surface sheen is relatively glossy and even, except for a few streaks, accretions, and old splatters on the surface.

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Hans Schäufelein the Elder | German | 1472-1540

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: Painting and frame appear to remain stable with no apparent change noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. Additional notations added to frame section. 2015: No change to painting or frame. 2016: No change noted to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged 2018: No changes to the painting or frame at this time

There is an overall light-colored ground visible through thinly painted areas. Through some small areas of abrasion, there appears to be an underlying red layer. This red layer appears to be under the light-colored preparatory layer in most areas of the background, but not where the sitter is painted. Examination under high magnification would be necessary to confirm this observation. The adhesion between the preparatory layers and wooden support appears stable at this time. There are minor losses to the ground and paint layers along the edge of the panel. These losses appear old and there is no evidence at this time that the surrounding areas of ground and paint are unstable.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2016: Framed in the gallery and on the wall. 2017: Framed, in gallery, on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed
Date and inscription painted across the top.

The adhesion between the oil paint and ground layers appears stable at this time. There is abrasion throughout the paint layers, especially in the thinly painted areas and details, including the sitter's hair.
There are numerous areas of old inpainting throughout the composition. The inpainting no longer matches the surrounding original paint in color or opacity, especially in the background.

The frame appears stable and adequately houses the painting at this time. There is general wear and abrasion to the gilded surfaces, especially at the knull edge and inner fillet. 2014: There is some blanching in areas of retouched sgraffito, bottom frame member. Does not appear to be recent.
17-1/2 x 12 in. (panel) approximately 36 x 24 x 2 in. (framed)

The wooden panel appears stable and in plane. There are two old vertical cracks that run the entire length of the panel (in the direction of the wood grain). These cracks may correspond to joins in the support, but further examination would be necessary to better determine the construction of the panel.

The surface gloss has a relatively even satin sheen. There are a few areas in the sitter's face and in the bottom right corner that appear slightly matte. These areas may be associated with old areas of inpainting. There is a small scuff or scratch in the bottom right that may be delamination of underlying layers of varnish.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, David Miller, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: There is no apparent change to the condition of the painting. 2013: There is no apparent change to the condition of the painting. 2014: No change in painting or frame, both remain stable and suitable for display. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016: No change in painting or frame. Minor preventative consolidation was done to the frame in areas of exposed gesso using Lascaux medium for consolidation. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the condition of the paintings or frame at this time.

When viewing thinly painted areas on each panel, it is apparent that each was primed with a white ground. This preparatory layer appears to be generally well adhered to the wood panel support and is stable at this time. Affecting the ground, paint and gold layers in varying degrees, each panel is also marked with overall age and mechanical craquelure. The craquelure appears to be generally stable at this time.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed on wall in gallery. 2018: Conservation lab; unframed

The thinly applied tempera paints appear to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers and is stable. Passages of abrasion are evident in both the tempera paint layers as well as the gold (background, clothing decoration and words) as a result of a previous restoration attempt. In several instances, particularly the gold background, these areas have been retouched. In general the fills (where applicable in the upper portion of the gold background) are stable. Areas of retouch adequately match the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint/gold layer.

The frame appears to be stable at this time.
2012: The frame remains stable. There are several, old losses that expose tiny areas of the underlying white gesso and numerous areas of old retouching and abrasions. These are not new, but were not previously noted.
2013: The frame remains stable. There are several, old losses that expose tiny areas of the underlying white gesso and numerous areas of old retouching and abrasions. These are not new, but were not previously noted.
2014, 2015: No change in condition of frame.
2018: There is no change to the condition of the frame at this time.
No treatment necessary at this time.
28 x 8 in. (each) approximately 40 x 41 x 3-3/4 in. (4 panels installed)

Comprised of four separate wood panels, one for each saint. Each panel has been thinned and cradled. The male saints have thin strips of wood on either edge. St Catherine has a thin strip on the right edge but not the left edge and St Catherine has a strip on the left edge but not the right edge. Each panel appears to be generally in plane and is stable at this time. It should be noted that the top left and right gilded back ground of each panel appears to have been filled and retouched during a previous restoration attempt. These areas appear to be stable and their consistency and general uniformity suggest that each panel was originally in an altar setting that had a slightly smaller configuration on the top.
The surface of the painting appears to be only slightly glossy. Small cleaning tests indicate the accumulation of a slight dirt layer on the surface of the painting.
A mild enzymatic solution was used on the surface of the varnish to determine the presence of dirt.
St. Mary Magdalene, St. Benedict, St. Bernard of Clairveaux and St. Catherine of Alexandria

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Sarah Gowen, David Miller, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Neroccio di Bartolommeo de' Landi | Italian | 1447-1500

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2014: No change to painting, frame exhibits some splintering and would need consolidation. 2015: No change in painting or frame- splintering in frame has not progressed further. 2016: The painting underwent extensive examination, photo documentation, and treatment in 2016 which included: old varnish and restorer's paint removal, aqueous dirt/grime reduction, barrier varnish application, fill application, inpainting, and final varnish application. The painting's condition has greatly improved and the frame remains stable. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the frame or painting are noted at this time

From viewing areas of thinly applied tempera paint, it is apparent that the wood panel support had been primed with a white ground layer. This preparatory layer appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is generally stable at this time. Affecting the ground and paint layers in varying degrees, the painting is marked with overall age and mechanical craquelure. The craquelure is very old and appears to be stable at this time. In addition there are localized areas of loss to the ground and paint layers which were filled and retouched during a previous restoration attempt. These areas of repair appear to be stable at this time. 2016: Ground remains stable and securely adhered to the wood panel. Wood worm holes were filled and inpainted during treatment.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015,2016: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: framed, on wall in gallery using flashlight
IMA - William L. and Jane H. Fortune Gallery - H214

Typical for a painting of this time period, the tempera colors were thinly applied in several layers. Portions of the Christ Child and Madonna's hands were never completed by the artist. Areas of paint abrasion are evident throughout the composition from previous restorations. In many instances these areas have been retouched to some degree, most noticeably in the Madonna's dark blue robe, where extensive areas of loss were retouched. The areas of retouch only moderately match the color texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint. 2016: Varnish coatings and areas of retouch were reduced where safe clearance could be achieved without risking original colors - a band of old, thickly applied, opaque restorers paint remaines along the bottom hem of the Madonna's robe. Losses related to insect damage, inherent deterioration of original paint (blue of mantle), and human intervention (abrasion and scratch in Madonna's cheek and neck) were improved through selective fill applicaiton and inpainting.

The frame appears to be stable at this time. 2014: There is some splintering and lifting of the wood due to age on the outside edge of right member at bottom right corner. 2016: Name plate was removed from the bottom rail and minor filling, consolidation, and retouching were completed at the time of the painting's treatment.

No treatment necessary at this time. In the future conservation can be considered in conjunction with curatorial research. 2014: Minor consolidation of outside of frame should be considered in the near future.
28 x 20-1/8 in. approximately 32-7/8 x 25 x 3 in. (framed)

The wood panel support appears to be generally in plane and stable at this time. Very old losses along the edges of the panel are mostly covered by the rabbet of the frame. Very old and dormant wood worm holes are present in the composition, many of which are filled with retouch. 2016: Exposed wood worm holes were filled and inpainted during treatment.

The surface of the painting is semi-matte in appearance. Small cleaning tests indicate the accumulation of a slight dirt layer on the surface. 2016: Dirt and degraded varnish were cleared using appropriate aqueous and solvent based solutions, a barrier layer was applied to separate conservation materal from original, and a final coat of varnish spray applied after inpainting was complete. The painting's appearance has greatly improved.

A mild enzymatic solution was used on the varnished surface of the painting to determine the accumulation of dirt. 2016: Varnish over each color was tested with a range of solvents prior to cleaning to determine appropriate cleaning solutions.
Madonna and Child with St. John the Baptist and St. Mary Magdalene

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: El Greco | Greek | 1541-1614||Artist, workshop of: Workshop of El Greco | Greek | 1541-1614

Parish church of Almadrones (Guadalajara), Spain, until 1936 or immediately after{1}; removed to the Fuerte of Guadalajara (former convent of San Francisco) until 1941{2}; at the Museo Nacional del Prado, Madrid, for conservation treatment, 1941-45; restituted to the bishopric of Sigüenza in 1945, sold and legally exported in 1952{3}; (Newhouse Galleries, Inc. New York, New York); Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, 1952{4}; The Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, 1958-2007 and on long-term loan to IMA since 1971 (C10035); given to IMA in 2007 (2007.53).
{1} Eyewitness accounts confirm that prior to the Spanish Civil War (1936-39), this painting, along with others from the same series, was in the parish church of Almadrones (Guadalajara). The American hispanist, Harold Wethey, in a letter to Dr. G.H.A. Clowes wrote: "Dr. F. Layna Serrano...is a native of the province of Guadalajara and knows this whole region. He visited the church at Almadrones before the civil war and saw the apostles when they still hung in the church. He says that the pictures were high on the walls and hard to see. He intended to go back and investigate them further, but the civil war came and he never had another opportunity" (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive). {2} The Marqués de Lozoya, Director General de Bellas Artes from 1939 to 1951, had the Almadrones paintings taken to the Prado for restoration: "El Sr. Comandante del 'Fuerte de Guadalajara' halló en los desvanes del mismo NUEVE lienzos enrollados los que fueron toscamente restaurados por un sargento aficionado a la pintura, y después se colocaron en un sitio alto y muy poco visible. En una de las visitas que a este centro realizó el Sr. Marqués de Lozoya pudo observar que los aludidos lienzos eran auténticos "Grecos" proponiendo y consiguiendo del señor comandante fueran traidos a los talleres del Prado, para su adecuada restauración como, en efecto, así se hizo. Dichos cuadros representan "San Juan", "Santiago", "San Felipe", "San Simón", "Santo Tomás", "San Bartolomé", "San Pablo", "El Salvador" y "San Andrés" (Declaration of Francisco J. Sánchez Cantón to the Museum's Patronato in 1944). The document is included in the unpublished catalogue of paintings by El Greco and made available to the IMA by Leticia Ruiz in November 2005. As Ruiz observed, the word "NUEVE" in capitals means that the series was not complete when it arrived at the Prado. The paintings were received by the Prado on September 10, 1941: "Museo Nacional del Prado. He recibido del señor Teniente Coronel Primer Jefe de los Talleres y Centro electrotécnico de Ingenieros de Guadalajara NUEVE LIENZOS del Apostolado del GRECO, que entrega a este Museo del Prado según órdenes recibidas y que serán restaurados en el mismo. Madrid a 10 de septiembre de 1941." Expediente de restauración de nueve lienzos del Greco (apostolado) propiedad de la Agrupación de Ingenieros de Guadalajara (10 de septiembre) Año 1941. (Archivo del Museo del Prado). {3} Five paintings (including this one) were restituted to the bishop of Siguenza in July 14, 1945 and subsequently sold. The four remaining paintings in the series were acquired by the Spanish Government for the Prado Museum (Archivo del Museo del Prado, caja 79). A letter from the director of the Prado, Fernando Álvarez de Sotomayor (Madrid, November 21, 1952) states that the paintings were "shipped out of Spain this year." (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive). {4} Invoice dated November 6, 1952 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

2012: There does not appear to be any change to the painting or frame at this time. 2013: Painting and frame appear to be stable with no change noted. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No change to the painting or frame at this time

There appears to be an overall toned ground, or possible imprimatura, that is slightly visible through the thinly applied brushstrokes of paint. This layer appears well adhered to the support. There are areas of previous loss and damage to the ground and paint that have subsequently been retouched. These areas appear stable at this time.

In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery. 2018: In storage with flashlight on ladder; framed
Painted initials in background near St. Matthew's proper left shoulder.

The oil paint appears well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers. There are areas of previous loss and damage to the ground and paint that have subsequently been retouched. These areas appear stable at this time.
The areas of retouching adequately match the color, texture, and opacity of the surrounding original paint at this time.

The frame appears stable at this time. There are numerous old damages and minor losses to the gesso and gilding. These areas currently appear stable. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface of the frame. The painting is glazed. 2018: frame has a layer of surface dust

The plain-weave fabric support appears stable and in plane. The canvas appears to be lined and there are possible previous tears; one on the right side, near St. Matthew's proper left shoulder and a second below and left of center in St. Matthew's blue robes. These areas of previous damage appear stable at this time.

The surface has an overall satin gloss. The gloss appears even throughout the surface.
Small cleaning tests indicate that there is a slight accumulation of dirt on the surface.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dirt.

Clowes Collection Archive). {4} Invoice dated November 6, 1952 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

2012: Both the painting and frame appear to be stable. No changes noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged. 2018: No changes to the painting or the frame at this time.

There appears to be a toned or red-colored ground which is visible where there are gaps between brushstrokes of paint, through areas where the paint is thinly applied, and in areas of abrasion to the paint. The adhesion between the ground and support appears stable at this time.

On the wall in the gallery and framed. 2014: In the gallery, framed, on the wall. 2015, 2016: In the gallery, framed, on the wall. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery. 2018: In storage with flashlight at eye level; framed
There are painted initials in the lower left corner below the saint's proper left hand.

The adhesion between the oil paint and preparatory layer appears stable at this time. There are numerous old areas where there appear to be losses and creases to the paint layer. These areas have been previously stabilized and inpainted. There are small, old losses throughout the paint layer that have not been filled or inpainted. These losses are covered by varnish and appear to be stable at this time.
The areas of inpainting have discolored and no longer match the surrounding original paint.

The frame appears stable at this time. There are numerous old damages and minor losses to the gesso and gilding. These areas currently appear stable. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface of the frame. The painting is glazed.

The original fabric support has been lined to a second support. There are no obvious signs of any previous damages to the original support. Overall, the support appears stable at this time and is taut and in plane.

The varnish is semi-glossy and relatively even throughout the surface. The varnish appears to be slightly discolored and there is a slight accumulation of dirt on the surface.
2014: A few matte spots are visible in the varnish layer on the subject's proper left sleeve, likely from retouching.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnish to evaluate accumulation of dirt on the surface.

Luis Pérez, Alcoy (Valencia), by 1908. Probably Frank G. Macomber, Boston. Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958].

2012: Both the painting and frame appear to remain stable with no change at this time.2013: No change noted at this time.2014: The painting was treated in July-August 2014 and is in significantly better condition aesthetically. No apparent change in frame.Summary of treatment: The varnish and overpaint were removed during the treatment. The painting was re-varnished with a stable synthetic varnish (B-72). Fills (Flugger) and retouching (pigments and Laropal A-81) were applied, and the painting was given a final saturating layer of varnish.2015: No apparent change to painting or frame.2016: No apparent change to painting or frame.2017: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2018: There is no change in the condition of the frame or the painting at this time

There is a toned or red-colored ground that is visible between strokes of paint or in areas where the paint is abraded. The adhesion between the ground and fabric support appears stable. 2014: analysis indicates a brown pigmented ground layer.

In the gallery, framed and on the wall.2014: In conservation studio, unframed. An in-depth technical analysis was conducted in August 2014.2015, 2016: In conservation studio2017: Framed in conservation lab. 2018: In storage with a flashlight at eye level; framed
There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. The paint displays numerous old cracks, including a small network of cracks across Christ's face, and abrasion throughout. Additionally, there are areas of old retouching that no longer match the surrounding original paint in color or opacity.

The frame appears stable at this time. There are numerous old damages and losses to the gesso and gilding. These areas currently appear stable. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface of the frame.

The fabric support appears stable, taut, and in plane. It also appears to have been previously lined to a second support. There are some cracks or creases along some of the edges, indicating that the original support may have been extended either by unfolding the tacking margins or by expanding the original canvas with additional pieces of canvas. Further examination while unframed would be necessary to fully determine the structure of the support. The fabric support appears stable, taut, and in plane. It also appears to have been previously lined to a second support. There are some cracks or creases along some of the edges, indicating that the original support may have been extended either by unfolding the tacking margins or by expanding the original canvas with additional pieces of canvas. Further examination while unframed would be necessary to fully determine the structure of the support. 2014: The painting was cut down to just a fragment, eliminating signs of construction such as cusping or selvedges. The painting has been lined. Canvas strips were attached to the lining canvas next to the original painting to extend the picture plane and complete the radiating light from Christ’s halo. This was likely done to “complete” the image as with the additional benefit of giving more room for framing.

The varnish appears generally dull, hazy, and discolored. There are some small surface splatters in the varnish in the bottom corners of the painting. There is a slight accumulation of dirt on the surface.2014: The varnish and overpaint were removed during the treatment. The painting was re-varnished with a stable synthetic varnish (B-72).

When viewing areas where the tempera paint has been more thinly applied, it is apparent that the wood panel support has been primed with a white ground. This preparatory layer appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is stable at this time. It should be noted that in the background, a red bole was applied on top of the preparatory layer. The bole was textured and gold leaf had been applied on top. Affecting all of these layers as well as the tempera paint and ground, the painting is marked with overall age and mechanical craquelure typical for a painting of this age. The craquelure appears to be stable at this time. 2016: A canvas layer was applied to the panel prior to the ground layer, as found in the technical analysis. 2018: It should be noted that additions at the bottom of the panel are slightly raised where the green addition meets the gold (especially on the left and right). (1776-1837): An Exhibition, Paintings, Drawings, Watercolors, Mezzotints held at Salander-O-Reilly Galleries, New York, 1988, p. 18, plate 25. Artist, follower of: Follower of Caravaggio, Michelangelo Merisi da | Italian | 1573-1610

Private Collection, Ireland.{1} (Count Ivan Podgoursky [1901-1962], New York) by 1948; Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1952; The Clowes Fund Collection since 1958 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10016); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2010.
{1} A. Ian Frasier, former curator of the Clowes Collection, writes in A Catalogue of the Clowes Collection, Indianapolis 1973, p. xxvii: "For a long time this picture was in a convent in Ireland." This information has not been verified.

The painting is structurally sound. The canvas is lined and in good plane. The aesthetic appearance of the painting is as good as it can be without major treatment to remove and redo the existing mismatched retouches, inpainting, and cloudy coatings.
2012: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The painting and frame remain unchanged.
The priming is a white layer, artist-applied, with additional priming over the seams in the canvas to produce a smooth surface. The ground is stable and in good condition.
On display in CL109. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall 2017: framed, on wall in gallery 2018: framed, on wall in gallery with flashlight.
IMA - William L. and Jane H. Fortune Gallery - H214

The oil (assumed) paint was applied in a smooth manner, often blended wet-in-wet. It is relatively thin and shows little brushmarking. The lining process flattened the texture of the paint considerably with heat and pressure so a determination of the original surface texture is not possible. The painting has been cleaned and restored many times, most notably in the 20th century to remove extensive repainting that had altered the composition into a Christ Child with a Crown of Thorns. Removal of these and most likely other restorations resulted in extensive damage and abrasion of the original paint film, especially in the dark colors. Modeling shadows in the flesh tones were also compromised. In subsequent years, a number of inpainting and varnishing campaigns attempted to integrate the damaged areas with varying success.

The frame is in good condition. There are a few scattered very small losses of gold leaf on the inner rail and liner. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate.

To fully understand this painting, all of the coatings and retouchings need to be removed to expose what is left of the original. Scholars could then assess the painting properly and advise on reconstruction of the damaged areas to make the picture look as good as possible. Removal of the previous restorations will also permit scientific analysis and technical studies of the painting free of any confusion caused by later interventions.
25-3/4 x 41-1/2 in. (canvas) approximately 34-1/2 x 49-1/4 x 4-1/4 in. (framed)

The painting is executed on three pieces of canvas, originally sewn together to enlarge the composition. The structure is easily visible in x-ray. The canvas is in good condition and does not require relining at this time.
The lining is well bonded to the original canvas and is in good condition at this time. Relining is not needed. The canvases are taut and in good plane. The replacement stretcher is satisfactory.

The painting is coated with a number of layers of synthetic varnish in attempts to saturate the colors and return depth to the painting. There is a general haziness of the coatings, coupled with imperfectly saturated areas of inpainting that detract from the painting's appearance; however, the overall gloss and appearance is satisfactory enough for display.

Baron Henri-Marie-Bruno-Joseph-Léon Kervyn de Lettenhove [1856-1928], St. Michel-lez-Bruges and Brussels; by descent to Colette H. Dawson (Mrs. John W. Dawson), Zionsville, Indiana, from 1948 {1}; purchased in 1960 by Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1885-1967], Indianapolis;{2} the Clowes Fund Collection, 1967-2010 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10014); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2010.
{1} Upon the death of Baron Henri Kervyn de Lettenhove in 1928, his estate was divided between his wife (who died in 1934) and one surviving child, the Vicomtesse Roger le Sergeant d'Hendecourt (died 1942). The four children of the latter were minors on the death of their father; two died in 1945, and the estate remained undivided until 1948, when it was inherited by Colette Dawson and her sister. Correspondence from John W. Dawson to Allen W. Clowes, 23 September 1960 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive). {2} Sales agreement, 19 August 1960 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

Silberman, New York); purchased by Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958] in 1933;{2} The Clowes Fund Collection, since 1958 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10057); Given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2010.
{1} See Austellung von Meisterwerken alter Malerie aus Privatbesitz sommer 1925, Städelsches Kunstinstitut, Frankfurt am Main, 1926, cat. no. 67, in which the captions to the illustrations on plate V (cat nos. 67 and 121) are reversed. When William E. Suida published and illustrated the painting in an article "Some Bolognese Trecento Paintings in America," Critica d'arte, 1951, pp. 52-58, the caption was again printed erroneously as "57. Jacopo de Bologne, New York, Kress Collection" (rather than "57. Simone, Clowes Collection, Indianapolis). See Suida's letter to Dr. Clowes dated 28 October 1951 (IMA Clowes Collection Archive). {2} Appears on a list of paintings bought from Silberman by Dr. Clowes dated February 22, 1934 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

Probably in the collection of the Italian line of the Savoy Family.{1} Hugo Kilényi [1840-1926], Budapest.{2} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York); {3} Dr. George Henry Alexander] Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, before January 1936;{4} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, 1958-2010 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10059); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2010.
{1} A partially damaged red wax seal, probably the Savoy family coat-of-arms, is present on the back of the painting. {2} Kilényi's collection was dispersed at auctions held at the Ernst Museum, Budapest, in 1917 and 1927. This painting, attributed at the time to Perugino, was not in either auction. {3} Prior to establishing a gallery in New York, Elkan and Abris Silberman had galleries in Vienna and Budapest, see for example the advertisement in Burlington Magazine, February 1926, p. xxiv. {4}Letter from Abris Silberman to G.H.A. Clowes, dated 14 January 1936, sending him an expertise by William Suida (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

From viewing thinly applied areas of paint it is apparent that the panel was primed with a white ground. This preparatory layer appears to be generally well adhered to the wood panel support and is stable at this time. Affecting the ground and paint layers in varying degrees the painting is also marked with overall age craquelure. This craquelure appears to be generally stable at this time. In several instances the craquelure has been retouched during a previous restoration.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2016: In gallery, framed and on wall. 2017: In gallery, framed and on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed
No signature or distinguishing marks on the front.

The oil paint appears to be generally well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers and is stable at this time. There are several old losses, mostly along the extreme outer edges of the painting (note one above the angel's head, hidden in the shadow of the frame and visible in old photos). Areas of paint abrasion are evident as a result of a previous cleaning attempt. In many instances these areas were retouched at that time. The retouching in the sky only fairly matches the color and opacity of the surrounding original paint, whereas other areas of retouch throughout the painting appear to more adequately match the color and opacity of the surrounding original paint.

The frame appears to be stable at this time. 2014: Frame appears structurally sound. Some old losses and restorations are visible, but the frame has suffered no recent damages. 2015: loss on left beaded border revealing white gesso layer, consolidation should be done in the near future. 2016: Recent loss on beaded border revealing white gesso layer overall, frame needs minor consolidation and retouching. 2018: Loose ribbon ornament on upper left side of frame. Consolidated with Lascaux medium for consolidation.
No immediate treatment necessary at this time. In the future consider conservation treatment in conjunction with additional curatorial research.

There is a slight concave warp to the wood panel support which was accommodated for, a long time ago, by the rabbet of the frame. This type of aging characteristic is common for many panel paintings of this age. The wood panel appears to be generally stable at this time. Minute losses along the edge of the panel, partially covered by the rabbet of the frame can be seen, particularly in the bottom left corner where an old loss is present that was not previously filled or retouched. This area appears to be stable.
The surface of the painting appears to be slightly glossy in appearance. Small cleaning tests indicate an accumulation of a slight layer of dirt.
A mild enzymatic solution was used to determine the accumulation of dirt on the varnished painting.

2015: Consolidation of frame, particularly along left beaded edge where a loss reveals the white ground layer. 2016: Consolidation and retouching along the beaded edge of the frame where losses are noted. 2017: Recommend localized consolidation of frame. Areas of discolored inpainting in sky of the composition should also be readjusted. A final varnish layer applied on top of this.

m.mv:
Eugène Rodrigues [1853-1928], Paris. {1} Possibly (Ivan Podgoursky [1901-1962], New York);{2} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, before 1963;{3} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, until 2010 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10083); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2010.
{1}At lower right the drawing bears the collector's mark of Eugène Rodrigues, a Parisian lawyer and art collector (see Lugt 897). {2} Count Ivan Podgoursky, at times affiliated with Demotte Gallery, New York, sold many works of art to G.H.A. Clowes in the 1940s and 1950s, including another chalk drawing attributed at the time to Watteau. For information on Podgoursky, see his obituary in the New York Times, 23 April 1962. {3}This drawing is included in Pierre Rosenberg and Louis-Antoine Prat, Antoine Watteau 1684-1721 Catalogue raisonné des dessins, vol 1, Milan 1996, no. 68. Here it states that it entered the Clowes Collection by 1955 with reference to a letter from Walter Friedlaender to Dr Clowes of that date. There is no such letter, only an attestation dated 1955 by Friedlaender on the back of a photograph (which was likely given to Dr. Clowes by the dealer at the time of purchase). The first exhibition to include this drawing was Northern European Painting - The Clowes Fund Collection, Indiana University Museum of Art, Bloomington, Indiana, 1963, cat. no. 12.
The drawing is executed in red chalk (sanguine) on laid & chain paper

The drawing is in good condition.
2012: The drawing remains in good condition. It has not been moved from storage since the 2011 survey. 2013: No changes observed in the drawing. 2014: The drawing has remained in storage throughout 2014. No changes in condition have been observed. 2015: The drawing has remained in storage throughout 2015. No changes in condition have been observed. 2016: No changes in condition observed in the drawing. The drawing has been loaned to the Frick Gallery in 2016. Low light level restrictions were in force, and an IMA courier was assigned to the loan. 2017: The drawing has remained in storage throughout 2017. It was examined by new Curatorial staff in November 2017 as part of a larger survey. No changes in condition have been noted. 2018: No changes in condition are noted.
IMA Print Study, next to Prints, Drawings, & Photographs Storage 2013 - Print Study 2014 - Print Study 2015 - Print Study 2016 - Print Study 2017 - Print Study 2018 - Paper Laboratory
Collector's mark, black ink, lower right corner, recto. Appears to be superimposed letters R or B, and C
The image is executed in red chalk, or sanguine. The lines have a soft, subtly rubbed quality; a known counterproof was pulled from the three figures on the left (National Gallery of Sweden).

Drawing is stored permanently framed in bin storage. The drawing was acquired in the current mat and frame. The mat is decorated in the "French mat" style with hand printed inscriptions in iron gall ink: "Ecole Francaise du XVIII S" "Antoine Watteau". The mat is discolored and stained, constituting a visual distraction. The frame is gold leafed with many scratches revealing the red bole or gesso. It is also very shallow, barely holding the mat and a 4-ply matboard backing. Security hardware is attached. Glazing is Plexiglas.
2016: Drawing has been rematted in an 8-ply archival window mat and framed in a larger format gold-leafed frame with an archival blueboard backing.

The mat should be removed and archived, replaced with an IMA museum mat. The frame is not from the 18th century, and could also be replaced if desired. The drawing might be unframed and stored in a Solander box if it is matted in an IMA standard size mat. (NOTE: in the past this drawing was on permanent display in the Clowes galleries, and has only in recent years been retired to storage. It will now be rotated on a regular IMA schedule for works on paper) NOTE: The drawing was rematted and framed in 2016.
2012: No actions have been taken to alter the matting and framing for this work. These are low priority concerns, as the drawing has been inactive since the last survey.
2013: No actions have been taken to alter the matting and framing for this work. 2015: No actions have been taken to alter the matting and framing for this work. The IMA has a Curatorial vacancy for this collection at the moment. When it is filled, such discussions can begin to take place.
2016: Rematted with archival materials and reframed.
5 fc of light. The drawing was on continuous display for many years, so it would now benefit from a long uninterrupted period in storage.
The drawing is stored framed, upright in a slot storage cabinet in Prints, Drawings & Photographs storage. Climate is held to current museum standards.

The support is a cream-colored, laid & chain handmade paper. A felt texture is apparent. The paper is unlined, but lays relatively flat. The overall tone of the paper has darkened to beige, and there are several very small incidental stains. There is a small hole in the skirt area of the second figure from the left, and the lower right corner has been reattached. The paper is in stable condition.

Archduke Leopold Wilhelm [1614-1662], Brussels, then Vienna, by at least 1659; {1} Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister, Vienna, by 1895, and Staatsmuseum, Vienna, by 1923. {2} Possibly Princess of Thurn and Taxis. {3} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York); Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, by 1940; {4} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10049); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1}The painting is included as an unnumbered engraving by Nicolaus van Hoy in David Teniers the Younger’s Theatrum Pictorium, Antwerp, 1660, which documents Hapsburg Archduke Leopold Wilhelm’s most admired Italian paintings. It is also listed in a 1659 inventory as no. 357, see Adolf Berger, “Inventar der Kunstsammlung des Erzherzogs Leopold Wilhelm von Osterreich, nach der Originalhandschrift im Fürstlich Schwarzenberg’schen Centralarchive,” in Jahrbuch der Kunsthistorischen Sammlungen des Allerhöchsten Kaiserhauses, vol. 1, Teil II (1883), p. cvi. {2}The painting is included in the Führer durch die Gemälde-Galerie, Alte Meister. Vol 1 (Italienische, Spanische und Französische Schulen), Kunsthistorische Sammlungen des Allerhöchsten Kaiserhauses, Vienna 1895, cat. no. 241 as Jacopo Tintoretto. It is subsequently listed in Erich von der Bercken and August L. Mayer, Tintoretto, Munich 1923, vol. 1, p. 247. {3}This owner is given in A. Ian Fraser, A Catalogue of the Clowes Collection, Indianapolis 1973, p. 34 (“Princess Thurn and Taxis, after 1907”) and is repeated in Rodolfo Pallucchini and Paola Rossi, Tintoretto: Le opera sacre e profane, Milan 1982, vol. 1: cat. no. A46. By contrast Lionello Venturi, in an expertise dated 1 September 1937, writes that the painting remained in the possession of the Austrian state collection until 1933 when it was sold; see IMA Clowes Archive (C10073). Neither of these paths has yet been confirmed. {4}The painting was first exhibited in the United States in Four Centuries of Venetian Painting, Toledo Museum of Art, March 1940, cat. no. 56 (ill.), as owned by Clowes.

2012: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2014: No change in painting or frame, both remain stable and suitable for display. 2015: No change in painting or frame, slight accumulation of dust on the surface. 2016: No change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: A small scratch in the varnish was noted. This could be easily reformed. There are no changes to the condition of the painting or frame

From viewing old areas of abraded paint it appears as though a dark warm red-brown priming and/or imprimatura is present on the canvas support. Additional microscopic investigation would be necessary to determine the presence of other preparatory layers. At present the preparatory layer(s) appear to be well adhered to the canvas support and are stable at this time. Affecting the paint and preparatory layer(s) in varying degrees the painting is marked with overall age craquelure. The craquelure appears to be stable at this time. Finally, old losses along the bottom and upper right portions of the composition were filled and retouched during a previous restoration attempt. These areas appear to be stable.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: In storage at eye level with a flashlight; framed

The oil paint appears to be generally well adhered to the underlying preparatory layer(s) and is stable. Areas of paint abrasion are evident throughout the composition as a result of a previous cleaning attempt. In several instances these areas were not retouched. In instances where retouching is present it generally matches the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint.
The painting appears to be in generally stable condition. The frame has many old losses and insect damage (currently inactive) but appears to be in generally stable condition.
No immediate treatment necessary at this time. In the future consider conservation treatment in conjunction with curatorial research.
21-3/4 x 36-3/4 in. (canvas) approximately 30-1/2 x 44-1/2 x 3 in. (framed)

The support is a twill weave fabric. During a previous restoration attempt this support was backed with an additional piece of fabric. The adhesion between the original and backing (lining) support appears to be stable. Areas of old damage/repair are present intermittently along the bottom of the composition as well as along the top right edge where old fills and retouch are present. The fills and retouching appear stable at this time.

The surface of the painting is slightly glossy. Small cleaning tests indicate the accumulation of a slight layer of dirt. A natural resin varnish is present over the entire surface, and has discoloured over time. A layer of dust and dirt is also present on the surface of the painting. -2018: there is a small scratch in the varnish on the figure farthest to the right beneath the red fabric. This could be easily reformed.
A mild enzymatic solution was used to determine the accumulation of dirt on the surface of the varnished painting.
