Probably church of San Miguel, Cardona, Spain. {1} (Newhouse Galleries, New York) by 1957; {2} Edith Whitehill Clowes [1885-1967], Indianapolis, in 1959; {3} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10078A-B); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1}See Josep Gudiol, Pintura Gótica Catalana, Barcelona 1986, pp. 99, 358. {2}See advertisement in The Connoisseur, vol. CXL, no. 566 (December 1957), p. lxvi (ill. of C10078B). {3} Purchase agreement, dated 10 April 1959; see IMA Clowes Archive.
The areas of possible separation between the gesso and the wooden support should be closely monitored.

2012: Painting and frame appear to be stable at this time with no apparent change. 2013: Painting and frame remain the same with no apparent change noted. 2014: Painting and frame are in stable condition, no apparent changes. Areas of cracking and possible separation were closely observed and show no change in condition. 2015: No Apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: No Apparent change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the painting or frame at this time

There are numerous old areas where the gesso and paint layers appear to have lifted or separated from the wooden panel support. These mainly appear top surround the old, horizontal cracks that run through the width of the support. There are several areas where the gesso layers currently appear raised and should be closely monitored.
There is an old burn in the upper right quadrant located on the scalloped arch. The burn has affected the surface, ground, paint, and primary wooden support.

In the gallery, framed, and on the wall. 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2015: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery. 11/13/2017: In gallery, framed on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed

The areas of gilding display a marked amount of abrasion that exposes the underlying red bole. Additionally, the paint layers display some abrasion and numerous old losses. The majority of the paint losses have been retouched or inpainted, but the retouching has become slightly discolored.
There is an old burn in the upper right quadrant located on the scalloped arch. The burn has affected the surface, ground, paint, and primary wooden support. 2015: Old scratches and incised lines are also visible throughout the painting and appear to be part of the working method during the construction of the painting.
The painting is mounted in a shadow box frame that appears to adequately support, protect, and display the painting.
The areas of possible separation between the gesso and the wooden support should be closely monitored.

The wooden panel appears relatively stable at this time. There are several old cracks and splits in the panel that appear to have been previously stabilized and retouched. Additionally, there are areas that exhibit previous insect damage. There is no evidence of active insect damage or infestation at this time.

The surface coating has an overall, satin sheen and appears relatively even. It has become slightly dull over time and does not fully saturate the colors of the painting. There are some matte areas, most of which correspond to areas of previous retouching. There is a glossier area in the varnish on the right side of the painting (brown cloak area).
Localized testing with a mild enzymatic solution indicated that there is a moderate accumulation of dirt on the surface.
A cotton swab and a mild enzymatic solution were used to test the accumulation of surface dirt.

Possibly Lord Boston, Hedsor, Buckinghamshire, England. {1} (David M. Koetser, New York and London); (Ivan Podgoursky [1901-1962], New York).{2} Mary Charlotte Hunter[1881-1971], near Reading, by 1949.{3} (John H. Folman, Bronxville, NY);{3} sold to George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958] in 1957;{4} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10050); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} This information is recorded in the catalogue raisonné portion of Anne Dubois de Groër, Corneille de La Haye dit Corneille de Lyon, Paris, 1996, no. 135 (ill.) and in a number of earlier IMA publications; however it may be in error. Although Lord Boston [1860-1941] did own a female portrait by Corneille de Lyon, sold at Christie’s, London, Catalogue of Pictures by Old Masters, the Property of the Right Hon. The Late Lord Boston, formerly at Hedsor, Bucks…., 6 March 1942, lot no. 57, based on the auction catalogue description it is not this painting, but refers to de Groër, no. 142 (ill.). {2} A letter from Koetser to IMA, dated 15 June 1959, indicates that he sold the painting to Podgoursky; see Clowes Archive (C10026). Koetser also recalls that he purchased the painting in London, but cannot remember the collection he obtained it from. For information on Podgoursky, see his obituary in the New York Times, 23 April 1962. {3} See Christie’s, London, Catalogue of Old Pictures…the property of Miss Mary Charlotte Hunter of Beech Hill House, near Reading…, 29 April 1949, lot. no. 25. {4} See Bill of Sale, dated 25 September 1957, in IMA Clowes Archive.

2012: The painting and frame appear to be generally stable at this time with no apparent change. 2013: No apparent change to the painting or frame at this time. 2014: No apparent change in painting. Previous restoration of the right column exhibits some delamination (not currently active) and needs consolidation in the future. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change noted with painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the condition of the painting or frame

From viewing areas of thinly applied paint it is apparent that the wood panel support has been primed with a white ground. This preparatory layer appears to be well adhered to the wood panel support and is stable. Affecting the paint and ground in varying degrees, the painting is marked with overall age craquelure typical for a painting of this age. Areas of craquelure appear to be stable at this time.

In the gallery, framed and on the wall behind a plexi-glass covered niche within the wall. 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall, behind plexi-glass. Additionally, the painting underwent a full technical examination in the conservation studio May 2014, where it was unframed. 2015: In gallery, framed, behind Plexiglas. 2016: In gallery, framed, and installed behind Plexiglas. 2017: In gallery, framed, installed behind Plexiglas. 2018: In conservation lab, framed

The wood panel support appears to be generally in plane and is stable at this time. It suffered serious damages in the past, including infestation.
A cradle was attached to the verso of the panel during a previous conservation campaign, and has seized.

The surface of the painting has been coated with a varnish layer that was heavily applied. Because the painting is displayed behind plexi-glass no testing for the presence of surface dust/dirt was made at this time. 2018: tested for the presence of surface dust/dirt. No surface grime observed.

Artist, circle of: Circle of Botticelli, Sandro | Italian | 1444-1510

Exported from Milan, between 1792 and 1860. {1} Prince Tassilo Festetics de Tolna [1850-1933], Keszthely, Hungary; {2} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York); George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1933; {3} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10029); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} A red wax seal appears on the verso showing the two-headed eagle of the Austrian Empire, the initials FI in the center (a probably reference to Ferdinand I of Austria), and the words “Dogana di Milano.”According to Andrea Di Lorenzo, Curator at the Museo Poldi Pezzoli in Milan, a seal of this type could only have been in use until 1859-60; see correspondence with Di Lorenzo from May 2007 in IMA Provenance File (C10029). For a similar seal, see the entry for Bergognone’s Christ Rising from the Tomb (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., Samuel H. Kress Collection, 1952.5.1) in Miklós Boskovits and David Alan Brown, Italian Paintings of the Fifteenth Century, National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., 2003, pp. 126-129. Branded into the back of the panel are the initials “GES,” whose meaning has not yet been determined. {2}This information comes from an unpublished presentation brochure compiled by Silberman Galleries at the time of purchase; see IMA Clowes Archive. The painting was then attributed to Piero di Cosimo. {3} See receipt from A. Silberman to Clowes, dated 28 December, 1933; see IMA Clowes Archive, (C10029).

The painting is stable and in sound condition at this time. The long vertical cracks in the panel bear watching as there is evidence of several past damages and restorations along their length. The paint is worn and abraded with extensive restorations. Many areas of restoration no longer match in color or tone. The varnish is moderately yellowed. However, the painting is still visually acceptable.
2012: There appears to be no apparent change to the condition of the painting. The long vertical cracks in the panel do not appear to have moved. Additionally, the small, old losses in the rocks in the bottom right remain unchanged at this time.
2013: There appears to be no apparent change to the condition of the painting. The long vertical cracks in the panel do not appear to have moved. Additionally, the small, old losses in the rocks in the bottom right remain unchanged at this time.
2014: No change in painting, cracking network is stable, areas near pre-existing losses unchanged. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016: No change to painting or frame. 2017: No change to painting or frame. 2018: The condition of the painting is unchanged. A small loss to the gilding on the frame (not previously recorded) was noted. This area is stable.

The white gesso ground is in stable condition. Losses are present around the wood joins and the edges. Much of these have been previously filled and retouched. A micro cracking pattern, characteristic of natural aging of a wooden support,extends over the entire painting, particularly evident in the flesh tones. There is more significant cracking and old losses in the joins of the panels, which were subsequently filled and retouched. Much of the areas of glazing have been heavily abraded from invasive previous cleaning. This is particularly noticeable in the glazes of the trees and shrubbery where abrasion has resulted in less defined edges, as well as the halos. The paint layer is also abraded along the edges where the painting is in contact with the frame.

On display in CL112. 2014: unframed, in conservation lab. See technical examination (2014) for in-depth analysis. 2015, 2016: framed, in gallery, on wall. 2017: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed

The oil paint layers are stable and in good condition at this time. The paint is worn and abraded with extensive restorations. There are many small old losses that were never retouched in past restorations. Many areas of restoration no longer match in color or tone. Small losses associated with old cracking are noted at the extreme bottom proper right, in the stone parapet.

The frame is generally in good condition. There are scattered small losses and some areas of rubbing and abrasion in the blue polychrome and the gold sgraffito. There are old but stable cracks in the lower proper right corner of the spandrel. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate. 2014: The frame continues to be in stable condition, with no additional losses or damage. 2018: a small loss to the gilding (not previously recorded) was noted on the lower edge of the frame.

Watch the small losses in the stone parapet at the extreme bottom proper right, and the long vertical cracks in the panel also bear watching, particularly at the bottom center in the Madonna's blue robe. The painting would benefit from cleaning but is not necessary at this time.

The wood panel appears to be stable at this time. The long vertical cracks in the panel bear watching as there is evidence of several past damages and restorations along their length, particularly at the bottom center in the Madonna's blue robe.Some insect channeling is visible from the verso as well as in the x-ray. The panel remains in its original thickness. The verso of the joins have been previously conserved with linen and glue, covering the seams completely. There is slight wear along all edges.

The panel has a cross batten attached via a dove-tailed slot. The batten may have been added at the time the panel was created or shortly after. There are no problems associated with the cross batten.

The panel is evenly coated with a now quite yellowed natural resin varnish, followed by modern synthetic varnishes. The painting would benefit from cleaning but it is not necessary at this time. 2016: Minor abrasions are present in the varnish, and appear not to affect the paint layer.
Madonna and Child with St. John the Baptist

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Walter Gay [1856-1937], Paris by 1904.{1} Possibly Jules Strauss, Paris. {2} Germain Seligmann of (J. Seligmann et Fils, Paris and New York) by 1931;{3} (Pierre F. Nesi, Beverly Hills, California) by 1947;{4} purchased by George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958] in 1947;{5} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10028); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} The American painter Walter Gay, residing in France, loaned the painting to the Exposition des Primitifs Français au Palais du Louvre, Paris, 1904, cat. no. 177. The painting is included in Anne Dubois de Groër, Corneille de La Haye dit Corneille de Lyon, Paris, 1996, cat. no. 119 (ill.). {2} Provenance information provided by both Seligman and Nesi give Jules Strauss, a major collector of Impressionism, as a former owner. Although inconclusive, e-mail correspondence with his grandson Michel Strauss in December 2010 revealed that the painting is not listed in Jules Strauss’s notebooks, still in the possession of his grandson. {3} The painting was loaned by Seligmann to an exhibition “Art through the Ages” at the Cleveland Museum of Art in fall 1931. Although there was no catalogue for this exhibition, files in the Registration Department confirm this painting’s inclusion in the exhibition; correspondence with Cleveland Museum of Art, December 2010, in IMA Provenance file (C10028). {4} The painting is documented as being sold by Seligmann to Nesi in the Jacques Seligmann & Co. records at the Archives of American Art, Washington, D.C., Box 180, folder “G.H.A. Clewes (sic)”; see copy in IMA Provenance file (C10028). Germain Seligman, in a letter to Nesi, dated 10 June 1947 about the painting, indicates that he visited both Walter Gay and Jules Strauss, the two successive earlier owners, quite often in Paris; see IMA Clowes Archive (C10028). {5} Bill of Sale from Nesi to Clowes, dated 26 July 1947; see IMA Clowes Archive (C10028).

2012: No apparent change to the painting or frame at this time. 2013: The painting and frame appear to be stable at this time. No apparent change noted. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No change to painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change noted to painting or frame at this time. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the painting and frame remain unchanged at this time

When viewing more thinly applied areas of paint in the composition it is apparent that the wood panel support has been primed with a white ground. The ground appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is stable at this time. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees the painting is marked with overall age craquelure which appears to be stable at this time. 2014: The cracking networks on the surface are consistent with the stresses the painting would have experienced from a wooden support. There is some draw on either side from the stretching of the canvas, as well as additional cracking consistent with paintings on canvas.

In the gallery, framed and on the wall behind a plexi-glass coverd niche in the wall. 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall in display case. Probably Emile Gavet, Paris. {1} probably Count Tassilo Festetics [1850-1933], Budapest.{2} (Duveen Brothers, Paris) in the inter-war period.{3} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York); Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1942; {4} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, in 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10001); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} In an undated expertise authored by Lionello Venturi, probably dating to the early 1940s, Venturi identifies the painting as having been in “the Emile Gavet Collection, Paris, about 50 years ago.” A French custom’s stamp appears on the back of the painting. {2} Written in pencil on the verso: “Herzog Tassilo Festetics/ B.Pest.” Another painting in the Clowes Fund Collection was obtained by the Silberman brothers from the Festetics Collection (C10029). {3} An oversize photograph in the Richter Archive at the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C. is stamped “Duveen Brothers Inc., Paris”; see also the exhibition catalogue Masaccio e le origini del Rinasciemento, Casa Masaccio, San Giovanni Valdarno, Italy, 20 September to 21 December 2002, cat. no. 32, pp. 194-196 (ill.) wherein Miklós Boskovits refers to the existence of this photograph. The Richter Archive of Illustrations on Art was given to the National Gallery of Art by Solomon R. Guggenheim in 1943. {4} A cancelled check for a painting by Uccello, made out to E. & A. Silberman, is dated 12 November 1942; see IMA Clowes Archive.

2012: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2014: No change in painting or frame. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016: No change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the painting and frame at this time

From viewing areas of thinly applied oil paint it is apparent that the wood panel support was primed with a white ground. This layer appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is stable at this time. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees, the painting is also marked with age craquelure, typical for a painting of this period. The craquelure appears to be stable at this time.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall 2018: In conservation lab; framed with view of verso

The oil paints appear to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers and is stable at this time. Areas of paint abrasion are evident, from a previous restoration attempt, of retouch is readily evident, particularly in the sitter's face, clothing and background. In these instances the retouch adequately matches the color of the surrounding paint layers.
The frame appears to be stable at this time.
No treatment necessary at this time.
The wood panel support appears to be stable and generally in plane at this time.

The surface of the painting has been coated with a moderately heavy varnish that is unevenly glossy and matte. Small cleaning tests indicate that a slight accumulation of dirt is present on the surface of the painting.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of dirt.

Sir Richard Levinge [1911-1984], Knockdrin Castle, Ireland; to (C. Marshall Spink, London), possibly via (Adolf Fritz Mondschein, Vienna, Austria) in 1939. {1} (E. and A. Silberman, New York);{2} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1941;Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10006); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1}Spink corresponded with G.H. A. Clowes in 1956-57; informing Clowes that he bought the painting from Sir Richard Levinge, see Clowes Archive, Indianapolis Museum of Art, letters dated 6 April 1956 and 15 February 1957. In the letter, Spink relates that he was recently in contact with Levinge to learn the origin of the painting; Levinge reported that he had no old records. The Friedländer Project of the RKD, Den Haag, contains a photograph of the painting bearing a Friedländer notation on the verso that reads: “Spink London/ d.[urch]Mondschein/VI.39.” It is possible, but not confirmed, that Spink had business connections with Adolf Fritz Mondschein, later known as Frederick Mont after his emigration to the US in 1939, during this period. {2}Abris Silberman congratulates G.H.C. Clowes on his recent purchase of this picture, see IMA Clowes Archive, letter dated 24 February 1941.
Watch areas of lifting paint and ground in the proper upper right figures and proper lower far right figure.

The panel, paint and ground are mostly stable, with only a few minor areas of lifting paint in the proper upper right figures and proper lower far right figure. There is no danger of imminent loss. Modern pencil marks are visible in the faces of two figures. There is extensive old retouching that has changed color and no longer matches the surrounding original paint or gold. Other small scattered losses were never retouched and appear as light spots. Although it would benefit significantly from cleaning, the painting is not in dire need of major treatment at this time.
2012: No apparent change was observed. The cracks in the panel do not appear to have moved and the minor areas of cupping in the paint remain stable.
2013: No apparent change was observed. The cracks in the panel do not appear to have moved and the minor areas of cupping in the paint remain stable. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. The cracks have not progressed any further, and the areas of cupping remain stable. No recent losses were observed. 2015: No apparent change in painting or frame noted at this time. The cracks and areas of cupping noted in previous surveys remain stable. 2016: Minor lifting within old restoration material was noted in the figures in the top proper-right corner, the figures in the bottom proper-right quadrant, and in the large area of restoration at bottom-center during the painting's technical examination. Original ground and paint were observed to be stable. Consolidation was completed before returning the painting to the gallery. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the painting or frame were observed at this time
The white ground is is mostly stable, with only a few minor areas of lifting in the proper upper right figures and proper lower far right figure. There is no danger of imminent loss.
Framed and on the wall in the gallery. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery 2018: Framed in storage with a flashlight
IMA - Allen Whitehill Clowes Special Exhibition Gallery - W203 - nook

The paint is is mostly stable, with only a few minor areas of lifting in the proper upper right figures and proper lower far right figure. There is no danger of imminent loss. There is extensive old retouching that has changed color and no longer matches the surrounding original paint or gold. Other small scattered losses were never retouched and appear as light spots.
The 20th C wooden frame in the style of a 16th century Netherlandish form is in good condition. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate.

The painting should have a full laboratory examination to look at the few areas of lifting paint and ground and to remove the pencil marks. At that time, a proposal for further treatment to correct aesthetic issues may be considered.
oil and gold leaf on wood
The panel appears to be stable and in good plane. Old cracks and splits have not moved.
The verso was not available for inspection but there is no reason to suspect problems with a cradle at this time.
The varnish is dry and matte and does not saturate the colors well. Modern pencil marks are visible in the faces of two figures and can be easily removed.
A small cleaning test with a mild enzymatic solution shows a small amount of surface dirt on top of the varnish that can be easily removed.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, COConnell, Fiona Beckett, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, follower of: Follower of Angelico, Fra | Italian | 1390-1455

Probably Hugo Kilényi [1840-1926], Budapest. {1} Ercole Canessa [1868-1929], New York, Paris and Rome; {2} Alfred F. Seligsberg [1869-1933], New York, by 1934; Sale at (American Art Association, Anderson Galleries, New York) in 1934. {3} Probably purchased from this Sale by (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York); Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1934; {4} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, in 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10001); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} Kilényi is given as a former owner in a letter from Abris Silberman to Allen W. Clowes, dated 25 May 1959. (The famous Kilényi collection at Budapest was dispersed at auction in 1917 and 1927). However in provenance information provided to G.H.A. Clowes on 22 January 1949 by William E. Suida, hired to produce a catalogue of the collection that was never published, Suida recounts that Silberman believed that the painting was previously in Zagreb, in the collection of Count Désan Jankovith. Neither has been confirmed as the previous owner. The very early provenance of this predella panel is uncertain. It has been suggested by some, including in A. Ian Fraser, A Catalogue of the Clowes Collection, 1970, p. 8, that it may have been one of three works seen by Vasari in the Bartolomeo Gondi [died 1577] collection, but there is little evidence for this. {2} Canessa is given as the former owner in the 1934 auction catalogue (see footnote 3). Canessa’s estate was dispersed at auction in 1930 with the assistance of the attorneys Edmond E. Wise and Alfred F. Seligsberg. It is not known if Seligsberg purchased this painting from this auction, or obtained it by other means. {3} American Art Association, Anderson Galleries, New York, Paintings from the estates of the late Henry Walters, William D.N. Perine, Alfred S.(sic) Seligsberg, Charles A. Schieren…, 11-13 January 1934, lot no. 537 as “Attributed to Fra Angelico.” {4} See Bill of Sale from A. Silberman to G.H.A. Clowes, dated 6 October, 1934, in IMA Clowes Archive (C10001).

The painting is structurally sound and in good condition. It has been alleged that the sky is extensively repainted. A full laboratory examination is needed to determine the true state of the picture. 2012: There is no apparent change to the condition of the painting. The old cracks that were previously noted appear to remain stable, 2013: There is no apparent change to the condition of the painting. The old cracks that were previously noted appear to remain stable. 2014: No change to painting, small areas of lifting (gilding and gesso) on frame located at the inner edges and bottom left area. 2015: No changes to painting or frame, areas of lifting in the frame gilding remain unchanged. 2016: No change to the painting. Minor consolidation was done to the minor areas of lifting on the frame using Lascaux medium for consolidation. 2017: No changes to painting or frame. 2018: No changes to the painting or frame at this time
The (assumed) white gesso layers are in stable condition. There are many old vertical cracks that are sound at this time.
On display in CL112. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed

The (assumed) egg tempera and mordant gilding layers are in stable condition. There are many old vertical cracks that are sound at this time. The paint is worn and abraded in some areas and tiny old losses that were never retouched are visible but the painting is in acceptable visual appearance at this time. The extent of old repainting and restoration can only be determined with a full laboratory examination.
2018: an old loss to the ground and paint layer in the lower left corner should be noted.

The current display frame is the gold inner section of what was a larger ornate velvet covered mount. The rest of the frame is in storage. The display frame is in good condition. The gold and gesso layers show extensive age cracks which are stable at this time. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate. 2014: small areas of lifting gilding and gesso along inner edges of frame.
A full laboratory examination is needed to determine the true state of the picture.
tempera and gold leaf on wood
The wood panel is stable and in plane.

The verso was not available for inspection but there is no reason to suspect any problems with a cradle.
2018: Verso examined; cradle is in stable condition

The painting is evenly coated with a semi-gloss varnish that is acceptable in appearance at this time. There are scattered small dull spots, and a small white area is visible at the top of the (red) side of the "door."

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, after: After Holbein, Hans, the younger | German | 1497-1543

Von Stackelberg Family, Schloss Fähna, near Reval (now Talinn), Estonia; {1} Reinhold von Liphart [1864-1940], Schloss Ratshoff (or Ratshof), Tartumaa, Estonia, and by at least 1928 Gräfeling, near Munich, Germany; {2} Emil Paravicini-Engel [1870 - ?], Basel, Switzerland, by 1928 or 1929;{3} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, Vienna, Austria, and New York) by July 1936;{4} George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1937;{5} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10050); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} See Karl Woermann, “Hans Holbeins d. J. Selbstportrait von Schloß Fähna,” Zeitschrift für Bildende Kunst, vol. 10 (1875), pp. 315-318. Woermann erroneously placed Schloss Fähna near Riga, Latvia, which explains all subsequent similar mistakes. The painting is correctly identified as located in Estonia in “Vermischte Nachrichten,” Anzeiger für Kunde der deutschen Vorzeit, vol. 20, 1873, p. 117. {2} The restorer and Holbein scholar Paul Ganz informed Abris Silberman that the painting passed from the von Stackelberg family to R. von Liphart and on to Paravicini, see letter dated 24 July 1936 in IMA, Clowes Archive. By 1925 the von Stackelberg and von Liphart families were related by marriage. {3} See Paul Ganz, “Das Bildnis Hans Holbeins d. J.,” Jahrbuch für Kunst und Kunstpflege in der Schweiz, vol. v (1928-29) part II, pp. 273 - 292 with ill., esp. p. 287. {4} See letter from Ganz to Silberman, dated 24 July 1936, as cited above. {5} Note of agreement of purchase, to be affected in 1937, dated 28 December 1936, in IMA Clowes Archive.

2012: No apparent change observed. 2013: The painting and frame appear to be unchanged. 2014: No apparent changes in painting or frame. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The painting and frame remain unchanged at this time.
The adhesion between the preparatory layers and the wooden support appears stable at this time.
In the gallery, framed and inside a display case. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, in display case. 2017: In gallery, on wall, framed. 2018: In the conservation lab; unframed.
There are gilded dates and inscriptions in the blue background on the front of the painting.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the preparatory layers appears stable at this time. There is a fine crack pattern throughout the paint layer, but the cracks all appear stable at this time. There is old inpainting along the vertical crack on the left side of the panel. This inpainting has slightly discolored and no longer perfectly matches the surrounding original paint in color or opacity.
The frame appears stable at this time.
The wooden panel appears stable at this time. There is an old vertical crack on the left side of the panel that runs the entire height of the painting and a slight overall convex warp to the panel.
The varnish is relatively thick and evenly glossy throughout.

m.mv: This survey should be retitled to reflect the acquisition number (2014.91) Addition of acquisition number has been completed.
Capture One PRO 3.7.7 (3122) [sw: Capture One PRO 3.7.7] [fw: P 45 camera, ROM 1.2, Firmware 2.3.6/1.1.9]
Artist: Holbein, Hans, the younger | German | 1497-1543

Johann Nepomuk Wilczek, known as Count Hans Wilczek [1837-1922], Schloss Kreuzenstein, near Vienna, Austria; {1} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York); George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, in 1934; {2} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10049); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1}See letter from the art historian William Suida to G.H.A. Clowes, dated 22 January 1949 in IMA Clowes Archive. The Silberman brothers were known to have purchased many items from the private museum of Count Wilczek at Schloss Kreuzenstein; see An Exhibition of Paintings, E. and A. Silberman Galleries for the benefit of the Research Fund of Art and Archaeology, The Spanish Institute, New York, 1955, p. 7 (introduction by Daniel Catton Rich). All Wilczek records were lost during WWII, according to correspondence with a Wilczek heir in May 2014. {2}See purchase agreement, dated 2 December 1934, in IMA Clowes Archive.
The drawing is executed in an aqueous medium on laid & chain paper which is adhered flat to a thick wooden panel (about 7/16" depth). The panel is held inside the frame with two brass plates.
Drawing should not be considered for display until a thorough examination is conducted and any necessary treatment performed.

The paper appears to be stable. There are some areas of lifting paint that need to be investigated. 2018: Lifting is seen in the blue background paint (along the proper right shoulder of the sitter) and in the brown garment color in the same vicinity. Other small outbreaks within the blue background are likely but have not been systematically recorded at this time.
2012: The drawing has remained framed in storage since the 2011 condition survey. It has not yet received conservation attention, but if it is called forth for study, display, or loan, a consolidation treatment will be necessary and the work will be scheduled.
2013: There has been no change in the condition of the drawing, The paint insecurity is found in the blue background, and it is possible that some areas may be restoration overpainting. A full investigation into the paint insecurity and materials identification for this artwork will require a partnership between conservator and curator, and can be expected to be a large undertaking.
2014: The insecurity in the blue background paint is worrisome. There has been one small flake loss in the blue adjacent to t he proper right side of the figure. This painting has been identified as a candidate for an exhibition in 2016, so it will be taken to conservation for focused attention in the next year. (NOTE: it is possible that the insecure paint is restoration work, added by a past restorer)
2015: The work has received materials analysis attention, but there has been no effort to date to consolidate the lifting paint. It cannot be safely displayed in its current condition, and should not be handled unless absolutely necessary. The coming year may see the start of discussion for scheduling treatment.
2016: There has been no change in overall condition. No exhibition materialized for the work, so conservation treatment was never scheduled. It is suspected that the work has been restored, possibly extensively.
2017: The artwork has remained in storage for the year. The paint cleavage, found in the blue paint along the cape over the proper right shoulder and in the background of the upper right quadrant, does not appear to have worsened. This blue paint is strongly suspected to be added by a restorer to cover damage/loss in the original paint. A full examination is required. NOTE: This may have been accomplished by the Clowes conservator 2016-2017. Full treatment has not been enacted.

IMA Art Storage. The drawing was examined within the frame. 2013: IMA Art Storage. The drawing was examined framed, flat on a ca:rt. 2014: Painting now resides in F25, Prints, Drawings, & Photographs Storage. Examination was conducted in this space. 2015: Print Study 2016: Print Study 2017: Print Study 2018: Paper Laboratory

The drawing resides in the original Clowes Collection frame. The frame is wood with a red-glazed silver leaf finish. A metal inscription plate gives the following information: "Portrait of an Unknown Lady, CA 1538 / sometimes called Frau Holbein / Hans Holbein the Younger / German 1497-8 - 1543 / The Clowes Fund Collection." Several paper labels on the verso of the frame identify the work as the property of the Clowes Fund and identify the sitter as Elsbeth Holbein. Within the drawing, there is a single initial "H" painted in the lower right corner with black paint.

The drawing is executed in presumed aqueous-based colors with some black chalk touches to delineate features and soft shadows. There appears to be some insecurity in the blue background paint along the line of the figure's cape on the proper right side (likely restoration paint). There is also a small amount of flake loss in a spot in the figure's forehead, beneath the veil, but this area could also be restoration. 2018: Paint cleavage in the brown cape adjacent to the blue background has also been noted.

The drawing is stored permanently framed and hangs on a paintings rack in IMA Art Storage. The frame is sound and gives the drawing (adhered to a wooden panel) adequate support. The glazing in the frame does not appear to be touching the surface of the drawing. There is a security plate affixed to the verso of the frame.
As of 2014, the drawing has been permanently relocated to a bin slot in Print, Drawing & Photograph storage (F25).
2018: The wooden panel support is held in place within the frame by the pressure provided by two brass mending plates placed at the top and bottom edges of the frame opening. There is significant air space between the painting panel and the left and right edges of the frame. The frame opening could be resized to give the painting a safer and more comfortable fit.

The drawing should be unframed and examined in the next year to determine the nature and extent of the insecure paint in the blue background color and to enact consolidation where needed.
HANDLING NOTE: The art-bearing wooden panel is held in the frame with two mending plates at the top and bottom edges of the artwork. The panel is free to shift from left to right within the frame. Great caution is recommended when handling
2018: The painting was brought to the attention of Roxy Sperber as a candidate for treatment
5 f of light maximum. The drawing was on display for years in the Clowes Library of the IMA. A prolonged storage period for the artwork is considered beneficial.
Currently in bin storage, F25. Although the work is vertically oriented (with a slight backward slant), this is safer than sliding rack storage which would initiate vibration in movement.
chalk and watercolor on tinted paper
The drawing is executed on a laid & chain paper. The paper may have been toned a rosy-beige color before the drawing was created. The paper appears to be in stable condition.
The secondary support is a wooden board in four sections, which appears stable in a flat conformation. The adhesive used to join the board and the paper is unknown.
None are immediately apparent. UV examination was not conducted.
No travel is possible at this time (2015) No travel is possible at this time (2016) No travel is possible before a complete treatment can take place. (2018)
Work on the frame, adjusting it to better fit the panel.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, circle of: Circle of Fouquet, Jean | French | 1420-1481

Probably New York art market by 1946.{1} George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, by at least 1959;{2} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10040); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.
{1} Based on expertise of this painting made by Klaus G. Perls, Walter Friedländer, and Joseph Pijoan, all made in New York and dated in the period 1946 to 1948, the painting was likely in New York by 1946; see IMA Clowes archives (C10040). A new cradle obscures any identification, exhibition or other revealing marks once possibly present on the back of the panel or frame. {2} The painting was included in the exhibition Paintings from the Collection of George Henry Alexander Clowes: A Memorial Exhibition, John Herron Art Museum, Indianapolis, Indiana (now the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields) 3 October to 1 November 1959, cat. no. 25 (ill.).

The painting is in acceptable visual condition and is structurally sound for display. Old horizontal cracks that run through the face are stable. The paint has been greatly rubbed by past restorations and extensive repainting is assumed.
2012: The painting remains stable. The previous cracks and old damages that were noted do not exhibit any change.
2013: The painting remains stable. The previous cracks and old damages that were noted do not exhibit any change. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. (See complete technical analysis for more information). 2015: No change in condition of painting or frame. 2016: No change noted in the condition of either the painting or the frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the frame and painting at this time
The (assumed) white ground appears to be stable at this time. 2014: Off-white ground, thinly applied.

On display in CL110 (framed) 2014: in gallery, framed, on wall. The painting underwent an in-depth technical analysis in May 2014 where it was unframed, and examined in the conservation studio. 2015, 2016: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed

The oil paint layers have been heavily rubbed by past restorations and extensive repainting is assumed. The dark cloak and the background appear to have suffered more than the face but this has not yet been confirmed by lab examination and analysis. Old horizontal cracks that run through the face are stable. A small loss is visible at the extreme outer proper right edger due to rubbing from the frame.

The imitation French Gothic frame is in good and sound condition. The frame was extensively distressed to make it appear older than it actually is. A small damage is visible at the extreme proper bottom right outer corner. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate.
2013: The frame was replaced with a more historically accurate version designed and fabricated by Timothy Newberry. The losses and cracks are artificial distress marks to simulate age put there by Newberry.
No intervention is needed at this time. A full technical study would help in understanding the fragmentary nature of the picture.

The verso was not available for inspection but the wood panel appears to be structurally stable at this time. Old horizontal cracks that run through the face are stable. The panel was supposedly cut from a much larger composition and has been modified into its current appearance. This has not yet been confirmed by lab examination and analysis. 2014: the edges of the panel exhibit losses in ground layer, consistent with the theory that the panel was cut from a larger painting.

The verso was not available for inspection but the painting appears to be structurally stable at this time. 2014: The painting is cradled. The cradle members are all seized. Edge strips are present along all four sides of the panel.

The painting is heavily varnished with a natural resin coating that is moderately yellowed. There are some minor dull and cloudy spots that are not immediately apparent under gallery lighting. The painting's appearance is visually acceptable for display at this time.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, after: After Hals, Frans | Dutch | about 1581-1666

August Christoph von Wackerbarth [1662-1734]; {1} Königliche Gemäldegalerie, Dresden, Germany, until 1860. {2} Possibly in the collection of wealthy ship owner from Nantes, Fernand Crouan [1845-1905]; by descent to Mr. de Lagotellerie. {3} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York, New York); {4} Acquired by Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes of Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1934; Clowes Fund Collection, 1958-present (C10047);on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of The Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10047); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2015.
{1} Wackerbarth gave his art collection to the king of Saxony, Friedrich August I, of the House of Wettin, in 1710-11, and also served as an agent for the king’s art purchases as well. For more on Wackerbarth see Carl Niedner, “Der sächsische Kabinettsminister Graf August Christoph von Wackerbarth (Ϯ 1734) und die Königliche Gemäldegalerie in Dresden,” Neues Archiv für sächsische Geschichte und Altertumskunde, 31 (1910): 86-99, esp. p. 90, 94-95 {2} The IMA’s painting was listed in the 1722 inventory of the Dresden Gemäldegalerie as no. 147. (The number 147 appears in paint on the front of the painting at bottom right.) Scholars such as Valentiner have confused it with another version of the Hals portrait also owned by the Dresden Gallery; this version is listed as no. 191 in the same inventory. See SKD Archiv, Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister, Direktion, Inv. 1722-1728, Lit. A. From 1859-1861 a series of auctions took place to reduce the holdings of the Dresden Gemäldegalerie, and the IMA painting was sold at auction on 16 April 1860 by Carl Gotthelf Bautzmann, Dresden, as lot no. 89; see the annotated catalogue Verzeichniss der aus den Vorräthen der Kgl. Gemälde-Galerie zu Dresden … zu versteigernden Oel- und Pastell-Gemälde, at the Staatliche Kunstsammlungen Dresden (SKD Archiv, 01/GG Akte Nr. 6 Bd 1) which links lot no. 89 of the auction catalogue with the no. 530. The IMA painting indeed appears on an inventory list of paintings slated for auction as no. 530; this number appears on a paper tag on the back of the IMA painting. For this inventory, see SKD Archiv, Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister, Direktion, Die im Vorrath befindlichen Bilder und deren Verwendung betreffend, Nr. 530. {3} Hofstede de Groot reported that he examined the painting in Paris, France, at the home of Mr. de Lagotellerie. De Lagotellerie inherited the business and presumably the painting collection of his father-in-law in 1905. The company liquidated in 1906, whereupon De Lagotellerie moved to Paris. Note written by Hofstede de Groot in March 1912, RKD files. {4} The painting was never, as Slive suggests, in the possession of H. Klaus of Minneapolis but was acquired directly from Silbermann Galleries by Clowes. The mistake can be attributed to an announcement made on 26 January 1935 by the Illustrated London News, declaring the new owner of the self-portrait to be Dr. H. Klaus of Minneapolis, Minnesota. A letter written to the newspaper by Charles H. Dorr of E. and A. Silbermann points out the mistake. Clowes Collection Archives, Indianapolis Museum of Art (C10047). See also the same error in “Long hidden work by Hals is found”, New York Times, 9 January 1935.

2012: The conservation of this painting is almost complete with installation planned for early April, 2013. 2013: Conservation completed (April 2013 )and the painting has been reinstalled in the gallery. The current image of the painting should be updated with a new one as the conservation treatment has significantly altered the appearance of the painting. The painting and frame are structurally stable. 2014: Framed painting has been reinstalled in the Dutch Gallery. The painting and frame remain structurally stable. Current image of painting ( for this survey ) should be updated with the "after" treatment image showing the painting after full conservation treatment. 2015: Painting is currently unframed and on display in the exhibit: "CSI: What Lies Beneath". The frame is in conservation (S50) . BOTH painting and frame remain stable with no changes noted. 2016: Both painting and frame are temporarily in the conservation lab for a full technical examination report. No structural changes to either the painting or frame. 2017: No changes to painting ( unframed and on display ) and frame ( in the conservation lab). 2018: No change to the painting; small scratch noted on the frame

The oak panel support has been primed with a white ground layer. The ground layer appears to be generally well adhered to the oak panel support and is stable at this time. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees the portrait is marked with overall age and mechanical craquelure as well as very minute losses. These areas are all stable at this time. Many of the minute losses were retouched during a previous restoration attempt. At present, given the on-going conservation treatment, some of the retouch has been removed.

IMA Conservation Paintings lab. The painting is currently undergoing conservation treatment. 2015: On display in the gallery, unframed. (Special exhibit, "CSI: What Lies Beneath") 2016: Painting temporarily in the conservation lab for completion of a full technical examination report. Painting will be on display again in June 2016, unframed for the special exhibit, "CSI: The Flip Side." 2017: Painting still unframed and now in the Conant Gallery for an extended special exhibit: "CSI: The Flip Side" 2018: In conservation lab; unframed

The oil paints appear to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layer and is stable at this time. During a previous restoration attempt final touches (dark accents in the sitter's face, hair, hat and cloak have been abraded. Heavy retouch was applied to damaged areas in the sitter's black hat and cloak during that restoration attempt. At present, given the ongoing conservation treatment, some of the retouch in the hat and cloak has been removed. In the latter instance, three buttons were re-exposed once the black retouch paint was removed. The remains of these buttons appear to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layer and are stable at this time.
The frame appears to be stable at this time. 2018: A small scratch on the left side of the frame was noted
Detailed reports, both scientific and treatment-based, will be provided on the completion of the conservation of this portrait.
The painting is executed on a single piece of quarter-sawn oak. The oak panel support is generally in plane and stable at this time.

The painting has at least two or more varnish coatings, the uppermost of which is glossy in appearance. At present, given the ongoing conservation treatment, some of these varnish coatings (which are very yellow and disfiguring to the original colors used in the portrait), have been removed.
Upon completion of the conservation treatment a full treatment report, outlining the materials and procedures used, will be written.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)

By descent within the family of Mrs. Thomas Watkinson Payler (née Charlotte Hammond) [1747-1810] to Egerton Hammond, Non[n]ington, Kent, England, until about 1931. {1} Probably purchased from Egerton Hammond by (Robert C. Vose Galleries, Boston, Massachusetts); {2} Purchased by George Henry Alexander Clowes of Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1935; {3} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana; On long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10065); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2015.
{1} See copy of certificate, signed by W. Roberts, London, England, and dated 26 November 1931, in IMA Conservation File. Beneath the spandrel of the frame on the rectangular canvas at bottom left in red paint: “Mrs. Payler./Sir Josh. Reynolds.” Pendant portraits of Mr. and Mrs. Payler were painted a few months after their marriage in January 1771; see Algernon Graves and William Vine Cronin, A History of the Works of Sir Joshua Reynolds P.R.A., vol. 2, 1899, p. 735. {2} On the remnants of a label one can read “Lent Robert C. Vose Galleries/168.1930.” {3} The painting was shown at the exhibition American and European Painting from Vose Galleries at the John Herron Art Institute, now the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields, in 1935; see Archives of American Art, Vose Galleries, Box 8, Folder 4 (JHAI). These records at the Archives of American Art also include an exhibition checklist with prices, as well as a letter from JHAI to Robert C. Vose indicating that a commission was paid to JHAI when Dr. Clowes purchased the painting out of this exhibition.

The adhesion between the oil and tempera paints and the ground layer appears generally stable at this time. There is marked old abrasion to the paint, especially in the flesh-tones of the figures. There was likely substantial loss to the paint that was associated with the damages and splits in the wooden support. At this time, any old damages are covered by old fills and inpainting and it is difficult to discern the extent of that previous damage.
There are numerous old mechanical cracks throughout the composition. Several appear as a fine network associated with regular movement of the wood grain. Additionally, there are areas where there are larger, more prominent cracks that are associated with old cracks in the wooden support. At this time, the cracks appears to be stable.
There are several old areas of inpainting throughout the composition. These old areas of inpainting are discolored and no longer match the surrounding original paint. There are several losses around the perimeter, where the painting was in contact with the frame.

The frame appears stable at this time and adequately houses the painting.
The hanging hardware consisting of screw eyes, screws, and copper wire should be replaced with D-rings. 2014: Frame has some small old losses, old cracks, areas of old restoration that are loose. Consolidation of these areas should be done.

The hanging hardware consisting of screw eyes, screws, and copper wire should be replaced with D-rings.
Although the painting would greatly benefit from treatment, including the removal of the discolored layers of varnish and inpainting, a substantial amount of time would be necessary to fully evaluate the extent of damage obscured under the old restorations before any treatment could be attempted. Any treatment would also take a substantial amount of time to complete (possibly 1-3 years). 2015: Frame was consolidated with Lascaux Medium for Consolidation.

The wooden panel appears generally stable at this time. There is an old cradle system affixed to the back of the panel. There are several old damages, and cracks in the panel that run slightly diagonal down from the top right of the round panel. These old damages appear to have been stabilized and are covered by old fills and inpainting.

There is an old, thick, and discolored varnish on the surface of the painting. There are likely several layers of varnish with dirt trapped between. The varnish is relatively even in gloss, but appears hazy and no longer saturates the colors of the painting.

Artist, follower of: Follower of Rembrandt van Rijn | Dutch | 1606-1669

Féréol Bonnemaison [died 1827], Paris, France; Sale at (M. Henry, Paris) in 1827. {1} V. H. Crosby, London, England; By descent to Mrs. H. Hallahan, London, probably until 1904.{2} Baron Leopold Hirsch [1867-1932], London, by 1909;{3} Sale at (Christie’s, London) in 1934;{4} (John Nicholson, London), in 1934.{5} (Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries, New York, New York), in 1934; Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1934.{6} Private English collection, from about 1944, possibly via Ivan N. Podgoursky.{7} (Newhouse Galleries, New York), by 1955; Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1955;{8} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, 1958-present; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of The Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10062); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2016.
{1} M. Henry, Paris, Catalogue de Tableaux Précieux des diverses ecoles et autres objets de curiosité…formant le cabinet de feu M. le Chevalier Féréol Bonnemaison, 20 April 1827, lot no. 71. The descriptive entry of this lot cut from the auction catalog is attached to the back of the painting. {2} According to the Museum of Fine Arts Boston’s website, for a painting by Benjamin West (06.2362), the Hallahan estate sale took place on 14 April 1904 in London at Knight, Frank & Rutley “being part of the collection formed by the late V.H. Crosby.” [Catalogue at National Art Library, London, still to be consulted, to confirm this painting’s inclusion in this sale.] {3} The painting, loaned by Hirsch, was included in the exhibition publication, A Catalogue of the Pictures and Drawings in the National Loan Exhibition in aid of National Gallery Funds held in the Grafton Galleries, London, 1909-10, no. 41. {4} Christie’s, London, Catalogue of the Collection of Important Pictures by Old Masters, British Portraits, Engravings and Drawings: The property of Leopold Hirsch, Esq., deceased, 11 May 1934, cat. no. 126 (ill.). {5} Although an annotated copy of the above cited auction catalogue available at the Frick Art Reference Library (FARL) indicates that the painting was sold to “G. Nicholson.” However, an article “Highest Prices in Hirsch Dispersals,” The Art News, p.17, listing auction results, indicates that lot no. 126 went to the English dealer, John Nicholson. {6} For the invoice dated 31 May 1934, signed by B.M. [Bertram] Newhouse and Dr. Clowes, see IMA Clowes Archive, Rembrandt file. {7} The particular private English collection is not identified by Newhouse Galleries at the time of its sale to Dr. Clowes for a second time. In correspondence with Podgoursky in spring 1944, “the little Rembrandt panel” was one of several paintings Dr. Clowes agreed to sell, see Clowes Archive, Podgoursky correspondence. Dr. Clowes sometime sought to upgrade his collection by exchange or by trade, or when seeking funds to purchase another painting. {8} The painting is included in the exhibition and catalogue, Paintings from the Collection of George Henry Alexander Clowes: A Memorial Exhibition, John Herron Art Museum, Indianapolis, 1959, ca. no. 46 (ill.).

Giuseppe Toscanelli [1828-1891], Florence, Italy, until 1883. {1} Probably (Armand Georges Lowengard [died 1943]), Paris, France. {2} (Boehler and Steinmeyer, Lucerne, Switerland), possibly in 1922. {3} Julius H. Haass [died 1931], Detroit, Michigan, and by descent to his wife Mrs. Lillian Henkel Haass [1879-1960], Detroit; (Newhouse Galleries, New York, New York); Sold to Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, in May 1958; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, 1958--present; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10075); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2016.
{1} Sold at Jules Sambon, Florence, 9-13 April 1883, Catalogue de la Collection Toscanelli de Florence, Tableaux , Meubles et Objets d’art, lot no. 85, as Andrea del Sarto, and illustrated in the accompanying Collection Toscanelli: Album contenant la reproduction des Tableaux et Meubles anciens, plate XIX. {2} In notes provided to Dr. Clowes by Newhouse Galleries, the “Lowengard Collection, Paris” is identified as a former owner. No other Lowengard is known other than Armand Georges Lowengard, who was Joseph Duveen’s nephew and, like his uncle, involved in the art trade. See IMA Clowes Archive, Foschi file. {3} Boehler and Steinmeyer was founded in Lucerne in 1919, and existed into the early 1930s.

Major and Mrs. Bono, Venice, Italy; {1} (Arturo Grassi, Florence, Italy, and New York, New York); {2} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, about 1937; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, 1958--present; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10074); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2016.
{1} On several occasions Dr. Clowes relayed the provenance of this painting to others as: “found…in the attic of an Italian naval officer in Venice, whose wife was a direct descendant of the old man [depicted].” {2} See letter from Arturo Grass to Dr. Clowes, dated 9 April 1950, noting that he was uncertain whether the painting had been published anywhere since its acquisition by Dr. Clowes from Grassi years earlier.

The painting is quite worn and abraded. Its current acceptable appearance is due to extensive restoration by William Suhr. Suhr's varnish is quite yellowed. A more recent glossy varnish was applied on top of the yellowed coating to impart greater depth and saturation to the colors. The painting is structurally stable at this time. A small cleaning test is visible in the sitter's proper left elbow. There is a small white spot in the brown shoulder garment.

This appears to be an old loss that was previously retouched but is now visible. This may relate to the pinpoint losses noted in the "media" section of the report. The condition of the painting and frame are otherwise unchanged.

The painting was executed with a number of oil (and added resin?) rich glazes which made it prone to easy damage from early cleaning methods. Laboratory examination is needed to determine the true state of the original paint layer. Despite the extensive restorations, there remain many small old pinpoint losses below the varnish that were never filled nor retouched.
2012: There is a small, previous loss in the lower right on the sitter's proper left elbow that is approximately 3mm x 4mm. This damage is not new, but should be noted. 2013: No apparent change noted at this time. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. Old areas of abrasion are visible, particularly in the note in the sitter's hand where the writing is illegible.

The Venetian Renaissance (style?) frame is in generally good condition. There are areas of deep cracking in the gesso/polychrome/gold carvings, notably along the bottom and the proper upper left corner. There are some losses visible in that corner but the surrounding areas seem to be stable at this time. There are a number of old, inactive insect escape holes. The verso was not available for inspection. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate.

Laboratory examination is needed to determine the color and composition of the ground layer(s) and to determine the true state of the original paint layer. 2014: The ground is a white calcium carbonate ground, with a grey imprimatura layer. The original paint layer has suffered damages in the past, and is covered in significant retouching, particularly the background and in the lower half of the painting.

The canvas appears to be in good condition. It is taut and in good plane. 2014: The verso of the lining canvas bears a stain resembling the shape of the sitter on the front. This may be due to the application of a previous varnish (a coloured varnish could account for the reddish and greenish tints) that saturated through to the underlying lining canvas.

It is assumed that the painting is glue lined. The lining appears to be well attached and in good plane at this time. The verso was not available for inspection to look at the condition of the stretcher.
The present upper layer of varnish remains clear and glossy, saturating the colors well. The older lower layer has discolored to a medium yellow tone. Cleaning is not recommended at this time.

{1} After her husband’s death in 1958, Edith Whitehill Clowes continued collecting. The sale by Schaeffer Galleries has not been verified.

2012: Painting and frame appear to be in stable condition with no apparent change noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2014: No change in painting or frame. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016:No change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the frame and painting appear unchanged at this time

There appears to be a toned or red-colored ground that is slightly visible through areas where the paint is thinly applied. There appears to have been marked old loss to the ground and paint layers. The adhesion between the ground and support appears stable at this time.
On the wall, in the gallery, and framed. 2014: in gallery, on wall, framed. 2015, 2016: in gallery, on wall, framed. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery. 2018: Framed in storage with a flashlight
IMA - Allen Whitehill Clowes Special Exhibition Gallery - W203 - nook
There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting.

The oil paint appears to be well adhered to the preparatory layers at this time. There are extensive old damages to the ground and paint layers, that appear to be stable at this time. There are marked abrasion and cracks throughout the painting layers, which also appear to be stable at this time.
There is extensive inpainting and retouching throughout the composition. These areas no longer match the surrounding original paint in color or opacity.

The frame appears stable at this time. There are numerous old damages and minor losses to the gesso and gilding. These areas currently appear stable. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface of the frame.
The original fabric support is lined (likely to a second fabric support). Overall, the support appears stable and in plane at this time.

Overall, the varnish appears somewhat glossy. There are several areas throughout the surface where the varnish appears slightly matte and dull and other areas where the gloss is even higher than the surrounding surface. Most of the variation in the surface appears to relate to areas of retouching.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Roxane Sperber (2018)

(Demotte, Paris, France, and New York, New York). {1} Count Ivan Podgoursky [1901-1962], by 1943; {2} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1946; The Clowes Fund Collection, 1958-present; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Courtesy of the Clowes Fund, since 1971 (C10043); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2016.
{1} A glass plate negative of this painting exists in the Demotte gallery photographic materials today housed at the Louvre (currently being digitized); see correspondence between IMA and Musée du Louvre archive staff, spring 2014 and September 2016. Georges-Joseph Demotte [1877-1923] and his son, Lucien Demotte [1906-1934] ran the Demotte gallery, which specialized in Islamic art and medieval sculpture, in the early 1900s, but sometimes dealt in European paintings. In correspondence from Podgoursky to Dr. Clowes, dated 25 February 1946, he says this painting “comes from the famous Demotte collection of Goyas.” {2} Count Ivan N. Podgoursky sold several paintings to G.H.A. Clowes in the late 1930s and 1940s. He may for a time have worked for Demotte and used Demotte’s New York address as his shipping address.

2012: No apparent change to the painting or frame. IN PROGRESS: The frame is currently being conserved by a frame specialist. The painting is currently in conservation for digital imaging, technical examination and conservation assessment as well as for conservation treatment. ( The latter will begin once the technical examination and conservation assessment have been completed.) 2013: Treatment is in progress on the painting. 2014: Treatment and scientific analysis still in progress on the painting. The frame has been conserved. 2015: Scientific analysis still in progress. Dirt//varnish removed from front of painting. Frame is in conservation lab (S50). 2016: No additional changes to painting or frame. 2017: No changes to painting or frame. 2018: No changes to painting or frame are noted at this time

From viewing localized areas of thinly applied oil paint as well as localized areas of loss along the bottom edge of the painting (mostly covered by the rabbet of the frame), the wood panel support appears to have been initially primed with a white ground layer on top of which a warm red-brown imprimatura appears to have been applied. Affecting these preparatory layers as well as the paint layer in varying degrees the painting is marked with overall age and mechanical craquelure. The age craquelure appears to be stable. Areas of mechanical craquelure, coinciding with horizontal seams in the wood panel support, at one time exhibited localized passages of loss which have since been filled and retouched during a previous restoration attempt. This is most evident along the lower horizontal seam in the painting. Additional areas of localized old losses in the ground/paint layers are evident in the lower left edge and left bottom corner of the composition. Presently stable, these areas appear to have been locally retouched during a previous restoration.

In art storage, framed and on a painting rack. 2014: The painting has been in the Conservation Lab and Conservation Science lab for full treatment and extensive analysis. 2015: Unframed in the conservation science lab. Extensive analysis still in progress. 2016: Unframed in the IMA Conservation Science Lab. 2017: Unframed in the IMA Conservation Science Lab. 2018: Unframed in the IMA Conservation Science Lab.

For the most part the oil paint layer had been thickly applied with localized areas where the back of the brush was used to "scrape" away some areas of paint as a means of further delineating figures and/or background. At present the paint layer appears to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers. Localized areas of traction crackle are evident in the paint layer. These areas have been present in the painting for a very long time and appear to be stable. Some areas of paint abrasion are present as a result of a previous cleaning attempt. In some instances these areas were not retouched during that time. Where retouching is present it should be noted that it only moderately matches the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding areas of original paint.
The frame is marked with areas of minute flaking and loss in the gesso/finishing layers.
Because the painting is not currently on display, no treatment is necessary at this time. In the future, conservation should be considered in conjunction with further curatorial research and input.
Oriented horizontally, the wood panel support is comprised of more than one member. It appears to be generally in plane and stable at this time.

The painting has been very heavily coated with a varnish that has an overall satin/glossy sheen. This thick varnish layer greatly obscures the textural quality of the paint layers as applied by the artist. Small cleaning tests on the surface of the painting indicate that there is an accumulation of dirt on the surface.
A mild enzymatic solution was used to test for the accumulation of dirt on the surface of the varnish layer.
El Juego de Barras (The Game of Bars)

Baron Max von Heyl [1844-1925], Darmstadt, Germany, by 1925; Sale at (Hugo Helbing, Munich, Germany) in 1930. {1} (V.B. Galleries, Inc.); {2} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958], Indianapolis, Indiana, by 1958?; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2016.
{1} Hugo Helbing, Munich, Katalog der Sammlung Baron Heyl, Darmstadt (Band 1): Sammlung von Antiquitäten, Gemälden alter und neuer Meister, Skulpturen, Textilien, Wandteppichen und Orientteppichen, alten Möbeln und Einrichtungsgegenständen aus dem Nachlass des verewigten Freiherrn Max von Heyl, Generalleutnant à. l. s. und seiner Gemahlin Doris, geb. Stein, Darmstadt, Munich, 28 and 29 October 1930, cat. no. 256, plate 33. {2} IMA, Clowes Archive, contains a dealer’s binder whose authorship is identified as “V.B. Galleries, Inc.” This gallery can now be identified as "The Galleries of Paul S. Van Baarn, Ltd." specializing in antique tapestries, paintings, furniture and works of art; see "Front Matter," Burlington Magazine (March 1938): vi.
A wool and silk tapestry woven scene depicting Raphael's "Miraculous Draught of Fishes".

December 2018 - No change in condition. The tapestry was examined December 3-11, 2018 for treatment recommendations. This follow-up was recommended by the conservator who examined the tapestry in 2017. The current review supported the recommendation that slit repair should be undertaken as well as wet cleaning; both of these recommendations align with general tapestry maintenance and do not indicate unusual damage. These are general recommendations suggested by two outside consultants.
2011 Location: Clowes Courtyard2012 - 2015 Location: Art storage (Tr1 lv2)2016 Location: Toby stage2018 Location: W308 Textile Gallery
The tapestry is supported and prepared for hanging according to current conservation standards.
December 2016 - the tapestry is in need of slit repair
The treatment will stabilize the tapestry for exhibition.
No treatment necessary beyond periodic preventive maintenance when the tapestry is on display.

m.mv: Laura Kubick, Richard McCoy, Sue Dupuis, David Miller, Morgan Nau
Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10100A-B); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2017.
The objects are a pair of stone rampant lions, each holding a shield. Lion A has its proper left (PL) front leg on the shield and Lion B has its proper right (PR) front leg on the shield.

The lions are structurally stable. There are some old, but stable repairs present on both. Lion A has a repair at its tail and a large patch that spans from its PR torso to its PR back thigh. Lion B has a repair where its tail is attached to its body, on its PL front paw and across the shield. 2012: There is also a loss on the top PR corner of lion B's shield. This is not a new issue, but was not noted before. Old images exist that document this loss. 2015: There are areas of repair/ fills on Lion B on the PL side along the forearm extending up into the PL side of the mane, another large area on the PL leg, and PL top edge and side of base. These are old repairs, however they are hard to see in gallery lighting and were observed this time with additional illumination. There is a rectangular shaped loss on Lion B's shield, at the top of the sigil. Old images exist that document this loss.
Both lions have darkened areas throughout as well as water trail marks. The surfaces of the stone are abraded and weathered overall. These aesthetic condition problems are the result of the sculptures having resided outside previously.
2012: No condition change is apparent, but a note about an existing condition issue was added to the first paragraph above. 2013: No change is apparent. 2014: No change is apparent. 2015: No condition change is apparent, but notes about existing condition issues were added to the first paragraph above. 2016: No change is apparent. 2017: No change is apparent. 2018: No change is apparent prior to enclosing in protective boxes during Clowes Pavilion renovations.
In Medieval Renaissance gallery- CL109 2018-12-27: could not be examined as are enclosed in protective boxes in-situ during Clowes Pavilion renovations.
A) lion: 20 x 11 x 10 in. (sight) B) lion: 20 x 11 x 10 in. (sight)
pair of lions supporting heraldic shields
