The areas of previously cupped and cracked ground and paint should be monitored for any new insecurities, especially if the painting should travel.

2012: Painting and frame appear to be generally stable with no apparent changes at this time. 2013: No change to painting or frame noted. 2014: Painting and frame remain stable with no apparent changes. 2015: Both painting and frame appear to be stable with no changes. 2016: No changes to note on either the painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: Condition of the painting and frame are unchanged

There is a light colored ground layer that is visible through areas of abrasion and cracks in the paint layer. The adhesion between the ground and fabric support appears stable at this time.
There appears to have been previous issues with the stability of the ground and paint layers. There are old marked mechanical cracks and areas of cupping throughout that appear to have been stabilized during the previous lining, but several of the areas were not realigned in plane leaving the surface of the ground and paint a little uneven.
Framed and hanging on the storage racks in IMA Art Storage. -2018 in storage on a ladder with a flashlight; framed
There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting.

The adhesion between the ground and paint layers appears to be stable at this time.
There appears to have been previous issues with the stability of the ground and paint layers. There are old marked mechanical cracks and areas of cupping throughout that appear to have been stabilized during the previous lining, but several of the areas were not realigned in plane leaving the surface of the ground and paint a little uneven.
Additionally, there is marked previous abrasion throughout the paint layers, especially along the cracks where the cupped texture made these areas more vulnerable to abrasion. The cracks and abrasion are most noticeable in the sitter's flesh due to the contrast between the light color of the paint and the dark appearance of the lines from the cracks.
There are several small old losses in the paint. These old areas of damage appear stable at this time and have been visually compensated.
There is a substantial amount of old inpainting throughout the composition. The inpainting has discolored over time and no longer matches the surrounding original paint in color or opacity.

The frame appears to be stable and adequately supports the painting at this time. There is general wear and marked abrasion throughout. There are numerous old damages and cracks, most of which appear to have been stabilized.
The areas of previously cupped and cracked ground and paint should be monitored for any new insecurities, especially if the painting should travel.

The fabric support support appears generally stable and is taut and in plane. The original support has been previously lined to a second fabric support. The adhesion between the original support and the lining appears stable at this time. There are old stretcher bar creases in the support, which appear to have been reduced during the lining.
The surface coating is discolored and the surface gloss is relatively uneven. There are several areas that appear relatively matte, which is mainly associated with areas of old inpainting.

2012: No apparent change noted to either the painting or frame at this time. 2013: The painting and frame appear to be stable with no apparent change at this time. 2014: No apparent change to painting, frame has an area of minor lifting in the gesso layer that will eventually need consolidation. 2015: No change in painting or frame. 2016: No change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the frame or painting at this time

Silberman Galleries, New York, New York);{2} George Henry Alexander Clowes (1877-1958), Indianapolis, Indiana, by 1937; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10038); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2017.
{1} A version of the Cromwell portrait was included in the sale at Robinson, Fisher and Harding, London, England, A Catalogue of the Collection of Family Portraits of the Penruddocke Family…removed from Compton Park, Salisbury and sold by Direction of Captain G.W. Penruddocke, 13 November 1930, lot 23. {2} The Silberman brothers were known to have purchased many items from the private museum of Count Wilczek at Schloss Kreuzenstein; see An Exhibition of Paintings, E. and A. Silberman Galleries for the benefit of the Research Fund of Art and Archaeology, The Spanish Institute, New York, 1955: 7 (introduction by Daniel Catton Rich). All Wilczek records were lost during World War II, according to correspondence with a Wilczek heir in May 2014.

2012: The frame and painting appear to be generally stable with no apparent change noted at this time. 2013: Painting and frame remain the same with no apparent change. 2014: No changes noted to painting or frame at this time. 2015: Painting and frame remain stable with no apparent changes at this time. 2016: No additional changes to painting or frame at this time. 2017: No additional changes to painting or frame at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the painting or frame at this time.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. There are some areas of previous abrasion to the thinly painted areas, including the shadows of the flesh tones and the sitter's features and hair.
There are old areas of inpainting throughout, especially along the joins in the panel. These areas have become discolored over time and no longer match the surrounding original paint.
The frame appears stable and adequately houses the painting.

The wooden panel appears generally stable and in plane. The verso of the panel has a cradle system attached. There are two vertical joins that run almost the entire height of the painting and two horizontal joins along the top and bottom. There appears to have been some previous instability associated with these joins as there is old inpainting present in these areas.

The surface coating is relatively thick and generally uneven in gloss. It appears somewhat discolored and slightly hazy. There is a diagonal scratch in the varnish that measures approximately 2 inches, located in the bottom right corner. The scratch appears to be confined to the varnish, but further testing and observation under high magnification would be necessary to determine if there is any minor damage to the paint layer.

Baron Henri-Marie-Bruno-Joseph-Léon Kervyn de Lettenhove [1856-1928], St. Michel-lez-Bruges and Brussels, Belgium; by descent to Colette H. Dawson (Mrs. John W. Dawson), Zionsville, Indiana, from 1948;{1} Edith Whitehill Clowes (Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes), Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1960; The Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1960, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10012);{2} given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2017.
{1} On the death of Baron Kervyn de Lettenhove in 1928, his estate was divided between his wife (died 1934) and one surviving child, the Vicomtesse Roger le Sergeant d’Hendecourt (died 1942). Four children of the latter were minors in 1942; two died in 1945, and the estate remained undivided until 1948, when it was split between Colette Dawson and her sister. See letter from John W. Dawson to Allen Whitehill Clowes, 23 September 1960, File C10012, Clowes Registration Archive, IMA. {2} Sales Agreement, 19 August 1960, File C10012, Clowes Registration Archive, IMA.

Noseda, London.{3} (Germain Seligmann et Fils, Paris) by 1937;{4} Probably private collection of Germain Seligmann [1893-1978], New York, New York;{5} (Pierre F. Nesi, Beverly Hills, California, and later New York), on commission with him by 1941;{6} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958] in 1947;{7} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2017.
{1} The inventory of the Gaignières collection, made in 1711, was first published by Charles Loizeau de Grandmaison, “Charles Gaignières, ses correspondants et ses collections de portraits [troisième article]. Appendice” in Bibliothèque de l’école des chartres, vol. 53 (1892), pp. 12-44, and contains several portraits of Marie de Lorraine. The catalogue raisonné of Corneille de Lyon’s work lists four versions of this portrait of Marie de Lorraine, the most significant of which is in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery; see Anne Dubois de Groer, Corneille de LaHaye dit Corneille de Lyon, Paris, France, 1996, nos. 13-13C. The Clowes version, no. 13B, is supported by a modern cradle, and no trace of the red wax seal of Colbert de Torcy is present. {2} Christie’s, London, England, The Hamilton Palace Collection, 13th day’s sale, 15 July 1882, lot no. 1653 as “Lady of the time of Francis I, by Janet.” {3} The illustrated priced catalogue of the 15 July 1882 auction notes that “J. Noseda” purchased lot no. 1653, as well as many other portraits of royalty in this sale. This is likely to refer to Jane Noseda [1813/1814–1894] who was primarily a print dealer. On Noseda family, see Mark Westgarth, “A Biographical Dictionary of Nineteenth Century Antique and Curiosity Dealers” in Regional Furniture: The Journal of the Regional Furniture Society, vol. 23 (2009): 143-4. {4} Jacques Seligmann et Fils, Paris, was listed as the owner in the catalogue Chefs d’Oeuvres de l’Art français, Palais National des Arts, Paris, 1937, cat. no. 44. {5} Letter from Nesi to Clowes, 8 May 1947, File C10027, Clowes Registration Archive, IMA. {6}Letter from Seligmann to Nesi, 28 March 1941, File C10027, Clowes Registration Archive, IMA. {7} See bill of sale from Nesi to Clowes, 16 January 1947, File C10027, Clowes Registration Archive, IMA.

There are some small areas of tenting ground and paint in the lower right, just above the sitter's proper left shoulder (approximately 2-3 mm in size). The areas of tenting are associated with a crack in the wooden support. These areas are vulnerable to loss and should be stabilized.

There appears to be a light-colored ground that is slightly visible through areas of abrasion in the paint layer. Overall, the adhesion between the ground and the support appears stable at this time. However, there are some small areas of tenting ground and paint in the lower right, just above the sitter's proper left shoulder. The areas of tenting are associated with a crack in the wooden support. These areas are vulnerable to loss.

In IMA Art Storage, framed. 2014: conservation lab, unframed 2015: conservation lab, unframed 2016: conservation lab, unframed 2017: unframed, on exhibit ( CSI ) in the galleries. Frame in conservation lab. 2018: Framed on gallery wall, with flashlight
There are no discernible signatures or markings on the front or back of the painting.

Overall, the adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable. There are some small areas of tenting and cleaving ground and paint in the lower right (approximately 2-3 mm in size), just above the sitter's proper left shoulder. The areas of tenting are associated with a crack in the wooden support. These areas are vulnerable to loss and should be monitored carefully. There are very small, old paint losses in this area.
There is previous inpainting along most of the old horizontal cracks, indicating that the ground and paint were likely unstable in these areas at some point. The inpainting is slightly discolored, but not to the point of being markedly distracting.
There is a very fine crack pattern in the paint throughout the composition. These fine cracks appears stable at this time but have accumulated some dirt that makes them appear visually prominent, especially in the lighter passages of the painting. Additionally, there is some minor old abrasion to the thinly painted areas.
The frame appears stable at this time and adequately houses the painting. There is general wear and abrasion to the surface of the frame and old nicks and losses to the knull edge.

There are some small areas of tenting ground and paint in the lower right, just above the sitter's proper left shoulder (approximately 2-3 mm in size). The areas of tenting are associated with a crack in the wooden support. These areas are vulnerable to loss and should be stabilized.

The wooden support appears relatively stable at this time. There is a very slightly convex warp to the panel; the wood grain runs horizontal to the composition so that the top and bottom edges are slightly out of plane.
There are old cracks in the panel that run horizontally through the composition. These cracks, although old, may be slightly unstable due to the strain caused by the old cradling system on the verso.

The is a mahogany cradle affixed to the back of the painting. The cradle appears strongly adhered to the original panel and all of the movable battens are locked. This may indicate that there is stress being applied to the panel.

The varnish is relatively thickly applied. It appears fairly even in gloss, however there are a few small matte areas that appear to mainly be associated with previous inpainting. The natural resin varnish has discoloured over time, resulting in a darker and yellowed appearance to the painting.

Julian Acampora (died 1958), New York, New York; {1} (John H. Folman Art Gallery, Bronxville, New York) in 1954; {2} George Henry Alexander Clowes (1877-1958), Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1954, as by Francesco Francia; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, since 1958 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10038); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2017.
{1} Acampora was a restorer of old master paintings; see his obituary, New York Times, 25 April 1958. He is identified as the owner prior to Folman; see letter from G.H.A. Clowes to Folman, November 1954, File C10038, Clowes Registration Archive, Indianapolis Museum of Art. {2} See 1954 letter cited above. 2012: The condition of the painting remains stable. From old areas of localized loss not filled or retouched during a previous restoration it is apparent that the wood panel support was primed with an off-white colour. It appears to have yellowed slightly over time. The ground appears to be well adhered to the wood panel support and is stable. There are some small losses of the paint and part of the ground along the edges. The ground exhibits a cracking pattern related to the wood grain, typical of an aged 15th century panel painting. The cracking network extends through the paint layers, and has been accentuated by the accumulation of dirt.

In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014: unframed, conservation lab. 2015, 2016: in the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2017: Framed, on wall, in gallery. 2018: Framed in storage with a flashlight
IMA - Allen Whitehill Clowes Special Exhibition Gallery - W203 - nook

The oil paint appears to be well-adhered to the underlying preparatory layers. Some abrasion is present which was the result of a previous cleaning attempt. In several instances these areas were retouched. The retouching in the Christ Child has become lighter with age, and remains quite obvious. In other areas (the Madonna's blue robe and clothing, the sky and foreground), the retouching adequately matches the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint A micro cracking pattern from natural aging extends over the entire painting. Small paint losses are scattered throughout the painting. Some wear is visible around the perimeter of the painting where the paint is in contact with the frame. Some of the paint has been heavily abraded from a previous cleaning. This is particularly noticeable in the glazes of the trees and shrubbery, the words in the prayer book, as well as the halos.

The frame appears to be generally stable at this time. 2012: The frame appears to remain stable. There are old superficial losses to the gilding that have been retouched as well an numerous old areas of abrasion throughout the surface. These are not new, but should be noted. 2013: The frame appears to remain stable. There are old superficial losses to the gilding that have been retouched as well an numerous old areas of abrasion throughout the surface. These are not new, but should be noted. 2014: No change to frame. 2017: Frame remains the same.
No immediate treatment necessary. In the future conservation should be considered in conjunction with additional curatorial research.

Comprised of several pieces of wood, the wood panel support appears to be generally in plane and is stable at this time. Partially covered by the rabbet of the frame, very old losses along the left edge of the panel are present. Only in some instances were these areas filled and/or retouched during a previous restoration. These areas appear to be generally stable at this time. The panel is currently in stable condition and remains in plane. Previous insect damage is visible when viewed from the verso in the form of woodworm channeling. The panel was also thinned before the addition of the cradle. There are a few splits in the panel that have been conserved. These were likely the result of a previous convexity. There is slight wear along all edges. The bottom left corner is dented with some loss of the support.

The panel is cradled with an elaborate 20th century cradle, involving 16 fixed vertical members, and 8 movable horizontal members.The cradle members are not seized, indicating that the panel has been kept in a stable environment with little changes in humidity and temperature (appears to be a tangential cut as seen from the bottom edge, possibly contributing to the previous warping which resulted in the cradle).

The surface of the painting is generally glossy in appearance. Small cleaning tests indicate the presence of a slight accumulation of dirt on the surface of the painting. The painting has a layer of natural resin varnish, which has somewhat discoloured over time.
A mild enzymatic solution was used to determine the accumulation of dirt on the surface of the varnish.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground layer appears stable for both paintings. Both paintings exhibit some abrasion to the paint layer throughout. There are some minor areas of old inpainting in the sky of the painting depicting the gondolas on the canal and in the sky, brown foreground, and left edge of the painting depicting the people and architecture at the edge of the canal. For both paintings, the old inpainting is slightly discolored.

The frames for both paintings are the same style and molding. The frames appear stable and adequately house the paintings. There is general wear and abrasion to both frames and several old nicks and losses to the outer edges. The mitered joins are cracked and slightly open, but appear stable at this time.

Both paintings are executed on fabric supports and appear stable, taut, and in plane. The supports have been previously lined to a second fabric support. The adhesion between the original and lining supports appears stable at this time.

The varnish is relatively even in gloss for both paintings. It appears slightly discolored, hazy, and no longer saturates the colors of the two paintings. Additionally, there is old darkened residual varnish or dirt trapped in the interstices of the paintings. These darkened remnants break up the spatial depth of the compositions.

Possibly (V. B. Galleries, New York, New York);{1} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971 (C10088); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2017.
{1} Another textile was purchased from the V.B. Galleries by George Henry Alexander Clowes, Hendrick Mattens’ Miraculous Draft of Fishes, 2016.372. This gallery can now be identified as “The Galleries of Paul S. Van Baarn, Ltd.” specializing in antique tapestries, paintings, furniture and works of Art; see “Front Matter,” Burlington Magazine (March 1938): vi.

A small mille fleurs tapestry with central ogival medallion containing a figure of Christ; wool and silk wefts, wool(?) warp (2-ply S); intentionally eccentric wefts form curving flower stems; details in the Christ figure and the stars around him have been created and/or are reinforced with embroidery.

No change in condition. To avoid unnecessary handling and the resulting stress and strain to which this textile would be subjected the tapestry was not unrolled for its annual assessment. It was examined in-situ in its rolled state in art storage. The tapestry has not moved from this location since its previous assessment and the environment in art storage has not fluctuated outside of the parameters set for optimum preservation. The tapestry's protective wrapping is clean, intact and undisturbed, indicating that there has been no significant change in the condition of the tapestry. (2018)

The tapestry has been prepared for hanging with linen strapping and a dust guard across the bottom edge of the back; a loose linen lining is stitched across the top and along both side edges; there is a muslin sleeve for hanging stitched across the top back of the tapestry over the lining.
For storage, the tapestry is rolled face out and warp wise on an acid-free tube, with a Tyvek tube header and outer wrapper.

No treatment necessary at this point for structural stability; aesthetics may be improved through re-treatment, but this would be an enormous project involving significant re-weaving and would likely not appreciably improve the appearance of the piece.
Mille Fleurs Tapestry with Medallion of Christ

Fletcher, Oxford, England; by descent to Marjorie Fletcher, Constable’s wife’s great niece.{1} Colonel Maurice Harold Grant [1872-1962], London, England;{2} (John Nicholson, Gallery, New York, New York) in 1947; George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana in 1947; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} Typed excerpts from a 23 February 1934 letter by Marjorie Fletcher was shown to John P. Nicholson, and shared with Ivan Podgoursky at the time GHA Clowes purchased the painting. She writes that the painting was “in our family for three generations;” see Clowes Registration Archive, File C10025. {2} In correspondence dated 13 February 1948, John P. Nicholson identifies that he obtained the painting from Colonel Grant the year before; see Clowes Registration Archive, File C10025 Colonel M.H. Grant was the author of several books on English landscape painting, including A Chronological History of the Old English Landscape Painters, 1926, reprinted 1957. See Clowes Registration Archive, File C10025

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, David Miller, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, follower of: Follower of Weyden, Rogier van der | Flemish | about 1399-1464

(Galerie Sedelmeyer, Paris, France);{1} Eduard Friedrich Weber [1830-1907], Hamburg, Germany, in 1897.{2} Marczell von Nemes [1866-1930], Munich, Germany, by 1930.{3} Probably Countess Vetter von der Lilie, Vienna, Austria;{4} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York, New York);{5} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958}, Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1934; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} A red oval wax seal on the stretcher bar can be deciphered to read: Galerie Sedelmeyer Paris.” {2} A paper label, once on the verso of the painting, bears a round ink stamp which can be deciphered to read: Galerie Weber, Hamburg. It also bears the hand-written date "1897" as well as the inventory number "969". Eduard Weber did not own a gallery but amassed a large and important private collection which he called the Galerie Weber. This painting is not included in any of the published posthumously in Berlin in 1912 with other parts of this collection. However, correspondence in June 2013 with Carla Schmincke, author of the 2004 Hamburg University dissertation Sammler in Hamburg: Der Kaufmann und Kunstfreund Konsul Eduard Friedrich Weber (1830-1907), revealed that in an unpublished inventory of Weber's collection, which she viewed in 2000 in the possession of a Weber heir, since deceased, nos. 967 to 971 were all purchased at Charles Sedelmeyer's Gallery in Paris. {3} The early Netherlandish art scholar, Max Jakob Friedländler, knew of three versions of this portrait: one formerly in the Cardon collection, Brussels (see RKD photo, Kunstwerknummer 104196); another, one in the Von Hollitscher collection, Berlin (see RKD photo, Kunstwerknummer 232913), and the Clowes Collection painting, which had belonged to Marczell von Nemes in 1930 (see Friedländer's notes on RKD photo, Kunstwerknummer 232912). Friedländler was very familiar with the von Nemes collection; he wrote the introduction to the 1931 posthumous auction collection catalogue as well as an obituary in Pantheon, vol. 7 (1931), p. 32. {4} Art historians who documented the Clowes Collection, in 1968 (Mark Roskill, unpublished manuscript in Clowes Archive) and in 1973 (A. Ian Fraser, A Catalogue of the Clowes Collection, Indianapolis Museum of Art) both note that the painting came through Silberman Galleries from Countess Vetter von der Lilie, Vienna, but this had not been corroborated. A custom's stamp on the stretcher bar reads "Bundesdenkmalamt Wien" indicating that painting did pass through Vienna where the Silberman brothers had a gallery. {5} Bill of Sale, dated 6 October 1934, from A. Silberman in Clowes Archive.

Baron Henri-Marie-Bruno-Joseph-Léon Kervyn de Lettenhove [1856-1928], St. Michel-lez-Bruges and Brussels, Belgium; by descent to Colette H. Dawson [Mrs. John W. Dawson], Zionsville, Indiana, from 1948;{1} purchased by Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1885-1967], Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1960;{2} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1967, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapols Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} Upon the death of Baron Henri Kervyn de Lettenhove in 1928, his estate was divided between his wife (who died in 1934) and one surviving child, the Vicomtesse Roger le Sergeant d'Hendecourt (died 1942). The four children of the latter were minors on the death of their father; two died in 1945, and the estate remained undivided until 1948, when it was inherited by Colette Dawson and her sister. Correspondence from John W. Dawson to Allen W. Clowes, 23 September 1960, see Clowes Registration Archive. {2} Sales agreement, 19 August 1960, see Clowes Registration Archive.

2012: No apparent change in painting or frame. IN PROGRESS AT THIS TIME: Frame and painting currently in conservation for digital imaging, technical examination and detailed assessment for conservation treatment. 2013: Conservation treatment completed on both the painting and frame. 2014: Painting and frame remain stable with no changes. 2015: No changes to painting or frame at this time. 2016: Painting and frame remain stable since 2013 year conservation treatment. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged since 2013 year conservation treatment. 2018: The condition of the painting and frame are unchanged at this time.
There is a light colored ground visible through brushstrokes and areas of abrasion in the paint. The overall adhesion between the ground and the paint layer appears stable.

There are painted initials and a date in the lower right.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. There are old losses associated with the horizontal crack/join that runs the width of the painting. There is also extensive old inpainting along the crack. The inpainting has markedly discolored over time and no longer matches the surrounding original paint in color or opacity.
There is marked abrasion throughout the painting, including the thinly painted areas such as the ships in the water.
The frame appears stable at this time. There is general wear and abrasion throughout. Additionally, there are numerous old losses to the gold and gesso layers.

The wooden panel appears generally stable at this time. The verso is fitted with a cradle system. There is a prominent horizontal crack/join that runs the width of the painting through the sky. There are several old losses and damages along this crack, indicating that there were previous structural issues with the support. There do not appear to be any active structural issues.

The surface coating is relatively even in sheen. There is an overall satin appearance to the surface. The extensive inpainting appears glossy in comparison to the surrounding surface. The varnish has become slightly dull and hazy.

Dawson], Zionsville, Indiana, from 1948;{1} purchased in 1960 by Edith Whitehill Clowes [Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes] [1885-1967], Indianapolis, Indiana;{2} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} Upon the death of Baron Henri Kervyn de Lettenhove in 1928, his estate was divided between his wife (died 1934) and one surviving child, the Vicomtesse Roger le Sergeant d'Hendecourt (died 1942). John W. Dawson, letter to Allen W. Clowes, 23 September 1960 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive). {2} Sales agreement, 19 August 1960 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

2012: Painting and frame appear to remain stable. Marked with localized areas of age craquelure the panel was primed with a white ground layer as is evidenced when viewing thinly painted areas of the composition. The adhesion between the ground and panel support, as well as areas of age craquelure, appear to be stable at this time.

There does not appear to be any signature or date on the front of the painting.

The oil paint layer appears to be well adhered to the underlying ground layer. Marked with passages of paint abrasion, from a very early restoration attempt, some of these areas have been retouched previously. For the most part the areas of retouch still match the color and opacity of the surrounding original paint at this time. In addition there are passages of traction crackle in dark areas of the composition which is a result of the long term aging characteristics of the various paint layers. Creating a slight texture to portions of the composition, these areas of traction crackle are very old and remain stable.

Frame appears stable at this time. 2016: Frame appears stable and in very good condition but one minor loss with exposed wood is present within the top member, left of center. Loss appears to relate to old restoration and may require consolidation. 2017: No change to frame.
No treatment necessary at this time. 2016: Minor consolidation of frame recommended. 2017: Frame remains the same.

Given the large size of the painting the wood panel support appears to be generally stable and in plane. A small area of old fill and retouch is present in the bottom right corner of the composition. This area appears to be stable at this time.

The surface of the painting has an overall glossy appearance that is uneven in some areas, partially as a result of passages of traction crackle in the dark paint layers of the composition. Small cleaning tests indicate that there is no significant dust or dirt layer present on the surface of the painting. 2015: loss and scuffing in varnish layer, bottom right corner near frame edge, appears to be an older loss. 2017: No change to surface coating. 2018: a linear scratch in the varnish should be noted on the right side of the foreground below the water and above the leafy plant. This is likely associated with the above mentioned scuffs.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dust and dirt.
Virgin and Child in a Wooded Landscape

Constantini, Florence, Italy, who possibly acquired the terra cotta relief in Prato, Italy;{1} Charles Fairfax Murray [1849-1919], London, England.{2} Adolph von Beckerath [1834-1915], Berlin, Germany, by 1898 and until his death;{3} Estate auction at (Rudolf Lepke, Berlin), in 1916.{4} Elizabeth Drey of (Paul Drey Gallery, New York, New York) by 1962; Edith Whitehill Clowes in 1962;{5} Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} This is suggested in the auction catalogue, Nachlass Adolf von Beckerath, Berlin, Rudolph Lepke’s Kunst-Auctions-Haus, Berlin, 1916, lot no. 65 (ill. plate 10). {2} Ibid. {3} Von Beckerath is identified as the owner of the terra cotta relief in Ausstellung von Kunstwerken des Mittelalters und der Renaissance aus Berliner Privatbesitz veranstaltet von der kunstgeschichtlichen Gesellschaft, Alte Akademie der Künste, 20 May – 3 July 1898, p. 82, with installation photo plate LIX. {4} Nachlass Adolf von Beckerath, Berlin, Rudolph Lepke’s Kunst-Auctions-Haus, Berlin, 19 May 1916, lot no. 65 (ill. plate 10). {5} Bill of Sale from Paul Drey Gallery to Edith Whitehill Clowes, 15 May 1962, in Clowes Registration File, C10097)

The object is a terra cotta polychrome relief sculpture depicting an annunciation scene with the angel Gabriel at the proper right side of the composition and the virgin Mary seated on a chair at the proper left side of the composition. Examination in the gallery did not allow access to the back of the object.
2012: The back of the object was examined. It has irregular edges and vertical striations that suggest the clay was rolled out on wood or a scraping tool was used on the back before the object was fired. The edges have inherent, but stable, cracks due to the process of manufacture where clay was folded onto itself. There is also a raised vertical line on the back about 3 inches from the PR edge that is likely from manufacture as if the original wet clay was pressed onto a wooden structure and this line was formed from being pressed into the seam of two joined wood panels.

The terra cotta substrate appears to be structurally stable.
The surface has extensive paint loss, but the paint present is generally stable and the label text for the object indicates that the painted surface has been in its present condition for some time. There is one area in the lower proper left corner under Mary's chair where there is paint lifting.
2012: No change in condition is apparent, but removing the object from its case allowed for closer examination and the following additional issues have been noted. There is a tiny loss on the beak of the dove, but this issue is not new as it is documented in previous photographs. There are two original holes in the surface of the object, located at the edge of the architectural element in the center of the composition that suggest there was originally a dowel there intended to depict a pillar, but the dowel is now lost.
The back of the work has many surface losses, but these are stable. A particularly large loss is located at the back bottom PR corner and the top center near where hanging hardware is attached. There is a large area in the top center of the back of the work that appears to have chalk applied to it. There is also illegible writing in chalk in the center of the back. There is also an intentionally drilled hole in the center of the bottom edge of the work. The edges and back of he work have minor scrapes and abrasions throughout.
There is a paper label attached to the back of the object with pressure sensitive adhesive described above under "distinguishing marks." There is another incomplete portion of a paper label that has been removed.
2013: No change is apparent, however the back was not examined. There is a small amount of debris inside the case and it is unclear from where this originated.
2014: No change is apparent, however the back was not examined. There is a small amount of debris inside the case and it is unclear from where this originated.
2015: No change is apparent, however the back was not examined. There is a small amount of debris inside the case and it is unclear from where this originated. An old repair was observed at the bottom of the middle structural element, above the dowel hole, where a section had broken off and been readhered.
2016: No change is apparent, however the back was not examined. There is a small amount of debris inside the case and it is unclear from where this originated.
2017: No change is apparent, however the back was not examined. There is a small amount of debris inside the case and it is unclear from where this originated.
2018: No change is apparent, however the back was not examined.

In the Medieval Renaissance gallery- CL109, while the object was on the wall in its case. 2012: The object was removed from its case for examination in the gallery. 2013: Object examined inside its case while installed in gallery CL109. 2014: Object examined inside its case while installed in gallery C 202. 2015: Object examined inside its case while installed in gallery C202. 2016: Object examined inside its case while installed in gallery C202. 2017: Object examined inside its case while installed in gallery C202. 2017: Object examined inside its storage cabinet in W203.nook.c2.lv1.

W.S. BUDWORTH & SON, INC. PACKERS & SHIPPERS OF WORKS OF ART 424 West 52nd St., New York, N.Y.
TITLE ____ ARTIST____ (missing)DDRESS____

Notes at the USC Fisher Museum of Art suggest it was purchased by “Mason”. {3} See information provided by the University of Southern California (USC) Fischer Museum of Art, Los Angeles, in e-mail correspondence June 2018. {4} Ibid. {5} Bill of Sale from Newhouse Galleries to Edith Whitehill Clowes, 6 June 1966, in Clowes Registration Archive, File C10056).

Additionally, there are some small old losses throughout. These areas are all under the varnish and appear stable at this time. There are some areas of previous inpainting, but they do not appear to have appreciably discolored.

The frame appears stable at this time. There are numerous old damages and minor losses to the gesso and gilding. These areas currently appear stable. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface of the frame. -2018 an unretouched loss is present on a decorative element on the right edge of the frame half way down. This may be one of the previously noted losses
The fabric support appears stable, taut, and in plane. The original support has been lined to a second (likely fabric) support.
The varnish is very thick on the surface. It is discolored, hazy, and no longer saturates the colors of the painting. There are numerous old streaks and accretions on the surface.
Surface cleaning should be considered to remove dust, and old fingerprints.

Possibly Duke Francesco (II) Maria Sforza [1495-1535], Milan, Italy.{1} Count Istvan Ambrózy-Migazzy [1869-1933], Hungary.{2} (E. and A. Silberman Galleries, Budapest, Hungary, and Vienna, Austia, later New York, New York;{3} Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana, by 1937; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} A coat-of-arms on the verso of the panel has been linked by some scholars to the Sforza family because it features the “biscione,” a blue snake devouring a human. Others, like Mark Roskill, have questioned this, since the other elements of the coat-of-arms (a white eagle and 3 fleurs-de-lis) cannot be traced to a particular line of this lineage. {2} Ambrózy-Migazzy is a surname for which there are multiple spellings. Count Istvan, a naturalist and founder of the Mlyňany Arboretum, today in Slovakia, was likely only a minor collector of art, although paintings now at the New Orleans Museum Art, New Orleans, Louisiana (61.73) and the Toldedo Museum of Art, Toledo, Ohio (36.21) are also from his collection; {3} Dr. G.H.A. Clowes purchased several paintings from Elkan and Abris Silberman which derived from central European collections.

2013. No apparent change at this time. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the painting and frame remain unchanged at this time

The wood panel support is generally in plane and is stable at this time. Affecting the ground and paint layers in varying degrees, age craquelure is present throughout the composition. It is stable at this time.
2012: On April 2, 2012 a very old loss in the Madonna's dress, right below the neckline, appeared to have an area of structural weakness affecting the paint/ground layer to the left and slightly below it. As a preventative measure this area was locally stabilized with gelatin adhesive. With appropriate approval, the area of old loss was locally filled, inpainted and locally varnished. This treatment occurred May 14 - 16, 2012.

When viewing passages of the oil paint layer that have been more thinly applied it is apparent that the wood panel support was primed with a white ground. This preparatory layer appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is stable at this time. Very old small "dots" and accretions which are underneath the current surface coating were not retouched. In addition, localized areas of paint abrasion are present but no retouching was applied in these areas as well. Finally, in the bottom left edge a very old loss is present which was not filled or retouched during the previous restoration attempt. Mostly covered by the rabbet of the frame, this area appears to have been covered with varnish. It is stable. Retouching in several areas of the painting has discoloured over time, and no longer matches the original paint.
2012: See "2012" entry for "Ground/Preparatory Layer" above.
The frame appears to be stable at this time. The frame exhibits a history of flaking and many old losses are apparent across the frame.

No treatment necessary at this time. 2014: Painting would benefit aesthetically from varnish removal, new retouching where the old retouching no longer matches the original paint, and a saturating layer of varnish.

The surface of the painting has been coated with a moderately thick layer of semi-glossy varnish. Small cleaning tests indicate that there is a slight accumulation of dirt on the surface. Small matte areasare scattered throughout the painting in areas of retouching where the varnish does not adequately saturate the paint.
2013. On 9/30/13, a finger mark left minor dull areas across the right side of the head and hair. These were successfully removed via a light local surface cleaning and mild friction from a soft, dry microfiber cloth to reduce varnish bloom.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dirt.

Probably Andrew H. Noah [1858-1931], Akron, Ohio; Sale at (American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, New York, New York) in 1939.{1} George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana; Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, since 1958, and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} American Art Association-American Galleries, Paintings & Drawings from the Collection of the late Andrew H. Noah, Akron, Ohio, …with other properties sold by order of the various owners, 12 April 1939, no. 17 (ill.)
Three separate drawings of red chalk (sanguine) on laid & chain paper joined in one format.

The drawing(s) appear to be in stable condition.
2012: The condition of the drawing is unchanged since the 2011 condition survey. It has remained undisturbed in drawer storage.
2013: No changes observed. The drawing has remained in drawer storage since the last evaluation
2014: No changes observed. The drawing has remained in drawer storage since the last evaluation.
2015: No changes observed. The drawing has remained in drawer storage since the last evaluation. The location of the drawing will now be transferred to Print Drawing & Photograph storage, to be with other works on paper.
2016: No changes in condition observed. The drawing now resides in Prints, Drawings, & Photographs Storage, upright in a slotted bin.
2017: No changes in condition observed. 2018: No changes in condition observed. The drawing(s) have been unframed and are currently stored in conservation awaiting modifications to the mat.
2018: Eligible for loan is the borrowing institution maintains IMA gallery standards and the loan period does not violate the rotation policy for light-sensitive artwork.
IMA Art Storage 2013: Paper Lab 2014: Paper Lab 2015: Print Study 2016: Print Study (as always, framed) 2017: Print Study (framed) 2018: Paper Lab

The images are executed in red chalk (sanguine). NOTE: White chalk touches are thought to be added by a later restorer. Graphite drawing lines are also present and they are very important to the composition. The chalk lines are hard and flattened; at least one "pressed copy" was made from this grouping, which lifted loose particles and blurred and embedded remaining chalk. The media at this point is considered very stable.

Clowes frame has a gold leaf finish on a decorative, sculpted wood frame with high carving and delicate details. Security hardware is present. The paper is shown beneath a narrow window mat, which allows the original mount carrying "French Mat" decoration to be visible. The glazing is currently Plexiglas, but was once fitted with UV filtered glass.

Remove the drawings (if possible) from the cardboard backing, and re-mat in acid-free materials. A larger, deeper frame might be considered as well. The drawings could also be matted to an IMA standard size and stored in a Solander box.
2018: The secondary support will be modified in the following way: A collar of acidic matboard surrounding the layered, historic parts of the mount, will be removed and replaced with archival matboard. This new matboard will not be visible, as the overlying window mat (which is an IMA cream-colored archival matboard) will cover it completely. The older parts of the mount, including the discolored French mat design layer, will be visible.
5 fc maximum. The drawing was on display in the IMA galleries for many years; a prolonged storage period is beneficial.
The drawing is stable. It remains framed, with museum-accepted materials inserted to replace harmful cardboard, etc. It is stored upright in a slotted bin.
red chalk and graphite on paper

The papers are cream-colored with a fine laid & chain pattern, which runs horizontally in two papers and vertically in the third. They are joined together at the edges and all are adhered firmly to the backing cardboard. The papers are thought to be of high quality fiber. The three papers have slightly differing degrees of brightness and there are minor stains and a slight unevenness of tone in each one. The drawings have been through a restorer's hands, and some imperfections have been overlaid with white chalk or paint. On the verso there is an iron gall ink script which is visible through to the recto side of the first figure. A paper insert forms the top section of the first paper - 5/16" tapering to 1/4" wide.

The three joined drawings are backed with a soft, white wove paper that could either be a lining or a dry-mount tissue. This is adhered to a thin cardboard faced with a cream-colored paper carrying an exaggerated laid & chain texture. This cardboard is larger than the drawing on all sides; the French Mat lines are drawn upon the protruding borders of the cardboard, and gold-faced strips of paper are adhered inside of the French Mat design to form a fillet around the edges of the drawings. This complicated format is acidic, stained, and warped. The ink lines are smudged and blotchy, and the mat constitutes a visual distraction.

2018: Once the acidic matboard collar is removed from the drawing's mount, remove the brown gummed tape that held it on (spanning the mount and the acidic matboard). The new matboard collar (archival) will be secured to the original mount using Japanese paper and wheat starch paste.
2018: Reports and imaging: 6-8 hours. Treatment time: 9 - 14 hours.

m.mv: Kristen Adsit, Richard McCoy, Sue Dupuis, Laura Kubick, David Miller, Morgan Nau

(E. and A. Silberman Galleries, New York, New York) by 1938;{1} George Henry Alexander Clowes in 1938; on long-term loan to Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} Letter from Abris Silberman to Clowes, dated 25 October 1938, in Clowes Registration Archive, File C10093. {2} Letter from E. and A. Silberman Galleries, Inc. to Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes dated 25 October 1938. “I want to notify you that we have shipped today via the Railway Express Agency, prepaid, to your home address, the Italian Chest.” Clowes Historical Files.

The object is a lidded wooden chest with metal hinges, lock and side handles. The front of the chest is decorated with a scene of the magi visiting the Virgin and child in the manger, surrounded by a decorative border with foliage, dogs, rabbits and shields. The design was carved or burned into the wood, and the resulting negative space was filled with a thick pigmented (paint) layer.

Overall the object is structurally sound, intact and stable.
STRUCTURE: The wood that forms the chest is structurally sound and intact. In addition to seams between wooden planks, there are large splits in the wood at the bottom of the front panel, and at the center of the bottom panel (visible when the lid is opened).
There are old losses to the wooden planks, mostly around areas where the wood has been joined, or where metal hardware is present. The most noticeable of these is found to the proper right of the lock on the front panel. In that area, nails appear to have been added to hold the remaining wood in place.
The proper left handle missing completely. The remaining hardware shows signs of red-colored corrosion, indicating an iron-based composition for the metal.
SURFACE: Overall, the surface bears scratches, abrasions, accretions, staining and minor losses consistent with other objects of its age. The paint layer suffered extensive losses in the past, but currently appears to be stable. The losses are most significant on the proper right side of the lower border on the front panel.
The lid is highly stained with both dark and light spots. The largest darkened area is at proper left, the lighter bleached spots at rear proper right.
The surface appears to be coated with a thin shiny layer. This layer appears to be slightly darkened.
The surface is dusty.
2012: There is no apparent change to the condition of the chairs -- no new cracks or losses evident.
2013: No change is apparent.
2014: No change in condition but note that there is a small loss below the feet of the second figure from the right that appears newer than others. It has likely been there for awhile but was not previously recorded.
2015: No apparent change noted at this time.
2016: No apparent change noted at this time.
2017: No change in condition but note that there is a small loss of green in the proper left side vertical decorative border element, about 1/2 way up that appears newer than others. It has likely been there for awhile but was not previously recorded.
2018: No apparent change noted at this time.
Clowes Pavilion, IMA - Netherlandish gallery - C202r1 - riser 2018-12-27: IMA storage, W203 nook
IMA - Allen Whitehill Clowes Special Exhibition Gallery - W203 - nook

Interior of lid near the latch has a small metal plaque with the number "7748." A paper label with the collection number is also affixed to the back of the chest.
White plus signs have been painted on the proper left side panel and on the interior of the lid near the front. Inside the lid, the same paint was used to form "13." next to the x, and "XXVI" at the front proper left corner. At the top proper right corner of the front panel, a similar paint reads "3496." This paint was likely applied in the past by a dealer or former owner.

m.mv: Kathleen Kiefer, Sue Dupuis, Amanda Holden (2018)

Possibly (V.B. Galleries, New York, New York);{1} George Henry Alexander Clowes, Indianapolis, Indiana; on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields in 2018.
{1} George Henry Alexander Clowes made at least one important purchase from the V.B. Galleries in New York, New York, so perhaps the provenance of this silk carpet is identical. (This gallery can now be identified as “The Galleries of Paul S. Van Baarn, Ltd.” specializing in antique tapestries, paintings, furniture and works of Art; see “Front Matter,” Burlington Magazine (March 1938): vi.)

A knotted pile Persian rug; silk warp, weft and pile; red ground field with predominant beige central medallion; dark blue vase figures present in each corner of the field; various leaf and floral motifs scattered across the ground overall; five patterned borders surround the central field concentrically outward to the edges; medium blue silk-covered edge cords; knotted warp fringe across top and bottom edges.

The carpet was examined June 11-13, 2018 and no change in condition was noted. Additional condition observations at that time include: The pile direction of the carpet is inconsistent due to previous wear. The result is depending on the viewing angle there are sections where the rug appears darker and/or lighter than the surrounding areas. There are lines in the middle of the carpet from the pressure and compression of furniture over time. There is damage and loss of silk warp and fringe on both ends and some knotted fringe is at risk of detaching due to breaks in the warps. These condition notes do not indicate a change in condition over time, but instead are just a more detailed recording of the current and past condition. 2018
The rug is stored rolled face out on an acid-free tube with Tyvek header and outer covering.
No treatment necessary at this time; consider vacuuming the back of the rug next time it is unrolled and handled.
silk warp, silk pile 625 knots per inch

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, David Miller, Linda Witkowski, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist, after: After Bosch, Hieronymus | Netherlandish | 1450-1516

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: There is no apparent change in condition. 2013: There are no apparent changes noted at this time. 2014: The painting and frame appear to remain stable with no changes at this time. 2015: There is no apparent change to the painting's condition; the painting is currently undergoing complete technical examination and treatment. 2016: Treatment was completed on the frame and painting and both appear brighter and more uniform overall. Painting: old varnish and restorer's paint was reduced/removed and a barrier varnish applied, old fills adjusted and new applied, extensive inpainting carried out, and final varnish layers applied (see treatment report for details). The painting appears significantly brighter overall. Frame: damage and delamination were addressed through fills and inpainting. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged since 2016 conservation treatment. 2018: The condition of the painting and frame remain unchanged

There appears to be a light colored preparatory layer below the current composition. Previous examinations that include x-radiography and Infrared reflectography have indicated an underlying composition; therefore, under the current image, there are numerous paint layers.
The adhesion between the preparatory or underlying layers and the wooden support appears stable at this time. There are numerous old losses and damages that have been retouched. Additionally, there are previous losses to the ground and paint layers along the edges of the panel, where the wood is exposed. The paint and ground surrounding these old damages appears stable at this time.

In the Painting Conservation Lab, framed. 2014, 2015: Painting, unframed, in Conservation Lab and placed in flat storage. 2016: Framed, in gallery (Davis Lab, CSI Exhibit), on wall. 2017: Framed in IMA Art Storage. 2018: In storage at eye level with flashlight; framed

There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting.
There are paper labels on the verso of the frame that appear to contain Clowes inventory information. Additionally, there is an oval stamp on one of the horizontal members of the cradling systems attached to the verso. In normal light, the stamp is illegible. 2015: Stamp on cradle verso is transparent to reflected infrared.

The oil paint appears well adhered to the underlying layers of paint and ground below. There are numerous old areas of damage and abrasion throughout, many of which have been retouched or inpainted. Additionally, there are losses and damages to the ground and paint layers along the edges of corners of the panel; many of these areas expose the underlying wood support. The original paint layers surrounding the current losses and damages appear stable at this time.
Many of the areas of retouching have become somewhat matte in surface gloss and it has become hazy and no longer matches the surrounding original paint. The shift in color is difficult to discern exactly due to the heavy varnish layers. 2016: Cleaning, barrier varnish, and inpainting all contributed to an overall saturation of color as well as the reintegration of forms throughout the composition.

The bottom right corner of the frame has some damage and delamination of the veneer wood, but the frame is otherwise stable and adequately supports and houses the painting. There are some scuffs, nicks, and abrasion to the frame overall. 2016: Damage and delamination was addressed during treatment and the nameplate removed and filed in Registration.

The wooden panel has a slight convex warp so that the sides curve back and out of plane. There is a vertical split, possibly along a previous join in the support, that runs the full height of the painting. At this time, the split does not appear to be unstable. It is unclear whether the cradle system attached to the verso has contributed to the split. At this time, due to the stable museum environment, the cradle does not appear to be causing a tremendous amount of stress on the support or ground and paint layers.
The verso exhibits some previous insect damage, which is not currently active. 2016: The support was found to be stable with the cradle system stabilizing the central split.

The painting has a heavy varnish that likely consists of several layers. The varnish is markedly discolored. There are several, small varnish tests in the upper half of the painting that indicate the effect of the discoloration from the varnish layers. Overall, the varnish appears dull and hazy and no longer saturates the colors of the painting. Many areas of retouching have also become matte.
Additionally, there is a moderate accumulation of dirt on the surface. 2016: The painting no longer appears dull and hazy. Cleaning proved successful in greatly reducing grime, old varnish, and restorer's paint, and applying final layers of varnish fully saturated color and evened the surface sheen overall.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Sarah Gowen, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Bosschaert, Ambrosius , the younger | Dutch | 1609-1645

John Kenneth Danby, Wilmington, Delaware [1889-1956]; {1} Sale at (Parke-Bernet Galleries, New York, New York) in1956; {2} probably purchased by Victor D. Spark, New York. Acquired in 1958 by Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1885-1967], Indianapolis, Indiana; The Clowes Fund Collection, 1958-present (C10008).
{1} The Delaware Historical Society provided a brief biography of Danby on their website. He established Danby Galleries in Wilmington in about 1935. {2} Following Danby's death, his estate was put up for auction. See Parke-Bernet,New York, Important American Furniture and Decorations; American and British Portraits and other paintings, part one, 13 October 1956, no. 345.

2012: No apparent change was noted at this time. 2013: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2014: No change in painting, frame has an old split that is slightly open, and will eventually require consolidation. 2015: No new changes in painting or frame, old split in frame remains inactive. 2016: No change in painting or frame. 2017: Painting received full conservation treatment and was returned to its frame. Framed painting is currently on the wall in the gallery. The painting and frame are stable. 2018: No change to the condition of the frame or painting

When viewing areas of paint that have been more thinly applied, the wood panel support appears to have been primed with a white ground. The ground appears to be stable and well adhered to the wood panel support. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees, the composition is marked with overall age craquelure typical for a painting of this age. The craquelure appears to be stable at this time.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2016, 2017: In the gallery framed and on the wall. 2018: In storage at eye level with a flashlight; framed
There is a signature and date in the bottom right corner of the front of the painting: A BOSSCHAERT 16__(?)

The oil paint appears to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers. Some areas of the paint layer exhibit traction crackle (top-center of the composition) though this also appears to be stable at this time. During a previous restoration attempt some paint abrasion has occurred, most of which was retouched during that time. At present areas of retouch adequately match the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint.

The frame appears to be stable at this time. 2014: frame has an old split (bottom center, outer edge) that is slightly opened and will eventually require consolidation. 2015: No change in the frame. 2016, 2017: No change to frame.

No treatment necessary at this time. In the future, curatorial research is recommended to try and determine the complete date on this painting. 2014: Although it appears to be inactive at this time, the split in frame should be consolidated in the near future. 2017: The split in the frame was consolidated when the painting underwent full conservation treatment during this time period.
The wood panel support appears to be generally in plane and is stable at this time.

The varnish coating is generally glossy with slight variations in areas where traction crackle is present in the underlying paint layers. Small cleaning tests on the surface of the painting indicate that a slight accumulation of dirt is present.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface of the painting to determined the accumulation of dirt on the surface.
2017: The painting underwent a full conservation treatment.

m.mv: Christina O'Connell, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Roxane Sperber (2018)
Artist: Boudewyns, Adriaen Frans | Flemish | 1644-1711||Artist: Bout, Peeter | Flemish | 1658-1719

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: No apparent changes noted with the condition of the painting or frame. 2013: Painting and frame appear to be stable with no apparent change noted. 2014: Painting and frame remain stable with no changes noted. 2015: Painting and frame remain stable with no changes noted. 2016: No changes noted to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the condition of the painting or frame at this time.
There appears to be a light-colored ground that is slightly visible through areas of abrasion in the paint layer. The adhesion between the ground and the fabric support appears stable.
In IMA Art Storage, framed. 2015: In lab, unframed. 2016: In Conservation Lab, unframed 2017: Framed, in conservation lab 2018: In storage on a cart; framed

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground layer appears stable. There is previous marked abrasion throughout the paint layer, most noticeable on the thinly painted areas such as the trees and the sky. There are minor old losses to the paint throughout the composition. Both the old losses and many of the areas of abrasion have been previously inpainted. The inpainting is slightly discolored and no longer matches the surrounding original paint.
The frame appears stable and adequately houses the painting. The frame exhibits a moderate amount of wear and there are old nicks and scuffs to the surface throughout.

The fabric support appears stable and is taut and in plane. The painting has been previously lined to a second fabric support. The adhesion between the original and lining support appears stable at this time.
The surface coating is relatively even in gloss. It appears slightly discolored, hazy, and no longer saturates the colors of the painting well.

m.mv: Artist, attributed to: Attributed to Cassatt, Mary | American | 1844-1926
The image is executed in pastel chalks on a wove, colored paper substrate. The paper is free in the interior, but the edges may be adhered to an unseen secondary support.

The pastel appears to be in good condition overall.
2012: The condition of the pastel is unchanged. It has been in dark storage since the 2011 condition survey report. The cardboard on the back of the frame has yet to be replaced, but this is a low priority while the pastel is inactive and not exposed to light.
2013: The pastel paper has a slight undulation through the heads of the figures. This may have been a pre-existing condition, not noted until now because of different lighting conditions. The pastel image does not appear to be harmed or in any danger. Climate in storage is very steady. Framing materials have not been altered at this point in time.
2014: The framed pastel has remained in storage throughout 2014. The paper substrate still exhibits some undulations, and certain sections are close to the glass glazing, but not believed to be touching. Colors remain bright. Poor quality framing materials have not yet been closely examined for suitability, but this work will be added to the backlog for framing attention and adjustments. The stable climate in storage is optimal. No changes noted.
2015: No changes in condition noted. The work has not been moved since the annual examinations were initiated.
2016: No changes in condition noted. This is the only work on paper remaining in general storage. All other works on paper have been moved to Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage
2017: No changes in condition noted. The work has not been moved since the annual examinations were initiated.
2018: No changes in condition noted. The work has not moved from storage.

IMA Art Storage. The pastel was examined within its frame. 2013: Art Storage. Examined while framed, hanging on a painting rack. 2014: Art Storage. Examined while framed, hanging on a painting rack. 2015: Art Storage. Examined while framed, hanging on a painting rack. 2016: Art Storage. Examined while framed, hanging on a painting rack 2017: Art Storage. Examined while framed, hanging on a painting rack 2018: Art Storage. Examined while framed, hanging on a painting rack

The drawing bears a signature near the lower left corner, in black pastel: "Mary Cassatt." The frame carries a metal didactic plate that reads: "Mother and Child / Mary Cassatt / American 1845-1926 / The Clowes Fund Collection"
The image is executed in pastel chalks, including the signature. The image is in excellent condition.

The pastel drawing is stored permanently framed. The frame is a carved wooden structure with a linen-wrapped inner frame. The frame back is cardboard and the glazing is glass. The frame is stored on a paintings rack in IMA Art Storage.

In the next few years, it would be a good idea to open the frame and check the framing materials. Acidic boards should be replaced with archival quality substitutes when possible.
2015: not yet scheduled
2016: not yet scheduled.
2017: Not yet scheduled.
2018: Not yet scheduled.
5 fc of light. 6 month maximum display duration, followed by at least 3 years of storage.

The drawing is executed on a wove, colored paper support which resembles modern papers fabricated especially for pastel medium. The current color is a taupe with dark blue fibers visible at the surface. The original color may have been closer to an overall blue. The paper is softly cockled, but held well away from the glazing of the frame except for larger swells of paper near the bottom edge. The paper appears to be in stable condition. There is a small loss in the upper left corner.
Possible behind the paper substrate. Adhesion would only be around the edges.
There is always significant risk involved when pastel images travel.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, David Miller, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: There is no apparent change to the condition. 2013: There are no apparent changes noted at this time. 2014: No changes apparent at this time. 2015: Painting and frame remain stable with no changes at this time. 2016: No changes to painting or frame at this time. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the frame is unchanged at this time. The painting remains mostly unchanged but several areas of insecure paint were noted.

From viewing areas of thinly applied oil paint it is apparent that the canvas was primed with a white ground. This preparatory layer appears to be moderately well attached to the canvas and is generally stable. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees the painting is marked with age and mechanical craquelure. The craquelure appears to be moderately stable at this time. In the bottom right corner a loss is evident that was filled and retouched during the previous restoration. However, along the upper right side of the composition a small area of paint loss is present, exposing the underlying ground. This loss is old and was not retouched during the previous restoration attempt. In both instances the areas appear to be moderately stable at this time. -2018: In addition to the loss on the right side several areas of insecure paint were noted in the upper right corner and orange paint on the leg of the figure furthest to the right
In art storage, framed and on a cart. 2016: In art storage. 2017: Framed, in conservation lab. 2018: Framed, in storage with a flashlight

The thinly applied oil paint appears to be generally well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers and is generally stable at this time. Localized areas of paint abrasion are evident throughout the composition as a result of a previous cleaning attempt. Areas of localized fills and retouch appear to be generally stable. The retouch generally matches the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint layer.
The frame appears to be stable.

Because the painting is not on display, no treatment is necessary at this time. In the future, conservation can be considered depending on the results of further curatorial research toward artistic attribution.

The painting is executed on a plain weave fabric support. The support was backed with an additional piece of fabric during a previous restoration attempt. A complex tear is evident in the right-center of the composition. The lined painting projects slightly outward in this area. Very slight undulations can also be seen in the lined painting. In spite of these surface deformations the original and backing supports appear to be generally stable at this time.
The surface of the painting is partially glossy in appearance. Small cleaning tests indicate the accumulation of a slight dirt layer on the surface.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the surface of the painting to determine the accumulation of dirt.
