m.mv: Artist, school of: School of Clouet, François | French | 1510-1572

The painting is executed in aqueous paints on laid & chain paper, which is mounted to a decorative matboard back and framed behind glass.
2018: Possibly dry-mounted
2018: Cleavage noted in the background paint

Overall, the painting appears to be in excellent condition.
2012: The condition of the painting remains unchanged since the 2011 condition survey. It is still desirable to investigate improvements to the framing, and it is hoped that this can be scheduled in the foreseeable future. Meanwhile, the painting is not at risk in storage.
2013: No changes observed. The painting has remained in storage since the last evaluation.
2014: No changes observed. The painting has remained in storage since the last evaluation.
2015: No changes observed. The painting has remained in storage since the last evaluation. The permanent location for this work will be shifted to Prints, Drawings & Photographs storage to join the other Clowes works on paper / parchment.
2016: No changes in condition observed. The painting has remained in storage since the last evaluation, although the storage location has changed. The framed work now resides in F25, bin storage.
2017: No changes in condition observed. The painting has remained in storage since the last evaluation.
2018: Because this survey examination took place in the Paper Lab, it was possible to use the microscope. There are two small, subtle outbreaks of lifting paint in the blue background. The insecurity may be in touch-up paint, painted over the original surface. A major problem is that the painting cannot be unframed because the back of the frame is screwed AND glued securely in place. Opening the frame would entail significant damage to the frame back, and cause vibration to the entire structure. This will have to be done at some point, but until major examination/analysis is called for, it will remain unopened. Limited information can be obtained from observing the artwork behind glass.
Although there is no visible evidence of a ground layer, a very thin gesso-like layer may be present beneath the paint.

IMA Art Storage. The painting was examined in its frame. 2013: IMA Art Storage. The painting was examined framed, flat on a utility cart 2014: IMA Art Storage. The painting was examined framed, flat on a utility cart. 2015: Print Study. Framed 2016: Print Study. Framed 2017: Print Study: Framed 2018: Paper Laboratory
Metal inscription plate attached to frame: "Sketch of Charles IX / School of Francois Clouet / French c.a. 1522-1572 / The Clowes Fund Collection"

The image is composed of aqueous-based paints, applied in small strokes. The paint is matte and opaque, resembling egg tempera. The exact nature of the binding material can be established with scientific analysis. There has been a minute amount of paint loss along the small creases near the bottom left and right corners.

The painting resides in the original Clowes Collection frame. When not on display, it is stored in IMA Art Storage, hung on a sliding paintings rack. The frame consists of a thin wooden outer frame containing a broad liner covered in red velvet, which is worn and threadbare in several locations. Inside of the liner is a fillet of alternating black and gold-leafed bands of raised wood. The back of the frame is closed with a piece of wood; the glazing is thought to be glass. There is advanced security hardware on the back of the frame. The painting inside of the frame is mounted to a larger piece of matboard decorated in the "French mat" style. The matboard is probably not of archival quality. The glazing appears to be in direct contact with the painting.
2016: NOTE 1: The frame structure as it stands could not easily accommodate alterations such as spacers. The painting is not at present experiencing distress in connection with its contact with the glazing. Working with this frame could be considered as a future project if it is called for exhibition. Note 2: The painting has been moved to F25 storage (prints, drawings, & photographs).
2018: The painting is now stored in Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage in an upright, slot-storage bin.

Within the next year, the painting should be unframed and given a formal examination. A spacer should be inserted into the frame to hold the painting away from the glazing; a gas-impermeable barrier material should be placed between the matboard/painting and the wooden frame back. The stability of the matboard mount can be assessed at that time and changes made if desired.
2013: A formal examination of this painting would begin at the request of the Curator. It is hoped that this will be forthcoming during 2014, as all Clowes holdings are examined.
2016: Deferred exploration of frame alterations until the painting is activated for loan or exhibition or at the specific request of the Curator (NOTE: as of this writing the European Art before 1800 Curatorial position remains unfilled.). No changes in the painting's condition have been noted as the painting rests in storage.
2017: The painting has remained undisturbed this year. There may be Curatorial interest in this work in 2018-2019 for more in-depth examination.
2018: The painting remains framed. If there is Curatorial interest, it could receive full conservation attention in anticipation of the Clowes Portrait exhibition or the Clowes catalogue.
5 fc of light. 6 months of display followed by at least 3 years of storage. NOTE: The painting was displayed almost continuously for many years; a prolonged storage period would be beneficial.

The painting is executed on laid & chain paper, presumed handmade. Paper of this period possessed exceptional qualities of strength and stability. (NOTE: No unpainted paper is available for observation). There is one thin crease line (about 5/8 inches long) near the lower right corner and a very small, branched crease (about 5/16 inches long) near the lower left corner.
2018: Use of the microscope in this examination has raised doubts about the identification of the substrate as paper. It could vellum. Cellulose fibers seen straying from the edges could be from an underlying dry-mount tissue. Certain areas of blue background paint have a texture that would suggest and underlying pore or follicle structure, indicating a protein skin product such as parchment or vellum.

The painting is mounted to a larger piece of matboard which is decorated with iron gall ink lines, watercolor, and a thin band of gold leaf-faced paper strips. The matboard has darkened to a warmer tone. The method of adhesion between the painting and the matboard is unknown at this time; a small tuft of white fiber protruding from behind the upper left corner may be part of a paper hinge. The matboard may not be of archival quality.
2018: It is possible that a dry-mount tissue is present beneath the substrate.
2018: May not travel until treated for paint insecurity
2018: Unframe for a proper examination when the time is deemed appropriate. At that time, stabilize cleaving paint, or otherwise deal appropriately with overpaint.

m.mv: Linda Witkowski, Sue Dupuis, Sarah Gowen, David Miller, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Baron Henri-Marie-Bruno-Joseph-Léon Kervyn de Lettenhove [1856-1928], St. Michel-lez-Bruges and Brussels, Belgium; by descent to Colette H. Dawson (Mrs. John W. Dawson), Zionsville, Indiana, from 1948 {1}; purchased in 1960 by Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1885-1967], Indianapolis, Indiana {2}; The Clowes Fund Collection [The Clowes Fund, Inc.], 1967 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971.
{1} Upon the death of Baron Henri Kervyn de Lettenhove in 1928, his estate was divided between his wife (who died in 1934) and one surviving child, the Vicomtesse Roger le Sergeant d'Hendecourt (died 1942). The four children of the latter were minors on the death of their father; two died in 1945, and the estate remained undivided until 1948, when it was inherited by Colette Dawson and her sister. Correspondence from John W. Dawson to Allen Whitehill Clowes, 23 September 1960 (IMA, Clowes Collection Archive).

2012: Old frame losses were noted. There are no apparent changes to the condition. 2013: No apparent change in condition. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change noted to painting or frame - both remain stable. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the painting or frame at this time

The wood panel appears to have been primed with a white ground layer that is visible through areas of thinly applied paint. Marked with age craquelure, typical for a panel of this age, the craquelure appears to be generally stable and well adhered to the wood panel support. There are areas of previous loss and damage to the ground and paint layers that have been subsequently been retouched. These areas appear stable at this time.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: Conservation lab; framed
There does not appear to be any signature or initials on the front of the painting.

The oil paint appears to be well adhered to the underyling preparatory ground layer. There are areas of loss in the ground and paint layers, as well as old abrasion to the paint layer all of which have been previously filled and retouched. These areas appear to be stable at this time. The old fills are not quite level with the surrounding area and areas of old retouch no longer match the color, texture and opacity of the surrounding original paint.

The frame appears to be stable at this time.
2012: The frame has old design layer losses scattered across the surface. Some losses have been toned in previous treatment. The frame appears stable but should be monitored. 2013: No apparent change in condition. 2014, 2015, 2016: No apparent change in condition.
No immediate treatment necessary at this time. For aesthetic reasons consider conservation treatment on this painting within the next 3 - 5 years.

The wood panel support appears to be generally stable and in plane. There are localized previous fills and repairs along the left side and bottom left edges of the panel. These repairs are very old and appear to be stable.
2016: The original panel is thinned and a full cradle is adhered to the verso (noted during technical examination earlier in year).
The surface has an overall glossy/satin sheen. Small cleaning tests indicate there is a moderate accumulation of surface dirt/nicotine over the surface of the painting.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dirt/nicotine.

2012: The painting and frame are stable at this time. 2013: The painting and frame are stable at this time. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change in painting or frame noted. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: Painting and frame are unchanged at this time

As noticed when viewing a very old small loss in the top right corner of the composition, mostly covered by the rabbet of the frame, the wood panel support has been primed with a white ground layer. Marked with overall age and mechanical craquelure, the ground layer appears to be stable and well adhered to the wood panel support. The localized area of fill and retouch in the bottom left side of the composition also appears to be stable.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015, 2016: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: In gallery, framed, on wall. 2018: In conservation lab; framed

The adhesion between the paint and ground layer appears to be stable. Areas of slight paint abrasion, from a previous restoration attempt, have been retouched. The areas of retouch only moderately match the color and opacity of the surrounding original paint at this time.

The frame appears to be stable at this time.
2012: On the underside of the frame, there is a small scratch due to the security screw. 2013: No apparent change in condition. 2014, 2015, 2016: No apparent change. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time.
No treatment necessary at this time. For aesthetic reasons consider applying a slightly more saturating varnish on the surface of the painting sometime in the future.
The wood panel support appears to be stable and in plane. There is a localized area of fill and retouch in the bottom left side of the composition. This area appears to be stable at this time.
At present the surface coating is extremely matte in appearance. Small cleaning tests indicate that no significant amount of dust or dirt is present on the surface of the painting.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of dust and dirt.

Baron Henri-Marie-Bruno-Joseph-Léon Kervyn de Lettenhove [1856-1928], St. Michel-lez-Bruges and Brussels, Belgium; by descent to Colette H. Dawson (Mrs. John W. Dawson), Zionsville, Indiana, from 1948 {1}; purchased in 1960 by Mrs. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1885-1967], Indianapolis, Indiana {2}; The Clowes Fund Collection [The Clowes Fund, Inc., 1967 and on long-term loan to the Indianapolis Museum of Art since 1971.
{1} Upon the death of Baron Henri Kervyn de Lettenhove in 1928, his estate was divided between his wife (who died in 1934) and one surviving child, the Vicomtesse Roger le Sergeant d'Hendecourt (died 1942). 2012: Old frame losses were noted. There are no apparent changes to the condition. 2013: The painting and frame are stable at this time. No apparent changes. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change observed, both the painting and the frame remain stable. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: No changes to the painting or frame

When viewing more thinly painted areas of the composition it can be readily discerned that the wood panel support was primed with a white ground. Marked with overall age craquelure the ground layer appears to be well adhered to the wood panel and is stable. Areas of previous fills and retouch appear to be stable at this time as well.
In the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2016: In gallery, framed and secured to the wall. 2017: In gallery, framed and secured to the wall. 2018: In the conservation lab; framed

The adhesion between the oil paint and ground layer is stable. As a result of an older previous restoration attempt, areas of paint abrasion are evident in the paint layer, some of which have been retouched. For the most part the areas of retouch moderately match the color and opacity of the surrounding original paint at this time.

Frame appears to be stable at this time.
2012: The frame has old design layer losses scattered across the surface. Some losses were toned in previous treatment. The frame appears stable but should be monitored. 2014, 2015, 2016: The frame continues to remain stable, no apparent changes. 2017: No changes to frame at this time.

The wood panel support appears to be stable and in plane. Old fills and retouch are present along both sides and bottom edges of the composition. These areas of previous restoration appear to be stable at this time.
2016: The original panel is thinned and a full cradle is adhered to the verso (noted during technical examination earlier this year).

The surface has an overall glossy sheen. The gloss appears to be relatively even across the surface of the painting. Small cleaning tests indicate that there is no significant amount of dust or dirt on the surface of the painting.

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: There is no apparent change in condition. The painting remains stable. In May, 2012, the painting was examined (IRR and X-radiography) and small cleaning tests to the varnish layers and overpaint were carried out. Because of these tests, the painting is not exhibition-ready without further intervention. 2013: There are no apparent changes noted at this time. 2014: No changes at this time. Because of cleaning tests ( see above ) the painting is still not exhibition-ready and will require further treatment. 2015: No changes apparent at this time. The painting is still not exhibition-ready due to the presence of small cleaning tests and will require further treatment. 2016: No additional changes. 2017: No additional changes. 2018: There are no changes to the condition of the painting or frame at this time

From viewing thinly painted areas of the composition, the wood panel support appears to have been primed with a white ground layer. The ground appears to be well adhered to the wood panel. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees the painting is marked with age craquelure. This appears to be stable at this time. Also, extensive retouch appears to be present, over large areas of the composition. These areas also appear to be stable at this time.

In IMA Art Storage, framed and on the storage rack. 2013: storage cabinet SMc24 2014: storage cabinet SMc24 2015: storage cabinet Smc24 2016: Storage 2017: Storage 2018: In storage with a flashlight, framed

The oil paint layer appears to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers. Extensive paint abrasion, from a previous restoration attempt, appears over much of the composition, particularly in the sitter's dark black robe. During the previous restoration attempt many of these areas have been retouched. In dark areas of the composition (sitter's black robe, dark background) the areas of retouching adequately match the surrounding original paint. However, areas of retouch in lighter portions of the painting (sitter's white clothing and flesh) have darkened over time. In all instances the retouching appears to be stable.
Frame appears to be stable at this time.

Because this painting is in art storage rather than on display, no treatment is necessary at this time. In the future consideration should be given for the conservation of this painting based on the curatorial research in determining artistic attribution.
The wood panel support appears to be generally in plane and stable at this time.
The surface coating is glossy in appearance. Small cleaning tests indicate there is an accumulation of dirt on the surface.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dirt.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Ink wash painting on laid & chain paper.
Re-matting and framing is highly recommended. 2018: Flag directive has been accomplished

Drawing was examined within its frame; the verso surface was unavailable for observation. The drawing appears to be in stable condition, with various crease and loss damages (some restored) and foxing throughout.
2012: The condition of the drawing inside of the frame appears unchanged. 2013: No changes observed. 2014: The condition of the drawing remains unchanged. The work was kept in stable storage throughout 2014. The acidic matting and frame back cardboard will be replaced with archival materials in late 2014 or early 2015. 2015: No changes observed. The cardboard will be removed before the end of the year. 2016: No changes in condition observed. The acidic cardboard backing of the frame was replaced with archival blueboard. The acidic matting remains in place.
2017: No changes to the recto side of the drawing are noted. See Primary Support
The drawing now resides in an IMA 4-ply museum mat and it is stored in a Solander box. This is an improvement over the previous substandard frame environment. The Solander box does contain matted works of many different sizes; it is best for all of the artwork if the mat sizes were identical in a single storage box.
2018: There has been no change in storage conditions. No changes in condition are noted.
The Print Study, off of Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage (F25) 2013 - Print Study 2014 - Print Study 2015 - Print Study 2016: - Print Study 2017: - Print Study 2018 - Paper Laboratory

Iron gall ink signature present in the lower right corner of the image: "Goya." There is a plate attached to the front of the frame naming Goya as the artist, and a label on the back of the frame also lists Goya as the creator of the drawing. Curatorial opinion attributes the work to Lucas Eugenio Velazquez.

The image is executed in ink washes. There are several types of ink present: the most pervasive ink appears to be carbon-based, with a matte black tonality; a brown ink is seen in a few touches. The warm-colored foxing stains beneath the ink tend to cause many areas to appear brownish. A very dark, dry black ink was applied as a final emphasis in selected outlines. All of the inks are in stable condition. Losses occur only through damages to the paper.

The drawing is stored within its Clowes Collection frame. The frame has a stressed gold leaf finish and bears an informational plate in the center of the bottom member. The backing board is acidic corrugated cardboard, held in place with brads. The backing board is barely accommodated within the shallow frame. There is a triple window mat on the surface of the work: the outer mat is a dark brownish-gray, the center mat is faced with gold paper, and the innermost mat is a slightly textured, neutral colored mat. The two interior mats are clearly acidic. There is a better quality barrier window mat inserted beneath the neutral colored mat. The drawing is held well away from the Plexiglas glazing. The method of attachment inside of the mat is unknown.
2012: The IMA plans to seek permission to change the acidic cardboard in the back of the frame to an archival material. The double window mat is also acidic and it would be best for the health of the paper to change these as well; the Curator will decide the proper look for the window mat and discuss any changes with the Conservator.
2013: The cardboard frame back and the mats remain unchanged. It is not certain whether the Clowes Foundation has been contacted regarding permission to remove acidic materials; it is hoped that this question will be communicated in the coming year. The wash drawing itself appears unchanged. The artwork has not been displayed in 2013.
2015: The acidic cardboard backing will be changed to an archival product before the end of the year.
2016: The acidic cardboard backing has been removed and replaced with archival corrugated blueboard.
2017: The drawing has been unframed. It is stored matted inside a Solander box in Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage.

The drawing should be unframed and removed from the current mat structure. The verso should be checked for tapes and adhesives. The multiple window design of the mat is beneficial in protecting the planar distortions caused by the large creases, but the mats should be archival. The frame backing cardboard should be discarded and a new back of acid-free cardboard should be applied. A deeper frame is desirable.
2012: The above actions are planned for 2013 2013: The above actions are anticipated for 2014. 2015: It is possible that the entire framing package may be discussed in 2016. Removing the acidic cardboard is the first improvement, expected to be accomplished before year's end. 2016: It would be beneficial to replace the acidic window mats (2) in 2016 2017: The drawing is now unframed. The current mat is chemically stable, but has only A second window mat to create a higher space to accommodate the paper distortions would be an improvement. 2018: The drawing remains matted and stored in the Solander box. If called for exhibition, improvements to the mat could be considered at that time.
5 fc. maximum light level. No longer than 6 months of display at one time; display should be followed by at least 3 years of storage.
brown ink and wash on paper

The support is a cream-colored laid & chain paper that contains multiple severe creases at the right, left. and top sides. These could be purposeful folds to decrease the size of the paper for a desired presentation/frame. There is a large tear (1 3/4") at the bottom edge (repaired with adhesive) and there are several obvious losses (restored) near the top edge. There is foxing throughout the sheet, but the spots are light-toned and diffuse. There may be adhesive behind the corners.
2017: The verso of the drawing can be examined for the first time. There are remnants of Kraft paper tape across the verso top edge and there is a large strip of Kraft paper tape applied at the bottom edge of the paper as a repair to a large tear. There are amber-colored adhesive residues behind all four corners. Small pieces of thick laid & chain paper have been applied to the back of the drawing to fill in losses or stabilize small damages. The adhesive used to apply the paper patches is unknown at this time. The drawing paper is stiff and slightly puckered throughout.

2012: Remove the acidic components of the framing system if possible.(NOTE: This work will be scheduled in Prints, Drawings & Photographs, not Conservation)
2013: Remove the acidic components of the framing system if possible.(NOTE: This work will be scheduled in Prints, Drawings & Photographs, not Conservation)
2015: This should be accomplished.
2016: The acidic cardboard backing of the frame was removed and replaced with archival blueboard in 2016. It is hoped that the window mats can be replaced with archival materials in 2017.
2017: Full examination and treatment would be beneficial 2018: If the drawing is needed for display, it will no doubt be scheduled for treatment in conservation. Analysis may give new details regarding materials used to create the drawing, and can be conducted if there is Curatorial interest.

Artist: Esteve y Marques, Agustín | Spanish | 1753-1830

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: No apparent changes noted to the frame or painting. 2013: Painting and frame remain the same with no apparent change noted. 2014: Painting and frame appear the same. No changes noted at this time. 2015: No changes noted on painting or frame. 2016: Frame and painting appear to remain the same. 2017: No changes to painting or frame at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the condition of the painting or frame at this time
There is a red-colored ground that is visible through areas of abrasion in the paint layer. The general adhesion between the ground and the fabric support appears stable at this time.
In IMA Art Storage; framed and on the racks. 2016: Unframed in the conservation lab. 2017: Unframed in the conservation lab. 2018: In storage at eye level with a flashlight; framed
There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. There is marked old abrasion throughout the entire surface. Additionally, there is a prominent old mechanical crack pattern throughout. The cracks have been accentuated by the paint abrasion.
There are numerous old damages and losses throughout, but especially in the upper right corner where there is extensive inpainting. There are other passages of inpainting throughout the composition. The inpainting has discolored over time and no longer matches the surrounding original paint in color or opacity. The discolored inpainting is most noticeable in the background.
The frame appears generally stable and adequately supports the painting at this time. There is general wear and abrasion throughout the surface.
The fabric support appears generally stable and is taut and in plane. The original support has been lined and the adhesion between the original and lining fabric appears stable at this time.
The surface coating is dull, hazy and discolored. There are some areas that appear slightly matte and uneven.

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: There is no apparent change in condition. The cracks in the paint appear to have remained stable. 2013: Painting and frame appear to be stable with no apparent change noted. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: Painting and frame appear to be stable. No noticeable changes. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the painting or frame
There is a light-colored ground that is visible through areas of abrasion and loss in the paint layers. The overall adhesion between the ground and the wooden panel appears stable at this time.

Flat files in IMA Art Storage. 2014: In conservation lab, unframed. The painting underwent an in-depth technical analysis in June 2014. 2015: Framed, in conservation lab. 2016: In conservation lab. Framed. 2017: Framed, in conservation lab. 2018: In conservation lab; unframed

There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting. The frame has an overall wooden panel affixed to the back, on which there are numerous numbers hand written and a round stamp (possibly a customs stamp?).

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. There are numerous old losses to the paint layers which expose the underlying ground. These losses are very small (only a few millimeters in size) and are mainly located in the sky and near the center of the painting on the figures of the Virgin and child.
There is marked old abrasion to the paint layers, especially in some of the thinly painted areas including the hair and shadows of the flesh-tones.
There is a fine mechanical crack pattern throughout the composition. The cracks appears stable at this time.
There are some areas of old inpainting, most noticeable on the Virgin's proper right arm, that has discolored over time.
The frame appears stable at this time and adequately houses the painting. Reconsideration of the current hanging hardware may be necessary if installed in a gallery.
The wooden support appears stable and relatively in plane. There is a very slight convex warp to the panel and the two side recede back and out of plane by an estimated several millimeters.

The varnish is slightly uneven and appears dull and hazy. The varnish has discolored and no longer saturates the colors of the painting. In areas where the varnish pooled in the interstices of the paint, the discoloration is more pronounced.
2018: There is an observable layer of surface dust
Madonna and Child with St. John the Baptist

2012: There is no apparent change in the condition. The old damages previously noted remain stable at this time. 2013: There are no apparent changes noted at this time. 2014: The painting and frame remain stable with no changes. 2015: No changes. 2016: No changes to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: There are no changes to the painting or frame at this time

From viewing thinly applied paint layers in the composition it is apparent that the wood panel support was primed with a white ground. This layer appears to be generally well adhered to the wood panel and is stable at this time. Affecting the ground and paint layers, a small loss is present in the top left corner of the composition. This loss is very old, partially covered by the rabbet of the frame and appears to be stable. Finally, affecting the ground and paint layers in varying degrees age craquelure is evident throughout the composition. This craquelure appears to be stable at this time.

In IMA Art Storage, framed and on a paintings rack. 2014: Currently at Westerley ( viewed 11/11/2014 ) 2015: Currently at Westerley 2016: Currently at Westerley 2017: Currently at Westerley 2018: In storage at eye level with a flashlight; framed

The thinly applied oil paint appears to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers and is stable at this time. From a previous restoration attempt, localized areas of paint abrasion are evident. For the most part these areas were not retouched at that time. They appear to be stable.
Moderately stable, a few minute areas of loss are on the outer side panels of the frame. Small gaps are evident in the corners of the inner frame components.
Because the painting is not on display, no treatment necessary at this time.
The wood panel support is generally in plane and stable at this time.
The surface of the painting has a semi-glossy overall sheen. Small cleaning tests indicate that there is the accumulation of a slight dirt layer on the surface.
A mild enzymatic solution was used to test for the accumulation of dirt on the surface of the painting.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)

The painting is in good structural condition. The canvas is taut and in good plane. The paint and ground layers are stable and well bonded to each other and the canvas. The varnish coating is somewhat dull but does an adequate job of protecting the paint surface. There is a curious drip mark in the proper left corner of the background that needs further investigation in the conservation lab. The top edge of the painting reveals gold leaf that has rubbed off from the interior of the frame rabbet onto the varnish layer with some minor rubbing of the varnish at the extreme top proper right corner.
2012: There is no apparent change to the condition. The painting remains stable. 2013: There is no apparent change to the condition. The painting remains stable. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2018: A small loss to the gilding on the frame was noted although it is not clear that this is new. There are no further changes to the condition of the frame or painting at this time.
The off-white oil-based (assumed) priming is in good condition.

On display; framed and on the wall in the gallery. 2014: framed, in gallery, on wall. 2015, 2016: framed, in gallery, on wall. 2017: Framed, on wall, in gallery. 2018: In storage on ladder with flashlight; framed
Signed in black paint in the proper bottom right corner, Pietro Pezzati.

The tube-quality oil (assumed) paint is in good condition with no cracking visible to the naked eye. Higher gloss of some dark black strokes in the clothing suggests the addition of resin and/or more oil. The paint was thinly brush applied in a painterly fashion, mostly wet on dry with some scumbling. There is almost no impasto present. Glazes, if used, were minimal. There are passages that appear abraded but were likely due to deliberate scraping back by the artist as part of his technique.

The frame is a 20th century hand-carved reproduction of a 17th century Spanish style, with red bole, gold leaf, and black painted painted panels. A brass nameplate is affixed to the bottom center rail. The frame is in good condition except for some scattered very minor abrasions and what looks to be two screw holes, found about 1/3 down from the top on both the right and left panels. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate. The verso was not accessible. -2018: a small loss on the lower right edge of the frame should be noted.
The portrait could someday benefit from a lab examination to determine the nature of the drip in in the proper left corner and whether additional varnish application should be considered.
The canvas is in good condition. Tension is satisfactory and the canvas is in good plane.

An overall surface coating is present. It is quite thin and varies in gloss. Although it appears to remain clear and relatively uncolored, it has become dull/sunk-in in some areas but still does an adequate job of protecting the paint and saturating the colors. Some minor rubbing is visible at the lower proper left edge, and at the extreme top proper right corner. 2018: a small accretion on the figure's proper right arm should be noted, although not new as it is visible in photo.
A small cleaning test was made with a mild enzymatic solution. Almost no surface dirt/grime came away.
Portrait of Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Christina O'Connell, Fiona Beckett, Linda Witkowski, Roxane Sperber (2018)

The painting is in good structural condition. The canvas is taut and in good plane except for a vertical ridge along the ridge edge and a slight ridge in the bottom proper left corner related to a crack in the painting. The paint and ground layers are stable and well bonded to each other and the canvas. The varnish coating is somewhat dull but does an adequate job of protecting the paint surface. The edges of the painting have some rubbing of the varnish from the frame rabbet.
2012: There is no apparent change in the condition. The crack in the paint previously noted in the lower right has not changed and there is no danger of loss.
2013: There is no apparent change in the condition. The crack in the paint previously noted in the lower right has not changed and there is no danger of loss. 2014: Small loss in the bottom left corner (2mm)-appears to be recent, as the paint flake rests on the nearby surface. The remainder of the painting as well as the frame remain unchanged. Consolidation of the small area should be done in the near future to secure the loose flake. 2015: Painting remains unchanged. Minor consolidation was done using sturgeon glue to secure the loose paint flake 2016: No change apparent in painting or frame. 2018: No changes to the painting or frame at this time

The off-white oil-based (assumed) priming is in good condition. A horizontal crack appears in the red color field above the signature that reveals the white ground below. It was likely caused by something rubbing up against the back of the canvas in the past. The ground is stable in this area and in no danger.

On display; framed and on the wall in the gallery. 2014: framed, on wall, in gallery. 2015, 2016: framed, on wall, in gallery. 2017: On wall, framed, in gallery. 2018: In storage on ladder with flashlight; framed
Signed and dated in black paint in the proper bottom left corner, Pietro Pezzati 1965.

The tube-quality oil (assumed) paint is in good condition with drying cracks visible in the sitter's proper right shoulder and scattered in a few other locations. A horizontal crack appears in the red color field above the signature that reveals the white ground below. It was likely caused by something rubbing up against the back of the canvas in the past. The paint is stable in this area and in no danger. Higher gloss of some dark black strokes in the clothing suggests the addition of resin and or more oil. The paint was primarily thinly brush applied in a painterly fashion, mostly wet-on-dry with some scumbling. Brushwork in the skirt and the brooch shows some impasto. Glazes, if used, were minimal. There are passages that appear abraded but were likely due to deliberate scraping back by the artist as part of his technique. -2018: a similar crack to that noted above can be seen in the upper right section of the painting (this was previously noted in condition section)

The frame is a 20th century hand-carved reproduction of a 17th century Spanish style, with red bole, gold leaf, and black painted painted panels. A brass nameplate is affixed to the bottom center rail. The frame is in good condition except for some scattered very minor abrasions and what looks to be two screw holes, found about 1/3 and 2/3 down from the top on the proper left panel. The frame is screwed to the wall with a security plate. The verso was not accessible.
Additional varnish coating application should be considered in the future.

The canvas is in good condition. Tension is satisfactory and the canvas is in good plane except for a slight ridge along the full length of the proper left edge, suggesting that the artist slightly restretched his canvas to enlarge it.

An overall surface coating is present. It is quite thin and varies slightly in gloss, although is more uniform than on the Portrait of Dr. Clowes. Although it appears to remain clear and relatively uncolored, it has become dull in some areas but still does an adequate job of protecting the paint and saturating the colors. Some minor rubbing from the frame rabbet is visible at the edges of the painting .
A small cleaning test was made with a mild enzymatic solution. Almost no surface dirt/ grime came away.

Minor consolidation in bottom left corner is needed to secure loose flake of paint back to the painting. 2015: Minor consolidation was done using sturgeon glue to secure the loose paint flake. 2017: No changes at this time.

m.mv: David Miller, Sue Dupuis, Linda Witkowski, Fiona Beckett, Erica Schuler, Roxane Sperber (2018)

Possibly (Pieter Locquet Sale, Amsterdam, The Netherlands), 22 September 1783, lot 325; possibly Pierre Yver.{1} Purchased from a Dutch diplomat in Vienna, Austria, ca. 1840 by the Polish Count Adolf Husarzewski;{2} his son, Count Jozef Husarzewski, and his wife, Karolina, née Princess Jablonowska; their daughter, Countess Eleonora Husarzewska [1866-1940], wife of Prince Andrzej Lubomirski, in their castle at Przeworsk, near Lvov (now Ukraine); their son, Prince Jerzy Rafal Lubomirski [1887-1978], Geneva; (Frederick Mont and Newhouse Galleries, New York, New York) in 1951; Dr. George Henry Alexander Clowes [1877-1958] from 1951-1958; The Clowes Fund Collection, Indianapolis, Indiana, 1959-present.
{1} Cornelis Hofstede de Groot, A Catalogue Raisonné of the Works of the Most Eminent Dutch Painters of the Seventeenth Century, vol. 6, London, 1916, no. 549, cites this early provenance, but the authors of the Rembrandt Research Project believe it applies to another version. For a thorough study of IMA's painting including provenance and exhibition history, see Stephanie S. Dickey, Rembrandt Face to Face, Indianapolis Museum of Art, 2006. {2} See contributions by Jerzy Mycielski and Leon Pininski in Miecislas Treter, ed., Album de l'Exposition des Maîtres Anciens, avec cinquante reproductions, Ossolinski National Institute, Lvov, 1911.

The painting is in good and stable condition. Old cracks and small damages, as well as discolored old retouchings are not disfiguring. The varnish is yellowed and somewhat hazy but cleaning is not critical at this time. 2012: No apparent changes noticed at this time. Both painting and frame appear to remain stable.2013: No apparent changes noticed at this time. Both painting and frame appear to remain stable.2014: No apparent changes to painting or frame.2015: No change to painting or frame.2016: No apparent changes to painting or frame were noted at this time. 2017: No apparent changes to the painting or frame. 2018: a full technical examination was carried out on the painting. A small scratch in the varnish on the upper left corner was noted during this examination and retouched. The painting and frame are in otherwise unchanged condition
The thin white ground is in good and stable condition. There are numerous old tiny losses that are hard to see without magnification that were never retouched in the past.

This report was generated from the outgoing loan inspection notes and the conservator's memory as the painting is currently on loan to the North Carolina Museum of Art and will not return in time for submission of the survey reports to the Clowes Fund. 2012: Painting and frame examined on the wall in the gallery.2013: Painting and frame examined on the wall in the gallery.2014, 2015, 2016: Framed, in gallery, on wall.2017: Framed, in the gallery on the wall; 2018: Framed, in the gallery on the wall
IMA - Frances Parker Appel Gallery - K305
Signed in the proper left corner: RHL in dark brown paint.

The paint is in generally good and stable condition. Oil paint was applied with a brush, most smooth with vigorous brushmarking. There is low impasto in the scarf. The back end of a brush or other pointed tool was used to incise strands of hair into the wet paint. There are areas of thin paint and numerous old tiny losses that are hard to see without magnification that were retouched in the past. Many of the old retouchings have discolored and no longer match the original paint.

The reproduction Dutch 17th century ebonized ripple frame is in sound condition. There are a number of scattered minor blemishes, nicks, abrasions, and small cracks that have been repaired over the years. The frame has a brass nameplate firmly attached with small brads. The painting is always glazed with Optium low-refectance acrylic, or when on loan, enclosed in a protective microclimate package constructed with the same glazing material. The frame is always screwed to the wall with a security plate.

The painting must remain glazed for protection and be fitted with a microclimate display package should it go on loan. Removal of the thick, hazy and discolored varnishes would enhance the appearance of the painting by improving the coloration and revealing the vigorous brushwork but is not critical at this time.

The 2-piece oak panel is in good and stable condition. The vertical join is stable and old cracks and checks are stable. The bottom proper right corner is cracked and slightly offset, but the area is stable. Framing strips were glued and nailed to all 4 sides, most likely at the time that the panel was cradled. The strips function well and there is no reason to remove them at this time.
The panel is cradled with 5 vertical fixed and 5 horizontal sliding members. The cradle functions well and does not impart stress onto the panel. There is no need to modify it at this time.

The panel is coated with multiple layers of a natural resin varnish, such as Dammar, that have discolored to a medium yellow tone. Residues of older, darker varnishes can be seen trapped in the interstices of some paint strokes. The varnish has turned somewhat hazy, prompting application of modern synthetic varnishes on top of the old coatings to improve saturation and depth. A local application of varnish in the upper proper right appears slightly streaky but is not disfiguring.

m.mv: The drawing is composed of red chalk or Conte crayon on cream-colored laid & chain paper.

The drawing appears to be in very good condition overall.
2012: No changes in condition are observed. The drawing has remained in Storage on a vertical rack, covered with an opaque light shield since the 2011 condition survey.
2013: No changes in condition observed. The drawing has not been moved from storage since the last evaluation.
2014: No changes in condition observed. The drawing has not been moved from storage since the last evaluation. (NOTE: If the drawing is called for display, there are several losses in the gold/bole layer of the frame that should be repaired)
2015: No changes in condition noted. The framed work has been moved to a new storage location within Prints, Drawings & Photographs storage. It will join the other Clowes works on paper, and it will be free of the vibration associated with rolling rack storage.
2016: No changes in condition noted. The drawing was unframed and now resides matted in an IMA 4-ply museum mat stored within a Solander box.
2017: No changes in condition noted 2018: No changes in condition noted

IMA Art Storage. Drawing was examined within the frame. 2013: IMA Art Storage. Examined framed, on a painting's storage rack. 2014: IMA Art Storage. There is a stamped red ink collector's mark in the lower right corner of the drawing. It is somewhat blurred; it is two initials within an oval shape.
The image is composed of red Conte crayon or chalk. The lines are strong and unmarred, and soft subtle passages read clearly.

The drawing is in the original Clowes frame of highly carved wood with a gold leaf finish. The backing board appears to be Fomecor, and the glazing is Plexiglas. The original green, French mat style matboard is present but has been separated from the drawing by an inner 4-ply window mat of archival matboard. The glazing is held an appropriate distance from the drawing surface. The framed work is permanently stored on a paintings rack in Service Level Storage.
2016: The drawing was unframed. It is mounted in an IMA museum 4-ply standard mat and stored in a Solander box.

The drawing is stable and it is evident that the IMA has intervened in the past to provide acid-free materials within the frame. The adhesive found on the verso is not causing problems at this time. No work is required.
5 fc of light maximum. 6 months of display followed by at least three years in storage.
2017: The unframed drawing is matted with archival materials and stored in a Solander box in Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage.

The drawing is executed on a cream-colored laid & chain paper. The paper is foxed with light brown spots clustered primarily around the edges. The paper is bright and appears strong. The verso surface is not available for observation.
2016: The verso edges hold spotty adhesive residues. The surface is somewhat discolored although the paper remains supple. There is a formal inscription written in pencil centered across the verso surface.
2018: While the adhesive around the verso edges is not currently causing problems, it would be beneficial to remove it at some point in the future.

Artist, follower of: Follower of Rubens, Peter Paul | Flemish | 1577-1640

2012: There is no apparent change in the condition of the painting or frame. There are some areas of previously tented paint, located in the background and at the top of the sitter's head. These areas are not new, but should be monitored. 2013: There are no apparent changes noted at this time. 2014: The painting and frame remain stable with no changes noted. 2015: No apparent changes to painting or frame. 2016: No changes to painting or frame at this time. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: There is no change to the condition of the painting or frame at this time

Visible via areas of more thinly applied paint, the wood panel support appears to have been primed with a white ground layer. This layer appears well adhered to the wood panel. It appears to be stable at this time. Affecting the paint and ground layers in varying degrees, the painting exhibits areas of age craquelure. These areas are stable at this time.

In IMA Art Storage, framed and on a storage rack. 2016: Unframed in Conservation Paintings Lab. Technical analysis in progress. 2017: Unframed in Conservation Paintings Lab. 2018: In storage on ladder with flashlight; framed

The oil paint layer appears to be well adhered to the underlying preparatory layers. In dark areas of the composition (sitter's hair and clothing) localized areas of traction crackle are present in the paint layer. These areas are stable at this time. Areas of paint abrasion, from a previous restoration attempt, are present and appear to be stable as well. No significant amount of retouch is present.
2012: There are some areas of previously tented paint, located in the background and at the top of the sitter's head. These areas are not new, but should be monitored.
Frame appears stable at this time.
No treatment necessary at this time. In the future, curatorial research is recommended to determine the artistic attribution for this painting.
The wood panel support appears to be in plane and generally stable.

The surface has an overall glossy sheen. Small cleaning tests indicate that an accumulation of dirt is present on the surface. 2018: There are several small patches of matte varnish visible in these conditions
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dirt.

Provenance research is on-going at the Indianapolis Museum of Art at Newfields. Please contact Annette Schlagenhauff, Curator of European Art, at aschlagenhauff@discovernewfields.org if you have questions, or if you have additional information to share with us.

2012: There is no apparent change in the condition of the painting or frame. 2013: Painting and frame appear to be stable with no apparent change. 2014: No apparent change in painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change in painting or frame noted at this time. 2016:No apparent change in painting or frame noted at this time. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: Several small losses to the gilding on the frame were noted but are likely not new. Condition of the frame and painting remain unchanged and in stable condition.
There appears to be a light-colored ground visible through areas of abrasion in the paint. The overall adhesion between the ground and fabric support appears stable at this time.
in the gallery, framed and on the wall. 2014, 2015, 2016: in gallery, framed, on wall. 2017: Framed, on wall in gallery. 2018: In storage at eye level with flashlight; framed
There is no discernible signature on the front of the painting.

The adhesion between the oil paint and the ground appears stable at this time. There is a prominent crack pattern throughout the paint, but the cracks appear to be stable. There is marked paint abrasion throughout, especially in the thinly painted areas of the background and sitter's hair.
There are several passages of old inpainting. These areas have discolored and no longer match the surrounding original paint.

The frame appears stable at this time and adequately houses the painting. There are numerous losses to the gilding and gesso throughout and a marked amount of overall abrasion and wear. 2018: there is a losses on the inner ornament of the upper section of the frame and along the right edge of the frame. These are mentioned above, but should be noted specifically.
The fabric support appears stable and in plane. It is lined to a second support. The lining also appears stable at this time.

The varnish is relatively thick and unevenly applied. It appears relatively even in gloss, but is generally hazy and no longer saturates the colors of the painting. The varnish appears discolored and due to the unevenness of its application, the areas where the varnish has pooled on the surface appear even more discolored.
There are some faint, old scratches in the varnish that run horizontally across the bottom of the painting. Under gallery lighting conditions, these scratches are not visible. Additionally, there are some splatters in the lower left of the painting.

2012: There is no apparent change in the condition of the frame or painting. The prominent crack pattern in the painting remains stable. 2013: There are no apparent changes noted at this time. 2014: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2015: No apparent change to painting or frame noted at this time; the painting remains stable. 2016: No apparent change to painting or frame. 2017: Painting and frame remain unchanged at this time. 2018: The condition of the painting and frame are unchanged at this time.

The canvas appears to be primed with a red-brown overall toned ground, or possible imprimatura which is visible within the overall age craquelure marking the paint and ground layers in varying degrees. This layer appears to be well adhered to the support.

In IMA Art Storage, framed and on the painting storage rack. 2014: In the conservation studio, unframed. An in-depth technical analysis is currently underway. 2015, 2016: In conservation studio, unframed. 2017: Unframed, in conservation lab. 2018: In storage at eye level with flashlight; framed

The oil paint layer appears well adhered to the underlying preparatory layer. There are areas of old abrasion in the paint layer from a previous restoration attempt. Within the overall age craquelure, dark dirt and residual old varnish, not properly removed from the previous restoration, can be seen. Though visually disturbing, these areas of the painting are stable at present.
Frame appears to be stable at this time.

Given that this painting is not currently on display, no treatment is necessary at this time. In the future further consideration should be given for possible conservation based on additional curatorial information.

The original support appears to be a plain weave fabric. It has been lined. There appear to be localized repairs in the top right and left corners. There are corner draws in the top right and, to a lesser extent, in the bottom left corners of the painting. These have been present for a very long time. In spite of this the original and lining fabrics appear to be stable.
The surface coating has an overall satin finish. Small cleaning tests indicate that there is an accumulation of dirt on the surface.
A mild enzymatic solution was tested on the varnished surface to determine the accumulation of surface dirt.

m.mv: The drawing is executed in red chalk and what looks like soft graphite, with small, subtle touches of white chalk on a cream-colored, laid & chain paper.

The drawing in is good condition.
2012: The drawing remains unchanged. It has remained in drawer storage since the 2011 condition survey.
2013: No changes observed. The drawing has remained in drawer storage since the last evaluation.
2014: No changes observed. The drawing has remained in drawer storage since the last evaluation.
2015: No changes observed. The drawing has remained in drawer storage since the last evaluation. It's permanent location will be changed to Print, Drawing & Photograph storage to join the other Clowes works on paper or parchment.
2016. No changes observed. The framed drawing is now housed in Prints, Drawings & Photographs storage in a slot bin unit.
2017: No changes in condition observed.
2018: The drawing was unframed. It is mounted with two dark tan glassine hinges at the verso top edge. There have been no observable changes in condition. (A treatment to remove the glassine hinges is planned for late 2018-early 2019).
2018: Loan is possible if IMA gallery standards are upheld and the period of the loan does not violate the IMA rotation policy for light-sensitive works.

IMA Art Storage. The drawing was examined in its frame. 2013: Paper Lab. The drawing was examined in its frame. 2014: Paper Lab. The drawing was examined in its frame. 2015: Print Study. The drawing was examined in its frame. 2016 - Print Study. The drawing was examined in its frame. 2017 - Print Study. The drawing was examined in its frame. 2018 - Paper Lab. The drawing was examined unframed

The verso of the frame carries a sticker label with the inscription:
"The Clowes Foundation, Indianapolis Fine Arts Department 3744 Spring Hollow Road Indianapolis, Indiana, U.S.A."

The drawing is composed primarily of red chalk (sanguine) and there are a few very subtle touches of white chalk in the garments of the figures. Shadows and lines laid to emphasize depth are drawn with a black medium, which has the appearance of a soft graphite or perhaps a sharpened Conte crayon. Scientific analysis could identify the black medium with certainty. The red, black, and white media are in excellent condition.

The drawing is stored permanently framed. The frame is an ornately carved, gold leafed structure faced with glass glazing. Enhanced security hardware is present on the verso. The mat is a deep, slate blue color, decorated in the "French mat" style, with black ink lines and a fillet composed of gold-leafed paper strips. The mat remains unblemished and attractive; it is not known whether the mat is composed of archival materials.
2018: The drawing was unframed in the Conservation Department. The colored mat was confirmed as acidic - the core fibers are discolored and the mat evolves a faint odor.

The drawing could at some point be examined in the IMA Science Center to confirm the identity of the media. The mat fiber could be tested to determine if lignin is present. UPDATE 2018: The existing blue window mat has been judged acidic; lignin is present.
5 fc of light. The drawing was on display in the IMA galleries for many years; a prolonged storage period would be beneficial.

The drawing is stable. It remains framed and stored upright in bin storage in Prints, Drawings, & Photographs Storage.
2018: The drawing will likely remain permanently framed for storage purposes. The frame package will greatly improve with the planned mat replacement.

The support is a handmade, laid & chain, cream-colored paper carrying a heavy felt texture. There is slight cockling and some obvious creases radiating from the top edge in the upper left and right corner areas and also the center of the top edge. The planar distortion is visually minimized in gallery lighting, and the mat and a Plexiglas frame spacer keep the drawing at a safe distance from the glazing. NOTE: The drawing is framed, so the verso surface was not available for observation.
2018: The drawing was unframed. There are no marks of interest on the verso surface
2018: Remove non-archival hinge papers from the verso. This will be beneficial for the structural health of the paper over time.
Three Studies of a Seated Woman

2018: Remove the glassine hinges from the verso top edge. Change the mat (if possible, with Curatorial consent) to an archival quality window and backing. UPDATE NOTE: The glassine hinges will be removed in preparation for the AWC exhibition of Clowes Portraits. A new archival mat is being created in the conservation department by conservation technician Laura Mosteller. The blue color of the replacement mat was approved by the Curator; French mat decoration will be executed by Laura. The blue color is a historic type of window mat favored at a distinct point in time by collectors. Curator Kjell Wangensteen believes that the blue window should be retained for both historic and aesthetic reasons.
2018: Reports and imaging: 6-8 hours. Treatment: 2-4 hours.

m.mv: Kristen Adsit, Richard McCoy, Sue Dupuis, Laura Kubick, David Miller, Morgan Nau
The work is a pair of high-backed side chairs with a carved wooden frame and caned backrest and seat. Both chairs are coated with a dark varnish over the wood and caning elements.

OVERALL: As objects, the chairs are intact and structurally sound, however they are not sound for use as domestic furniture. Chair B shows significantly more signs of historic damage and deterioration than Chair A.
STRUCTURE: The wooden frames of both chairs display channeling, holes and associated losses that are signs of an historic insect infestation which is no longer active. This is most apparent on the proper left front leg and proper left side of the seat on Chair B. On both chairs, the interior of the bottom of the front proper left leg is missing, though the loss appears to be more recent on Chair B. The caning on both chairs is largely intact, with minor losses at the edges. On both chairs, canes are broken at the top proper right edge of the back, though the losses are more extensive on Chair B.
CHAIR A: The front cross beam is loose, and pivots along the horizontal axis. The lower left side of this piece appears especially worn and smeared with a brown-colored substance, possibly a fill material. Several strands of caning are missing from the front edge of the seat at center, where it attaches to the wooden frame.
CHAIR B: L-shaped metal brackets have been attached to the wooden frame in two areas in two campaigns, apparently to help stabilize the structure. The older-looking piece is found along the entire length of the underside of the proper left side of the chair, attaching to the rear proper left leg. This piece is dark red-brown in color and attaches with six screws. A much-smaller, shinier, brass-colored bracket is also attached with two screws underneath the proper right crossbeam where it meets the rear proper right leg.
In contrast to Chair A, the horizontal cross beam below the seat is not carved or highly finished, likely an historic replacement for the missing original. On the front proper left foot of the chair, a matte brown fill material is smeared along the outside and front surfaces. The caning of the seat is slightly warped, with a few broken canes near the proper left side at center.
SURFACE: The surfaces show an overall pattern of dents and scratches that is consistent with their age. The varnish is flaking off the caning of both seats and backrests. The varnish is abraded or worn from the high points of the carved wooden frame, especially at the front feet. The varnish appears thick and grimy, most noticeably in protected areas of the carving. The surfaces are dusty.
2012: There is no apparent change to the condition of the chairs -- no new cracks or losses evident.
2013: There is no apparent change to the condition of the chairs.
2014: No apparent change to the condition of the chairs.
2015: No apparent change to the condition of the chairs was noted at this time.
2016: No apparent change to the condition of the chairs was noted at this time.
2017: No apparent change to the condition of the chairs was noted at this time.
2018: No apparent change to the condition of the chairs was noted at this time.

The chairs are housed on a cantilever shelf in Art Storage. In order to remove the chairs, they must be carefully moved around other pieces on the shelf, and tilted on their rear legs in order for the high backs to clear the supports for the shelf above.

The object is a triptych carved in multiple segments of bone and mounted in a wooden case. The central panel shows the Virgin seated in an arch under a canopy, holding the infant Jesus and flanked by angels. The proper left and right panels each show a human figure with a crown, possibly the patrons who commissioned the work, standing under canopies.

Overall, the work is structurally sound, intact and stable. The bone segments are all present, and each is almost entirely intact. Only one crack is visible, located in the canopy of the central panel, on the proper right segment, at the center of the proper left side. This crack is stable and neither of the pieces shows any potential for movement.
A fill has been attached to the canopy on the central panel, at the bottom center. This may reflect a misinterpretation of the object's original form. The oblong form makes this area a different shape than other hanging parts of the canopy. In addition, the fill now blocks from view the top of the carved archway under which the Madonna is seated. The fill is slightly darker and more orange than the surrounding bone.
The piece bears no evidence of paint layer or other intentional surface coatings. An uneven layer of embedded dirt is particularly visible in interstices of the carving, in surface pores, and along the horizontal surfaces.
The work remains well secured to the wooden case. A hard, milky yellow-white dried adhesive is visible especially in the vertical joins between bone segments of the center and proper right canopies. In addition, a bulkier, opaque gray-white substance is visible near the middle segment of the canopy on the center panel. It can be seen in several locations, most notably when looking under the canopy overhang.
2012: No changes noted at this time. 2013: No apparent change at this time. 2014: No apparent change at this time. 2015: No apparent change at this time. However, it should be noted that the milky yellow-white dried adhesive is also visible on the PR door canopy along the outer edge of the door. 2016: No change apparent at this time. 2017: No change apparent at this time. 2018: No change apparent at this time.

In the Objects and Variable Art Conservation Lab
2015: Examined in IMA Art Storage 2016: Examined in IMA Art Storage 2017: Examined in IMA Art Storage 2018: Examined in IMA Art Storage
None on work. On verso of wooden case, plain white label with black writing "TR# 10094"

The exterior verso of the wooden case has several minor splits along the grain at the proper left. There are three small holes in each of the exterior center, proper left and proper right wooden panels which likely held hardware or fasteners to secure the panels closed or hold it open for display. The edges of these holes are worn, exposing the light-colored wood. On the proper left and right panels, irregularly-shaped patches of dry residue are located above and below these holes. This may be the remnant of an adhesive which was also used to attach hardware. The exterior of the wooden case also bears minor scratches, scuffs and abrasions overall.
2012: No changes noted at this time. 2013: On the verso of the wood case, there is a rectangular patch of old adhesive residue along the bottom, suggesting that the border seen on the sides and front of the case previously continued on the back or some other hardware was present. This is not new, but should be noted. 2014: No apparent change at this time. 2015: No apparent change at this time. 2016: No change apparent at this time. 2017: No change apparent at this time.

The object is a carved ivory relief that measures 3 x 2 1/4 inches. It depicts a standing Madonna and child, flanked by two figures, each holding a chalice. The figures stand under a carved arch. There is a plain border on all four sides of the relief. On the proper left side of the relief, there are two locations where a small metal nail and a fragment of a metal hinge remain in the border, one 1/2 inch from the top edge and the other, 1/2 inch from the bottom edge. This hardware implies that the relief was once part of a diptych or had some sort of attached cover.

The relief is generally structurally stable, but there is a loose piece of ivory in the top border area, measuring 3/16 inches wide, located 1/2 inch from the proper left side. It is loose, but not in imminent danger of detaching.
There are large vertical cracks in the ivory, many of which begin at the top border and extend down into the image area. The carved figures also exhibit vertical cracks. There is one crack at the bottom proper left corner of the border. There are scratches throughout the surface of the relief, including initials scratched into the bottom side of the bottom border that appear to read R-T. The ivory is dusty and dirty overall, causing some of the cracks to appear black. The high points of the carving are yellowed from handling.
The ends of the metal nails exhibit sparkly and fuzzy looking black corrosion. The heads of the nails and the hinge fragments have a light layer of sparkly black corrosion on them.
2012: No change apparent at this time. 2013: No change apparent at this time. 2014: No change apparent at this time. 2015: No change apparent at this time. 2016: No change apparent at this time. 2017: No change apparent at this time. 2018: No change apparent at this time.

The object should not be stored or displayed upright using the stand leg of the frame. The frame is unattractive and a better mount should be made for display.

m.mv: Laura Kubick, Richard McCoy, Sue Dupuis, David Miller, Morgan Nau

The object is a gilded metal relief sculpture. It appears to be gilded silver, however further investigation is needed to definitively identify the media. The relief was cast in sections that are attached to each other and the background panel with pins or solder. The object depicts a pieta scene with Jesus draped across Mary's lap, with a male and female figure flanking the central figures. There is a cross behind Mary and the scene is surrounded by gothic architectural adornments, including a pierced canopy. The top of the relief has a cross shaped finial and below the scene are two crossed keys. On the back of the object is a vertical handle.

The object is generally structurally stable. It is heavily tarnished and there are residues that look like calcium carbonate polishing compound in the pierced gothic canopy above the figures. There is also shellac and another natural resin present in selected areas, especially in spots on the canopy and on the finial on top of the sculpture. These may be areas that have been touched up. It is unclear whether there was once resin present over all. There are fibers from the red velvet frame stuck in the surface on the back side of the finial.
2012: No change apparent at this time. 2013: There is no change apparent at this time, however it should be noted that there are existing cracks in the canopy that are either part of the original construction or sites of old repairs. The solder used to attach the sections together is visible, but gilded over. 2014: No change apparent at this time. 2015: No change apparent at this time. 2016: No change apparent at this time. 2017: No change apparent at this time. 2018: No change apparent at this time.

Objects and Variable Art Conservation Lab
2015: Examined in IMA Art Storage 2016: Examined in IMA Art Storage 2017: Examined in IMA Art Storage 2018: Examined in IMA Art Storage

Caution must be used when moving this piece. 2018: The object is not attached at all to the shadow box and could fall out if handled improperly. Caution must be used when moving this piece.

The display frame is a wood shadow box with a red velvet interior. The velvet has a lot of losses in the pile. The object is supposed to be secured into the frame via a slit in the frame where a handle at the back of the object can come through and then a wooden slat is stuck through the handle, securing it onto the frame. However, the wooden slat is currently detached from the handle. This is not a good mounting system for storage or display.
When the object lays flat, the weight of the object and frame are supported on the handle. If the frame were hung on a wall, the handle would not allow the frame to rest flat against the wall.

The object was examined under long wave UV radiation. This method detected selected areas where shellac was present, due to its orange fluorescence. Another resin was also present that fluoresced a greenish color, and is likely a natural resin. Both resins were most commonly present in the canopy over the central figures. The finial at the top of the relief was coated in shellac and shellac may also have been present on the vertical architectural borders on either side of the figures, although it was a much thinner layer.

m.mv: Laura Kubick, Richard McCoy, Sue Dupuis, David Miller, Morgan Nau

The object is a small carved sculpture depicting a seated Madonna with the infant Jesus on her lap, one child standing on her proper left side, and a seated child at her proper right side. There is also a snail located on the ground of the sculpture between the feet of Mary and the seated child. Behind the leg of the standing child are some grapes and wheat. The sculpture is not made from ivory as the object's registration information indicates, but seems to be made of a material like compo or plaster, but it seems less dense than plaster. The back of the sculpture is flat and has rough tool marks. It also exhibits air bubbles as if the sculpture was carved from a cast block of plaster or compo. There are also two deep holes in the back of the sculpture that have a dark resin or hide glue inside, inside them. The holes appear to have been used as a way to mount the figure to a backing or a wall. The sculpture is mounted on top of a black painted wooden base with brown felt on the bottom.
2012: The object record in EMu has been updated and no longer indicates the sculpture is made from ivory. 2013: The first sentence of the description above was edited to be more accurate, but there is no change in the object.

The object is structurally stable. Its main condition issues are aesthetic. It has yellowed resin or glue on Mary's head, veil, neck and chest and well as on Jesus' proper right arm and legs and the seated child's proper right arm and leg. There is black paint from the base on the grapes and wheat. There are some cracks in Mary's face, which have dirt trapped inside, but they appear stable. High points of the sculpture are darkened and burnished. There is grime in the crevices and interstices of the sculpture.
2012: No change apparent at this time. 2013: No change apparent at this time. 2014: No change apparent at this time. 2015: No change apparent at this time. 2016: No change apparent at this time. 2017: No change apparent at this time. 2018: No change apparent at this time.
