m.mv: Kristen Adsit, Richard McCoy, Sue Dupuis, Laura Kubick, David Miller, Morgan Nau

The work is a porcelain tea set decorated with navy blue banding, gilding, flowers, and floral garlands in the shape of a monogram "MA" topped with a red royal crown. The set comprised of 10 separate elements, including a teapot and its lid, a creamer, a sugar bowl and its lid, two teacups and saucers, and a tray.

All the pieces in the set are structurally sound, however some pieces are in pristine condition while others are highly damaged or repaired.
The teapot lid, creamer, both teacups and one saucer have never been broken. The sugar bowl has a minor internal crack on the bottom through the porcelain body, however it also remains intact. The teapot, tray, sugar bowl lid, and the saucer with the yellow roses below the monogram have all been previously broken and reassembled. The saucer has only one clean break, however the other components show a complex pattern of interconnected breaks.
The sugar bowl lid and saucer have been expertly reassembled so that the break edges align tightly and the profile of the piece is preserved. Most of the breaks are only visible due to light brown staining along the break edges. These pieces bear only minimal fills and inpainting along the break.
The two most damaged components of the set are the teapot and the tray, however the stark difference in the repair materials used and method of application suggest two different treatment campaigns were conducted by two different parties. Except for one break at the underside of the base, the broken pieces of the teapot have been tightly aligned in a manner similar to the sugar bowl lid and saucer. Furthermore, though there are large areas of fill and inpainting, ultraviolet light was necessary in order to see that the spout of the teapot has been heavily damaged.
By contrast, the repairs to the tray are immediately evident with the naked eye. From the verso a network of breaks is visible around the foot of the tray as well as in several locations up the lip. A matte, tan-colored material has been smeared in extremely wide patches along many of these breaks, seemingly to fill small losses as well as to smooth the transition between poorly aligned fragments. One crack at the proper left side appears to have been previously repaired with staples, as is evidenced by the sets of two aligned holes along the break which are now filled. A white layer is associated with the tan fill material, and appears to lie on top. On the recto, a thick layer of yellow-white restorer's glaze covers the surface between the blue band surrounding the monogram and the blue band delineating the floral border area. This is likely designed to disguise the breaks which are visible on the rear. With closer examination, much of the navy blue and gold border and handles also appear to have been inpainted.
The white interior of the sugar bowl appears to be slightly more yellow than the other pieces of the set, however no tide lines, stains or other surface marks are visible.
There is a small spot of light brown staining on saucer without a yellow rose below the monogram, at the top proper right of the recto.
Some of the pieces are slightly dusty.
2012: No change apparent at this time. 2013: The saucer with the yellow roses (marked 4B with a sticker), which was previously broken and repaired, has a chip not repaired on its gilded edge below the bouquet of pink and yellow roses that was not specifically noted. It is unlikely that this is new damage. There are small some dark translucent spots on the interior and some yellow residue around the foot of the cup, marked F. These are not new, but should be noted. There are also small stain spots on the interiors of the teapot and creamer that should be noted. 2014: No change apparent at this time. 2015: No apparent changes noted at this time. However, it was observed that on the edges of the tray there is loss to the gilding extending out from where it has been broken and repaired. This is not new, but should be noted. 2016: No change apparent at this time. 2017: No change apparent at this time. 2018: No change apparent at this time.

In the Objects and Variable Art Conservation Lab
2015: Examined in IMA Art Storage
2016: Examined in IMA Art Storage
2017: Examined in IMA Art Storage
2018: Examined in IMA Art Storage

On underside of pieces (Letters) bear the manufacturer's stamp. The stamp shows a crown on top of a shield, with thin banners above and below. The top banner reads, "Minton's China." On the shield is written: Phillips 359 Oxford St. 155 New Bond St. The lower banner reads, "London"
The bottom of the tray also has an embossed mark which is not colored. This reads "Minton" and has a small linear design below it.

The numbering on the pieces on this set is inconsistent. Several pieces are marked with a number-letter combination, such as the teapot, which is tagged "TR10099/1A". Others, such as one saucer, bear only a letter designation (E). In several instances the labels are delaminating from the surface of the work, and may be easily lost. The pieces should be relabeled using a lettering scheme that is consistent with the IMA's collections database, and using a medium such as paint.
A) teapot B) lid for teapot C) sugar bowl D) lid for sugar bowl E) creamer F) cup G) cup H) saucer I) saucer J) tray

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: The manuscript is bound in a 19th century leather binding NOTE: Binding reattachment was provided in 2011 by book conservator Richard Baker [see conservation record]. The pages are fine vellum, and the dark text ink is an iron gall mixture (presumed). Small versals appear in red and blue paint, and select whole sentences (presumed to be of heightened importance) are written in red paint. Margins are decorated with letter elaborations, and there are some larger, ornate versals that are painted with small scenes and carry metallic gold and painted vine motifs. All paint is aqueous-based, but the exact nature of the binder has not been determined.

The Missal is in good condition overall, although some of the small illuminations and decorative versals are in poor condition. The book cover was separated from the text, but re-attached by book conservator Richard Baker in 2011. The pages are flexible, although the text near the gutter is not easily accessible. Some illuminations are in excellent condition, but others have been smeared and abraded. The iron gall ink appears to have caused losses in the vellum in some words.
2012: The condition of the bound manuscript remains unchanged since the 2011 condition survey. The conservation work performed by Richard Baker has mitigated the most compelling condition problems in the book structure itself. Media problems have not worsened, but they remain unexplored.
2013: No changes noted. The Missal has remained in Storage throughout 2013.
2014: No changes noted. The Missal has remained in Storage throughout 2014. (The book was removed from the slipcase and physically checked. The 2012 conservation work has made the missal stable and easy to handle. The pages remain very flexible and the colors and ink have not experienced any stress).
2015: No changes noted. The Missal has remained in Storage throughout 2015. A new archival storage box has been constructed to hold all four Clowes books side by side.
2016: No changes in condition noted. 2017: The Missal was examined by a Getty scholar 12/4/2017 in the IMA Print Study. He confirmed that the book was very interesting and important within this period of art historical study. The binding and text block remain stable with no changes in condition noted. The Missal will not be displayed in the Clowes Pavilion until the IMA can have an appropriate cradle support fabricated.
2018: The Missal has not been displayed, although it may have been studied by scholars in the Art Study space appending Prints, Drawings and Photograph Storage. The condition remains stable - no changes noted.
The most ornate versals contain gold touches that are laid over gesso, applied in a somewhat mounded shape to give the gold height and prominence. The gesso appears to be in good condition.

Print Study, next to F25, Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage. 2013 - Print Study 2014 - Prints, Drawings & Photographs Storage (F25) 2015 - Print Study 2016 - Print Study 2017 - Print Study 2018 - Paper Lab
Bookplate, inside front cover: Shield with the motto "Tout Jours Prest" for Frederick H. Sutton

The media is presumed to be aqueous-based for the text ink, the versals, and the illuminations. The palette is limited to mixtures of red, blue, white, and black. Some of the versals and illuminations have been severely damaged, but the cause is unknown, although the action appears to be abrasion. Fine detail and color are occasionally lost and the damaged images are reduced to dark gray tones. The iron gall ink also shows occasional trauma resulting in lost vellum substrate beneath particular letters (a relatively rare phenomenon throughout the book). No active paint or ink cleavage was sighted during this examination.

The book is housed in a custom slipcase, finished in leather and bearing the title and descriptive information stamped in gold on the spine. The slipcase separates into two pieces in the center. The book is encased in a cardboard wrapper which is finished in buckram, silk, and paper. The wrapped book is inserted into the slipcase. The fit is snug, but the wrapper protects the leather binding of the book from abrasion.

The book should travel with a courier when needed for loan. The courier would make sure that the cradle or mount adequately supported the book, and would strap the pages.
The Missal would be a very good candidate for scientific analysis. The nature of the paints and inks and also the composition of stains and soils on the pages would be of the utmost interest to scholars of the art of this period.
5 fc maximum. Pages should be rotated continuously. Locking display case required.

Current storage system is very good. The Missal is stored in a custom-sized, padded cavity within a archival blueboard lidded box. The box is shelved in Prints, Drawings, and Photographs storage. The storage area holds the customary museum climate standards.

The text and illuminations are executed on fine vellum pages. The vellum is thin and light in color, and the flesh side is smoothed to an almost undetectable nap. Some of the pages appear slightly brittle around the edges, and there are tears, repaired with parchment pieces, paper tapes, and sewing thread. Some pages sustain staining and localized distortions.

The binding of the book is composed of stiff cardboard covered in leather. It is thought to date from the 19th century. The raised bands on the spine are decorative only. The binding is stamped in gold on the spine "M.S. 14th Century". There are marbled endpapers. The leather was refurbished by Richard Baker at the time of reattachment, masking small scuff damages. The binding is providing good support for the text.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: The manuscript is composed of iron gall ink text (with some words written in red paint) and illuminations and versals executed in aqueous paint, gold leaf, and possibly shell gold on parchment and vellum pages. It is bound into a full leather binding with gold stamped decorations on both boards and spine. Some decorative outlines have been painted/dyed black. The text is sewn on raised bands

The manuscript book is in good condition overall. The pages are secure in the binding, and the imagery is largely intact.
2012: The book is currently on display in the Clowes Library. Pages are turned every six months to avoid lighting any one illumination for a prolonged period of time. The book cannot be closely examined until it is rotated out of the gallery, but the overall condition has appeared unchanged when the volume is handled for each page rotation.
2013: Two page-turn rotations are enacted per year. At that time the book is handled and examined. No damages or changes have been observed.
2014: The last page rotation of 2014 was performed 12/15/2014. The book was handled to turn the page and adjust the polyethylene straps. No new instabilities or problems were observed.
2015: The page was rotated 12/14/2015 and the condition inspection was performed at that time. There have been no changes in condition.
2016: The page was rotated for the second time in 2016 on 12/12/2016. There have been no changes in condition.
2017: No changes in condition were noted. The pages continue to be rotated in the gallery every 6 months.
2018: The book was deinstalled from the Clowes Library and will be off-view during the period of the Clowes Pavilion renovation. The storage period is expected to be about 3 years. It is hoped that if the book is put back on display, a new custom cradle will be constructed that will fit the book better and make page rotation easier.

Paper Laboratory 2013 - Book is currently on display in the Clowes Library 2014 - Book is currently on display in the Clowes Library 2015 - Book is currently on display in the Clowes Library 2016 - Book is currently on display in the Clowes Library 2017 - Book was deinstalled from the Clowes Library on 12/4/2017 and taken to the IMA Print Study for examination by a visiting Getty scholar. The book was assessed at this time 2018 - Paper Lab
The parchment pastedown of the inside front cover contains an iron gall ink inscription (numbers and letters) and a pencil inscription (French) giving information about the manuscript (school; date).

The text is written in iron gall ink and occasionally red paint. The versals and illuminations are executed in aqueous-based paints with gold detailing. Illustrations may contain leaf or shell gold; a microscopic examination will be necessary for an exact identification. The binder of the paints has not yet been determined. Illuminations are in exceptionally good condition, without cracks or losses. There are some losses in painted areas from abrasion, but this is rare. The paint appears somewhat glossy and seems to bear flexing well.

The book is housed in a custom-made cardboard slipcase faced with leather and carrying a gold stamped inscription on the spine giving the title and descriptive information. The book rests in an inner wrapper composed of cardboard and finished with buckrum, silk and paper.

The information given in IMA databases is incomplete at this writing. Scholarship is ongoing on all of the IMA illuminated manuscripts and will be updated as more facts are confirmed.
Display: Pages should be turned on the rotation schedule used for watercolors.
Scientific analysis of the materials of this book of hours would be very worthwhile in terms of dating and future care. The data would be appreciated by illumination scholars, who urge analysis whenever possible in order to add to the body of knowledge that informs the art history of these works.
A courier should travel with this book when it is requested for loan to insure that it is installed properly. The courier (if a conservator) should strap the pages, or closely observe the conservator/preparatory of the borrowing institution during the strapping procedure. The cradle support design will depend on the pages selected, and this discussion should take place well in advance of the loan.
5 fc of light maximum. Each illumination should be allowed no more than 6 months display. When all of the illuminations have been rotated in turn, the book should return to storage.

The book will be housed in a custom-designed padded cavity within an archival blueboard lidded box when it comes off display. The box is shelved in the SpaceSaver carriages in Prints, Drawings & Photographs storage. Storage maintains the standard accepted museum climate parameters.
illuminated manuscript, tempera, gold and ink on vellum

The text and illuminations are executed on either parchment or vellum pages. Pages very in thickness and character throughout the book; some sheets are thin, white and soft (split skins?), while others are thicker, with a yellowish tone on both sides and a clearly visible pore structure. The pages show discoloration and grime at the edges from handling, and several tears have been mended with parchment repairs. The first major illumination was sliced across the width, and closed with parchment and glue on the verso. A few slits across vellum pages have not been repaired. All pages are serviceable, with adequate flexibility.

The leather binding is in very good condition. The parchment pastedowns and flyleaves are for the most part intact. The text is secure in the binding, and head- and tailbands are stable. The binding has undergone repair, which is evident at the spine area where new leather has been inserted.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: The bound manuscript is composed of illuminations and text created with aqueous media on parchment or vellum, bound into a full leather binding. Illuminations include inks, colors and metal leaf components.

Display: A cradle for this book is absolutely necessary for display, and its design and manufacture may be unusually complex. At least 6 months of lead time should precede any use of this book in the galleries.

The bound manuscript is in very good condition. The illuminations/ink appear to be stable and unfaded; the binding, although damaged, is serviceable. Great care must always be taken in handling as the binding is somewhat stiff; the book should be adequately supported when on display.
2012: The condition of the bound manuscript remains unchanged. It has not been displayed at the IMA since its arrival; two other bound manuscripts from the Clowes collections are currently in the galleries. It has been kept within the slipcase in dark storage.
2013: Condition unchanged. Illuminations appear stable, The pages remain flexible and the binding opens easily.
2014: Condition unchanged. The book continues to reside in storage. It has not been actively handled/displayed/studied in 2014 and has not been moved from a stable climate.
2015: The book has remained in storage for the year. No changes in condition have been observed. A new archival storage box has been constructed for all four of the Clowes books. The box arranges the books side by side (no stacking).
2016: No changes in condition noted. Some pigment identification analysis has been performed.
2017: The book has been on display in the "Chemistry of Color" exhibition in the Golden Gallery. It was taken off view 12/4/2017 so that a visiting scholar from the Getty could examine it in the IMA Print Study. He judged that this book was very important, and deserved further study. The condition of the book is unchanged. The pages have been rotated three times within the Golden Gallery.
2018: The book has remained off-view since it was deinstalled from the Golden Gallery. No condition changes have been noted.

There is aqueous gesso present beneath the metallic gold decorative elements in the marginal vine motifs. The gesso is applied as a high, rounded shape, and the gold touches display a striking three-dimensionality.
Paper Laboratory Print Study - 2013 Prints, Drawings & Photograph Storage (F25) - 2014 Print Study - 2015 Paper Laboratory - 2016 Art Study - 2017 Paper Laboratory - 2018

Front cover pastedown, pencil, upper left corner: "1 (or 4) Large 20 small [illegible]"
Inside front cover, on verso of flyleaf, in pencil: "Hours of the Blessed Virgin Mary according to the Use of Paris_c.1420_11-90_F.C.E."
Page adjacent to flyleaf:, cut-out of printed text describing the manuscript

The illuminations and marginal decorations are executed in aqueous-based paints. The binder could contain egg, either the yolk (egg tempera paint) or the white (glair). Gum is also a possibility. The text is written in what appears to be iron gall ink, with some words in red paint / ink.

Book is stored in a custom made slipcase, which separates into two pieces at the center. The slipcase is styled to look like a book: it is faced with leather and contains gold-stamped lettering on the spine area giving title and descriptive information. The manuscript book is placed first into a cardboard wrapper finished in buckrum, silk, and paper, which slides into the slipcase. The fit is snug, but the wrapper shields the manuscript binding from abrasion.

Display: Pages should be turned on the rotation schedule used for watercolors.
A courier should travel with this book when it is requested for loan to insure that it is installed properly. The courier (if a conservator) should strap the pages, or closely observe the conservator/preparatory of the borrowing institution during the strapping procedure. The cradle support design will depend on the pages selected, and this discussion should take place well in advance of the loan.
Scientific analysis of the materials of this book of hours would be very worthwhile in terms of dating and future care. The data would be appreciated by illumination scholars, who urge analysis whenever possible in order to add to the body of knowledge that informs the art history of these works.
The splits in the binding could be repaired by a book conservator with experience in books of this period. This is not essential, but it would be very beneficial to the preservation of the binding.
5 fc with continuous rotation of the pages.

The book is stored in a custom-fitted, padded cavity within an archival blueboard lidded box. The box is kept on a shelf in the SpaceSaver carriages in Prints, Drawings, and Photographs storage. Storage areas hold temperature and humidity to standard museum parameters.

The illuminations and text are executed on fine parchment or vellum. Pages are generally even-toned and flexible (as far as is allowable by the binding). Media is occasionally disrupted by natural flaws in the skins. The flesh side of each page has a noticeably high nap, which affects how the paint is laid; the full illuminations appear on both the flesh and the hair side of the pages.

The manuscript pages are bound into a full leather binding which has not been conclusively dated. The bookboards appear to be made of wood, and the textblock is sewn onto raised bands. The pastedown and flyleaf pages are paper; the paper has the outward appearance of being handmade. The head and tail bands are hand woven. The leather is worn to a smooth and shiny state, and there are numerous marring scuffs and scratches. The leather is splitting at the top and bottom of the joins between the boards and the spine; this damage could conceivably worsen with poor handling.
2012: The bookboards have been examined through a small tear in the binding. They are not wood, as once thought, but a thick, laminar, gray cardboard. This will help to date the binding.
2013: There have been no changes in the binding. The book has been continuously stored within its wrapper and slipcover.
2015: No changes in condition observed.
Hours of the Blessed Virgin Mary
If for any reason the book travels to another destination, a courier should be required. Mount instructions may very with the venue and/or the purpose of the loan.

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Artist: Master of the Dresden Prayerbook | Netherlandish | 1440-1525||Artist, workshop of: Workshop of Master of the Dresden Prayerbook | Netherlandish | 1440-1525

The manuscript is composed of presumed iron gall ink text and aqueous paint and shell gold images and versals laid on fine vellum and bound into a leather binding with blind tooled decoration on the boards and spine. The pages are sewed onto alum-tawed raised bands. This binding appears to be the oldest in this small collection.

Paint insecurity could develop in colors showing significant crack networks. Handle with great care. Page straps should not impinge on heavily painted areas.
2018: Losses in the paint layers of some illuminations has been noted, along with obvious insecurity in surrounding paint. The book can no longer be safely displayed. Treatment need is clear.

The manuscript book is in good condition overall. The pages are secure in the binding, and the imagery is largely intact.
2012: The book is currently on display in the Clowes Library. The pages are turned every six months to ensure that no illumination receives excessive light exposure. The book cannot be deinstalled and examined at this time, but no new damages were noted during the past page rotations when the book was closely observed and handled. It is secured in a custom-fitted Plexiglas cradle and the Library case has received security upgrades. The cracked paint passages appear to be stable.
2013: The book continues on display in the Clowes Library, receiving two page-turn rotations per year. There are no condition issues to report; the book has remained in stable condition (inspected during each rotation)
2014: The last rotation of 2014 occurred 12/15/2014. The book was handled to turn to the new rotation page and to adjust the polyethylene straps. No new insecurities or problems were observed.
2015: The page was rotated 12/14/2015 and the annual inspection was performed at that time. No condition changes were noted.
2016 - The page was rotated for the second time in 2016 on 12/12/2016. No condition changes were noted.
2017: The book was taken off display in the Clowes Library and taken to the IMA Print Study to be examined by a visiting Getty scholar. The book was seen to be in stable condition with no new problems noted.
2018: The book has been deinstalled from the Clowes Library and will remain in storage for the duration of the Clowes Pavilion renovation. The storage period is welcome after years of continuous display. It has been noted that the closed book in its wrapper is an especially tight fit inside of the slipcase; it is possible that the book structure has swelled from its time continuously open when on display. The right side page, opposite the left side large size portrait bust of Christ, shows large paint losses, and the paint at the edge of the losses cannot be considered secure. More paint can be easily lost. I recommend that the book be kept in storage until it can be conserved. A specialist in the treatment of paint on vellum could be brought to the IMA to perform the treatment - this would be the best course of action.

Paper Laboratory 2013 - Book is on display in the Clowes Library 2014 - Book is on display in the Clowes Library 2015 - Book is on display in the Clowes Library 2016 - Book is on display in the Clowes Library 2017 - IMA Print Study 2018 - Paper Lab

There is an iron gall ink inscription written directly on the exposed wooden board at the front of the book listing Pietro Peregino and Albrecht Durer (attribution guesses) and a pencil inscription on the front flyleaf referring to Jane Jordaens, a previous owner. A cut-out section of a printed text on the opposite page gives a description of the book.

The text is written in iron gall ink and occasionally red paint. The versals and illuminations are executed in aqueous-based paints with shell gold detailing. The binder of the paints has not yet been determined. The illuminations near the front and rear of the book show losses and cracking in some colors; whites appear to be particularly affected when heavily painted. The famous image of Christ's head has widespread cracking in the blue background. The illuminations should be checked carefully for active insecurity.
2018: The imagery on the page opposite the Christ head has suffered large losses and the paint surrounding the losses is at times raised and insecure. The book should not be used again until this can be addressed. A conservator should handle the book at all times, especially during visits by scholars.

The book is housed in a custom-made cardboard slipcase faced with leather and carrying a gold stamped inscription on the spine giving the title and descriptive information. The book rests in an inner wrapper composed of cardboard and finished with buckrum, silk and paper.

The information given in IMA databases is incomplete at this writing. Scholarship is ongoing on all of the IMA illuminated manuscripts and will be updated as more facts are confirmed.
Display: Pages should be turned on the rotation schedule used for watercolors.
Scientific analysis of the materials of this book of hours would be very worthwhile in terms of dating and future care. The data would be appreciated by illumination scholars, who urge analysis whenever possible in order to add to the body of knowledge that informs the art history of these works.
A courier should travel with this book when it is requested for loan to insure that it is installed properly. The courier (if a conservator) should strap the pages, or closely observe the conservator/preparatory of the borrowing institution during the strapping procedure. The cradle support design will depend on the pages selected, and this discussion should take place well in advance of the loan.
5 fc maximum. Each illumination should be on view no longer than 6 months. When all of the illuminations have been shown, the book should return to storage.

The book is stored in a custom-fitted, padded cavity within an archival blueboard lidded box. The box is stored on a shelf in the SpaceSaver units in Prints, Drawings & Photographs storage. Storage areas are adjusted to standard accepted museum climate parameters.

The text and illuminations are executed on pages of fine vellum which are soft, bright, and very thin. The pages are yellowish and soiled at the turning corners, and some have significant localized cockling. The large, full illuminations are painted on pages that are somewhat thicker and sturdier. There are only a few repairs (for edge tears) throughout the book, consisting of sections of parchment and glue. The first flyleaf page at the front of the book has been torn from the bottom edge to the center of the sheet along the gutter.

The active loss will be halted on the page described above. The book can then be carefully used in the galleries. However, the paint must never be considered absolutely strong and stable, even after treatment. Fragility will continue, and new outbreaks of lifting and loss could occur as the pages are flexed. (2018)

The full leather binding on this manuscript is in stable condition. Old insect holes are visible in the binding spine and the parchment pastedowns and flyleaf pages. The front pastedown is missing (exposing the wooden board) and the first flyleaf page has been sliced out. The sewing bands are visible in the gutter area between the bookboards and the text. The tailband has unraveled slightly. The text remains securely sewn.
Hours of the Blessed Virgin Mary for use of Rome

mv.d: Additional Information & Corrections to the Collection Database

m.mv: Artist, attributed to: Attributed to Homer, Winslow | American | 1836-1910
Drawing is executed on colored, textured paper with graphite pencil and white aqueous paint.
The materials of this artwork are not clearly understood at this time, so caution is urged in regard to rotation durations and light levels. The paper should be considered very fragile.

The paper displays a warm gray-green tonality on the verso and a very dark brown coloration on the recto surface. The brown coloration appears diffuse at the edges it shares with white paint areas. It is unclear what chemical reactions have taken place, but the paper remains flexible in spite of what appears to be severe discoloration. The graphite image is difficult to detect when pencil marks are made with light pressure. It is truthful to say that the deep color of the paper obscures the fine details of the drawing. The white painted areas appear stable.
2012: There has been no change in the condition of the drawing, which has remained in dark storage since the 2011 conservation survey
2013: No changes observed.
2014: The print has remained in storage since it entered the IMA. It is in a Solander box within an IMA museum mat. One new observation: the lower left corner tip has been bent forward. This crease should receive a reinforcing mend on the verso to ensure that the tip is never lost. The bent section is tiny, and this should not be considered an emergency, but it is worthwhile to note the problem for future work.
2015: No change in the condition of the artwork.
2016: No change in the condition of the artwork
2017: No change in the condition of the artwork
2018: No change in the condition of the artwork

F25 - Prints, Drawings, & Photographs storage 2013 - Print Study 2014 - Prints, Drawings & Photograph Storage (F25) 2015 - Print Study 2016 - Print Study 2017 - Prints, Drawings, & Photographs Storage 2018: Paper Laboratory
Signature, lower left corner, soft pencil: "Homer". Dated also, but the number is somewhat unclear because of overlapping marks in this area.

The image is executed in white aqueous paint and graphite pencil. The image is in good condition; the white areas are fairly thinly painted, and there is no cracking or flaking visible at this time. There is an unusual diagonal linear pattern impressed in some areas of white paint, which probably occurred during or around the time of creation. The pencil lines are for the most part strong and clear, the darkest lines impressed into the paper.
Drawing is in an IMA museum mat, appropriately hinged. The mat is new and in very good condition.

This work would be a good candidate for analysis to determine the reason for the brown coloration and if the mechanism driving the color change can be significantly slowed through passive means. It might also assist in understanding the mysterious splotches of lighter paper color found throughout the middleground. The old hinges on the verso top edge could be removed at some future date.
5 fc of light absolute maximum. Restricted display is recommended.
The drawing has been given an IMA 4-ply museum window mat and is stored in a Solander box. Temperature and humidity are within accepted museum standards.

The paper has a linear texture which could be part of a laid & chain pattern or could be a decorative texture impressed in wove paper. The grayish green color of the verso surface may not represent the original color of the sheet; it could be a faded stage of a bluish paper. The deep brown of the front surface is very unusual in its intensity and its nebulous character around the edges of painted areas. The white paint appears to protect the paper from the severe darkening on the front surface.,The verso is more difficult to interpret: the area behind the sky(recto) shows an interplay of several tones, while the color of the paper behind the heavily discolored foreground(recto) is more even. There are numerous poor quality hinges along the verso top edge along with thick adhesive residues.
Should not travel until the materials of the paper are better understood. Also, the white paint could be vulnerable to cracking and micro-flaking.

At some point, the acidic paper hinge and mount residues can be removed from the verso top edge. This may have a higher degree of difficulty than usual given the heightened discoloration of the paper. Also, pressure and expansion experienced during the procedure might aggravate the painted image on the recto; extensive testing will be required.
The nature of the discoloration is not understood at this point in time, so it is not possible to predict the possibility of improvement through treatment.
